The president's submission4 One of the main objectives of the Court and its tasks of transparency and accountability is to bring the European Court of Auditors closer to EU citizens.
I therefore very much welcome you as readers of the first annual report of the European Court of Auditors.
The aim of the report is to provide an overview of the Court's activities in 2007, in which it celebrates a 30-year term as an external auditor of the European Union, which, in accordance with its mission, contributes to the improvement of the financial management of the EU and is an independent guardian of the financial interests of Union citizens.
The Court shall make its main contribution to its audits and reports which enable the audit authority to improve its financial management and to assist the discharge authority (the European Parliament and the Council) in exercising control over the implementation of the EU budget.
This report reviews the audit reports published in 2007 and contains the main conclusions on the implementation of the EU budget for 2006 and on the sound financial management of the EU.
The Court not only informs about financial management over recent years but also actively participates in the creation of an EU financial control framework.
2007 was very important for EU financial management.
In the Court's opinion on important changes in the responsibility of the Member States and the Court's contribution to the public consultation on budgetary reform launched by the European Commission.
None of the Court's 2007 results would have been possible without the involvement, expertise and competence of 850 employees.
Staff is the main capital of a future-oriented body that is committed to continuous improvement.
This first annual activity report contains detailed information on the Court's reform process, which started in 2006 as a result of self-assessment.
Progress was made in 2007 in implementing the Action Plan, which was set up and, at the end of 2007, the so-called peer review procedure was launched under the direction of a group of auditors belonging to the national accounting tribunals in Canada, Austria, Norway and Portugal.
The first outcome of this reform process was the following declaration on the mandate, design, values and strategic objectives of the Court, on the basis of which the Court will report on future actions in due time.
I wish you a great deal of joy in reading the first annual activity report and I hope it will be of benefit to you.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
The European Court of Auditors shall be responsible, in accordance with the Treaty, for the control of the EU's finances.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving the EU's financial management while at the same time acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES In order to achieve its task, the European Court of Auditors has taken note of the following strategic objectives: Professionality Productivity Group of addressees Development and growth Audit methods, adequate audit strategy, further development of audit practice in the public sector, the development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards for EU funds, cooperation with EU-ORKB, an effective control framework within the Community for control, selection of relevant audit topics, approximation of time, transparency and readability of reports, quality of performance control, increased impact of reports on the development of relations with the audited entities, with a view to a better understanding of the audit process and better acceptance of audit results; development of contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as a budgetary authority and discharge authority; effective communication with EU citizens in the use of peer review experience in order to strengthen and strengthen the organisation, methods, procedures and results of the peer review process and achieve maximum efficiency; implementation of effective and dynamic staff policy; development of high-quality professional training; modernisation of infrastructure;
8 THE THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK WHAT'S THE COURT'S ROLE?
The budget of the European Union is around EUR 120 billion, representing around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of the 27 Member States.
Compared to national budgets, this is a small percentage.
However, for some Member States, EU measures play an important role in financing public actions, roughly corresponding to the GNI of some countries, such as Romania.
Over time, budget dynamics have changed and agricultural and cohesion policy are the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
The budget shall be adopted annually by the Council on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and by the European Parliament directly elected on a proposal from the European Commission.
The Commission is implementing the budget itself, but it is sharing a large part of the administrative tasks with the Member States, in particular with regard to agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure.
Depending on the expenditure system, national authorities may be responsible for defining the expenditure strategy, selecting beneficiaries and projects, as well as for the implementation of payments.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments on the basis of applications of the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union.
9 BOX 1, HOW DOES THE EU EXPECT HIS HIS HIS HIS HIS HISSELF HISSELF?
The EU budget serves to a large extent different objectives than national budgets, partly due to differences in competences.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which are usually the majority of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which usually takes the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has been the main contribution to budget expenditure, although it is now showing a downward trend.
In 2008, a slightly less than half of the budget for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development, was foreseen.
Since the 1980s, a significant proportion of expenditure has come from the area of cohesion.... regional and social Sustainable growth expenditure in 2008, including the lion's share of cohesion, was estimated at 38% of the budget.
This heading also covers a significant part of the EU's research budget.
About 6% of the budget is spent on the management of the Community institutions.

Democratic society needs complete and reliable public information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both in order to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
The European Court of Auditors acts as an external EU auditor, ensuring that EU funds, wherever they are used, are correctly booked and spent in accordance with the rules, taking due account of the optimal spending of funds.
The Court's audit work is used by the Commission, Parliament and Council, as well as by the Member States, to improve the EU's financial management.
In addition to the Court's activities, many national audit authorities examine EU funds, provided that they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.

The annual statement of assurance is commonly known under the acronym DAS (including Déclaration d.Assurance).
1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
The Court carries out an audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with the International Audit Principles (ISA), which apply both in the public and private sectors.
The Court is actively involved in the development of international audit standards in cooperation with the national audit bodies, which promote standardisation bodies (Intosai, IFAC) 2.
In order to ensure compliance of payments with the rules and legal framework, the Court is based on the results of both the examination of supervisory and control systems to prevent and detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and the sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Where systems are checked and considered reliable, the number of operations which the Court needs to examine in order to obtain reliable conclusions on their legality and regularity shall be reduced accordingly.
With regard to the selection of topics for performance control, the Court is seeking to identify the areas of control for which it can be expected that they will be the most likely to improve the expected savings, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending.

13 BOX 2 BOX 2 BOX 2 PRELIMINARY COURT CONTROLS WITH REGARD TO THE PAYMENT OF THE EU BUDGET The Court does not have the resources necessary for the detailed examination of all operations of the EU budget.
The Court follows these actions up to the final recipient of the aid, such as the farmer in southern Germany.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks, for example, to verify whether the data contained in the proposal is in line with the reality.
Population of all agricultural payments By applying a statistical sample, the results can be summarised for the population, i.e. for a specific area of income or expenditure, and can be used as a basis for a general assessment, together with the information resulting from the evaluation of the system.
This chart shows how the Court works to determine transactions for the purpose of carrying out a detailed audit.
In practice, the Court's random checks are more complex, for example on the basis of two-step sampling, in order to improve the effectiveness of the checks.

The organisational review (see page 17) shows that there are four thematic control groups that cover different budgetary areas (protection and management of natural resources, structural policy, transport, research and energy, external policy, own resources, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policy).
The Fifth Audit Group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for horizontal issues such as coordination in the field of assurance, quality assurance, development of the audit methodology of the Court and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a management committee composed of members of all audit groups shall be responsible for preparing all administrative matters requiring a formal decision of the Court.
MEMBERS of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a six-year term, as proposed by each Member State.
In addition to the functions within the college, which is responsible for final decisions on audits and opinions, as well as on further strategic and administrative issues, each member shall be responsible for its specific tasks mainly in the field of audit.
The member shall then adopt the report in the audit group or in the Court, and after its adoption in the European Parliament, in the Council and in front of other interested parties.
On 1 January 2007, together with the accession of Bulgaria and Romania, the Court welcomed two new members, Nadešda Sandolova and Ovidiu Ipir.
A year later, on 1 January 2008, the Court adopted three new members: Michel Cretin (France), Henri Grethena (Luxembourg) and Harald Noack (Germany), as the terms of office of the predecessors expired.
In addition, the Council extended the term of office of four members (Greece, the Netherlands, Austria and the United Kingdom) for another six years.

The President-in-Office of the European Court of Auditors shall be the President, elected from among them for three years, with the possibility of voting again.
The President's role is a priority inter pares.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in relations with the discharge authority, with the other institutions of the European Union and with the highest audit bodies of the Member States and the beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, a member of the Portuguese Court, was elected President of the Court.
The Secretary-General of the Secretary-General shall be the highest-ranking member of the institution and shall be appointed by the Court for a period of six years and shall be renewable.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the management of the Court's staff and staff, including vocational training and the Translation Directorate, with the exception of the Gaelic language, broken down by official language (22).
The Secretary-General shall also be responsible for the Secretariat-General.
The mandate of the current Secretary-General of the Court of Justice, Michel Hervé, was extended on 1 July 2007.
The Court's staff shall have approximately 850 staff (836 staff on 31 December 2007) and shall include auditors (484), translators (162) and administrative staff.
The Court's auditors have broad training profiles and appropriate professional experience in the public and private sectors, in particular in the field of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit, and in the field of law and economics.
Like other EU institutions, the Court employs citizens of all Member States.
18 SUMMARY OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND 3 THE COURT'S COMMENTS The results of the Court's audits of accounting and compliance audits are in most cases included in the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund (EDF) and in the specific annual reports on Union agencies and bodies.
Performance control results shall be published during the year in the form of special reports.
The Court shall also publish opinions on draft legislation affecting financial management.
ANNUAL REPORT 2006 ANNUAL REPORT ON IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET As the Court has repeatedly stated in its annual reports on the implementation of the EU general budget, the relevant and relevant internal control systems established by the Commission and the Member States are of key importance for ensuring sound financial management of the EU.
In recent years, the Court has recognised the Commission's efforts to promote and apply improved internal control and management procedures both with regard to the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the operations set out therein.
The 2006 Annual Report continued this tradition by identifying areas where there is a significant need for improvement in some cases, as well as areas where the situation is still unsatisfactory.
The Court found that the final accounts of the European Communities, which contained a report on the implementation of the EU budget for 2006, contained, in all material respects, a true and fair view of the financial situation and the results of the Communities, except in the event of excessive amounts of commitments and advance payments on the balance sheet.
It is therefore considered necessary that further improvements are needed to ensure that the newly introduced accrual accounting is fully satisfactory and that its potential as a reliable management and control tool is fully exploited.
3 This section aims at introducing, not a summary of, the Court's reports and opinions.
Further information can be found in the full text of the Court's documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
With regard to the expenditure areas covered by the final accounts of the European Communities in respect of expenditure areas in which the majority of payments originate from agriculture [mainly agricultural expenditure not covered by the Integrated Management and Control System (IACS), structural measures, internal policies and many external policies in respect of agriculture, the Court gives a negative opinion on the legality and regularity of agricultural expenditure and concludes that there are still significant errors in these expenditure areas.
In the case of payments in these areas, the supervisory and control systems have only partially reduced the risk of errors in the legality and regularity of transactions.
The Court stresses that complex or unclear eligibility criteria or complex legislation had a significant impact on the legality and regularity of the transactions.
However, the Court noted a significant decrease in the estimated overall level of errors in the agricultural transactions and concluded that the HACCP is an effective system, if properly applied, in order to reduce the risk of irregular expenditure.
In addition, the Court found that the underlying transactions did not show significant errors, including payments related to administrative expenditure, a major part of the pre-accession strategy and part of the external policy (see Box 3). 19

As a result, they may not, in general, be able to limit errors in underlying transactions to an acceptable level.

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND (EFF) In 2007, the Court also published an annual report on the European Development Fund (EFF).
While the Court was able to issue an opinion on the reliability of the EDF accounts, the opinion on the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions of payments approved by delegations in the beneficiary countries was limited in view of the significant level of error in those transactions.
OTHER ANNUAL REPORT In addition, a further 28 special annual reports on European agencies and other decentralised bodies and an annual report on the assessment of the effectiveness of the management of the European Central Bank were published in 2007.
SPECIAL REPORTS REPORTED IN 2007 IN 2007 The Court published a total of nine special reports.
The reports dealt with research on financial management issues in many different fields, ranging from cooperation in the field of VAT (No 8/2007) to capacity building in distant countries such as Angola and Vietnam (No 6/2007).
The Court's audit revealed various types of problems with different consequences.
The weaknesses identified by the Court in relation to the expenditure of the EU institutions on buildings (No 2/2007) indicate that not all EU funds have been used in this area.
The shortcomings identified in the report on monitoring, inspection and sanctioning systems with regard to the rules for the conservation of Community fish stocks (No 7/2007) can have serious consequences not only for water resources but also for the future of the fisheries sector.
Regardless of the different uses of resources in the different areas of the EU budget, the Court's reports point to a number of common topics which can be discussed as follows: 22 • • • Although the use of resources should be both rapid and effective, stress may arise in the pursuit of these two objectives.
This topic is the subject of the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and the Commission report on the management of the CARDS programme in the Western Balkan countries (No 5/2007).
Although planning does not guarantee effectiveness, it is important.
The strategic and long-term planning issues were addressed in the reports on the expenditure of the EU institutions on buildings (No 2/2007) and the evaluation of the EU Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development (RTD) (No 9/2007) and in the two external assistance reports, one on CARDS (No 5/2007) and the other on the effectiveness of technical assistance in capacity building (No 6/2007).
The Commission's assessments are a key element of their performance management system for assessing performance and, if necessary, assessing performance improvement needs.
Where the evaluation takes place at an early stage of the programming cycle, this means that progress is insufficient and insufficient data is available for the evaluation.
On the other hand, where evaluations are carried out at a later date, it may be possible to reduce the possibility of making changes in the current period of time and improvements before the next one begins.
The issue of the proper timing of the evaluations was addressed both in the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and in the report on the evaluation of RTD (No 9/2007).
23 • • Evaluation, like audits, is more difficult to carry out when the objectives of the expenditure programmes are unclear, which was the next topic of the last two reports.
The management and control of EU expenditure are subject to complex rules, which must be clearly and unambiguously formulated to ensure that they are used for their intended purposes.
The existence of clear definitions and rules is crucial for the collection or use of funds as planned.
This topic was addressed in the reports on the European Refugee Fund (No 2007/2007) and on the control of goods and substitutions carried out by Member States in respect of exports of agricultural products (No 4/2007).
The lack of common definitions is one of the factors that may affect the completeness, comparability and reliability of data from different Member States.
This may have consequences if the data are the basis for a decision, for example on the allocation of funds.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED In 2007, the Court also contributes to improving the EU's financial management by issuing opinions on proposals or issues relating to financial management.
These opinions are required as part of the procedure for the adoption of financial rules 4 or may be issued at the request of one of the other institutions of the Community 5. In addition, the Court may issue opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions may concern certain areas of expenditure, such as the two 2007 opinions, which concern the new regulations of the European Development Fund (Nos 2/2007 and 9/2007).
They may also cover broader issues related to EU financial management, such as the Court's opinion on the annual summaries, national declarations and the audit work of the national audit authorities (No 6/2007).
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise over the years in the audit of EU financial management and in some cases relate to certain audits.
For example, in its opinion on ensuring the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation (No 3/2007), the Court refers to the recommendation in the previous special report that the Commission should take action to improve the reliability of sources of information on fraud.
The need for simplification is a matter repeated in the Court's opinions (see, for example, Opinion No 7/2007 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities).
In its 2007 opinion (No 6/2007), the Court presented its position on the annual summaries, as well as on the so-called national declarations, which some Member States voluntarily presented on their own initiative.
This opinion was discussed in detail in the section on the Court's position on the matter.

Most of the Court's opinions have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on the Court's website.
26 IMPLEMENTATION AND IMPLEMENTATION Public control plays a key role in modern democratic societies in terms of effective financial management.
Control activities shall be transferred to addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, in order to determine whether their taxpayers' money is spent properly and properly.
In this way, public control is a key element of responsibility and a useful basis for public debate.
In this respect, the Court's work has considerable potential for impact.
The Court's audits serve decision-makers in the institutions concerned in the European context, in particular the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States, as a direct source of information.
On the basis of this information, they may take action, with or without reference to the conclusions of the checks.
Although the Court's audit activities have the greatest impact on its published reports, its impact already has some impact on the entire audit process.
In particular, all checks shall lead to the presentation of detailed checks to be submitted to the audited entity in order to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations.
The final text of the report shall also be subject to the procedure of the adversarial procedure to ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that we ensure that the final text of the report is subject to the procedure of the adversarial procedure.
The replies of the audited entity, in particular the Commission, shall be published together with the reports.
In its replies, the audited entity often takes into account the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to resolve them.
Following the audit work and the publication of the report, the audit results shall be assessed and used by Parliament and the Council to carry out their policy tasks to monitor the use of budgetary resources.
In the framework of the Court's annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form the basis for the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision.
The 2006 discharge procedure drew particular attention to the Court's conclusions on structural policy.
In its resolution on discharge for 2006, Parliament refers directly to the action plan proposed by the Commission directly following the conclusions of the Court's annual report and asks for quarterly reports on its implementation.
Parliament also calls for better insight into the corrective measures taken to remedy errors and errors.
Special reports shall also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, as they are published during the year, the presentation of special reports and the debate on this issue were usually held at Parliament and Council meetings at an earlier stage.
A good example of possible follow-up is the recent special report on building expenditure (No 2/2007).
Parliament has already entrusted its Management Board with the preparation of a report in which it will examine whether it is possible to create a European Construction Office entrusted with the construction and maintenance of the buildings of the European Union institutions and bodies.
Another example is the Court's report on the checks carried out by the Member States on the export of agricultural products (No 4/2007).
The Council and the Commission responded promptly to the Court's recommendations by amending the existing rules.
The impact of audit reports can be increased by their involvement in relevant media, which will increase their attention and encourage public debate.
The media is the most direct source of information for citizens.
Overall, the media report for the Court's annual report is quite extensive, but the press has also followed some special reports with interest.
The report on fisheries (No 7/2007) has paid great attention to the media.
In order to discuss the Court's report, the Extraordinary Council for Fisheries was convened and the Commission launched a procedure which could lead to changes to the legislation in order to remedy the deficiencies identified.
This is an example of a report which, due to its actuality and its actuality, could make a very valuable contribution to the decision-making process.
This section provides some guidance on the impact of the Court's reports published in 2007.
For more information on the follow-up to the Court's earlier observations, see the relevant chapters of the Court's annual report.
The most frequently reported by the Court in its most recent annual report is that, despite the actions taken, the shortcomings identified in the previous year were only partially resolved.
The Court's opinions should also be taken into account when considering the impact of the Court's work.
The Court intends to examine more and more the long-term impact of its audit work and of its opinions in this area.
This can be illustrated by the example shown in Box 4.

The opinion on a single study (No 2/2004) in 2004 made it possible to make a significant contribution.
In this opinion, the Court proposes that the definition and transposition of the entire internal control be included in a single integrated control system, which includes common principles and principles and ensures that the costs and benefits are proportionate.
The opinion on the Single Audit in 2007 turned into a reference document for the Commission, but also for the Court, in its comments on the definition of effective and effective internal control in the updated rules for the implementation of the Financial Regulation (opinion No 1/2007).
The integrated audit approach is reflected in the Commission Action Plan for the Integrated Internal Control Framework for 2006.
The Commission has taken steps to highlight the role and responsibilities of the Member States in internal control, including a new commitment to submit annual summaries of opinions, statements and audits carried out in accordance with the regulations applicable to each area of expenditure.
28 THE COURT'S OPINIONS NATIONAL SUMMARY AND DECLARATIONS The Commission and the Member States have taken initiatives to increase the involvement of Member States in the cycle of responsibility for EU measures.
The aim is to address partly the problem of significant errors in the legality and regularity of the main expenditure areas in the budget, in particular in areas where the Commission and the Member States share management.
Among the most significant recent changes are the obligation for Member States to submit annual summaries of available audit results and declarations, voluntary initiatives taken by certain Member States to submit national declarations and decisions by certain national control authorities on the preparation of audit reports on the management of EU funds.
In Opinion No 6/2007, the Court considers that all these elements, if properly implemented, can contribute to the improvement of the management and control of EU funds.
The opinion clarifies the conditions under which these elements may constitute added value and may be applied by the Court in accordance with international auditing standards.
Since annual summaries form part of the internal control system, the Court will assess, within the framework of its usual control procedures, to what extent they will improve the functioning of internal control.
Annual summaries may lead to improved overall control of EU funds in shared management areas to the extent that they reflect strengths and weaknesses.
National statements are based on voluntary initiatives taken by some Member States, taken at the highest level and presented to national Parliaments.
Although they do not in themselves constitute conclusive evidence, they can be seen as an innovative element of internal control and can provide valuable information on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court recognises the potential benefits of the statements of national and national audit work with a view to raising awareness in the Member States of the importance of internal control of EU funds.
The audit work carried out by national audit authorities (national audit reports) with regard to the legality and regularity of EU expenditure or with regard to national declarations could provide the Court with audit evidence if the Court is able to ensure the relevance and quality of the audit work in accordance with international audit standards.
In such a case, the Court will take into account the notes issued by the national control authorities in the planning and conduct of its own controls.
National declarations and control reports shall contain declarations concerning control systems.
National declarations may also contain certain opinions on the legality and regularity of transactions.
Experience has shown that the main risk to the legality and regularity of transactions is the reliability of the information provided by the beneficiaries at the time of the application for EU funding and not the way in which the data is processed by the Member States and the Commission.
The declaration that systems operate in accordance with the requirements of the EU Regulation cannot in itself guarantee the legality and regularity of the transactions in question.
Recognising the need to strengthen the role of national control authorities in the overall context of the responsibility for EU expenditure, the Contact Committee of the EU Supreme Audit Authorities has set up a working group on the harmonisation of control standards and standards adapted to the EU context.
Common control methods and methods increase the Court's capacity to rely on the work of the national control authorities, provided that the quality of the work is directly demonstrated.
VERIFICATION OF the EU BUDGET In September 2007, the Commission published a consultative document to launch an open debate on EU funding in the framework of an extensive budget review.
At the beginning of April 2008, the Court presented its contribution to the debate in which it presented the main principles to be taken into account in the development of the new programmes in order to ensure European added value in order to ensure clarity of objectives, simplification, dealing with reality, transparency and accountability.

These visits are normally applicable to central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds as well as to final beneficiaries.
The team of controllers usually consists of two to three controllers and the length of the examination trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
In 2007, travel expenses related to control travel amounted to EUR 0.49 million (compared to EUR 0.43 million in 2006).
This represents a significant investment to ensure a sufficient level of control of all levels and the location of the management of EU funds.

Emmanuel Rauch, a French auditor who has worked on the farm for several years, and his Spanish colleague, Mr Alejandro Ballester, were team leaders during the preparatory phase in autumn 2005.
The audit included travel to six Member States, Denmark to Italy, both to central administrative authorities to gain insight into control systems and to major ports to assess how systems work in practice.
To the extent that the language of the members of the team was insufficient, the translators from the language service department of the Court provided assistance.
The team of auditors is very proud to have contributed to the fact that political decision-makers will gradually see the serious consequences of the implementation of the Community's fisheries policy.
Other audit authorities also expressed interest in the study as they provide inspiration and know-how, for example, in the case of an upcoming analysis of a similar issue in the Baltic States.

The INTERNAL Service of the Court's Internal Audit Service shall support the Court in the achievement of its objectives through a systematic and methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
Furthermore, the Internal Audit Department presents proposals to improve the effectiveness of the Court.
Overall, the aim is to assess the performance of the different services in the implementation of strategies, programmes and actions to continuously improve.
In 2007, the Court's Internal Audit Department focused on auditing accounting (including supporting the work of the Court's external auditor), ex ante control, the implementation of internal control standards, the Court's recent enlargement (K2 Building) and the Court's recruitment procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and an external expert, shall monitor and ensure the independence of the internal auditor.
In addition, it shall examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and, if necessary, entrust them with specific audit tasks.
The Committee met eight times in 2007.

The President's presentation of the Court of Auditors, as an independent EU audit body, makes a unique contribution to improving the EU's financial management and promoting transparency and accountability through the provision of audit services and as a model.
2008 was the year of significant progress and significant progress in the EU financial management referred to in this annual activity report for the Court.
An important event was the evaluation of the experts of the European Court of Auditors by an international expert group which led to a positive conclusion on the adequacy of the Court's audit management framework and the independence and objectivity of its work.
In its annual report for the financial year 2007, published in November 2008, the Court issued for the first time an opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts.
However, as in previous years, too high amounts of errors in legality and regularity have been identified in areas of the EU budget, which represent the largest part of the expenditure.
In 2008, the Court also recognised changes at EU and national level which could lead to significant improvements in the EU's financial management in the future.
The two examples presented in this Annual Activity Report relate to the ongoing review process of the EU budget to which the Court has made an active contribution and to the Commission Communication on the Acceptable Risk of Error.
In the field of international relations, the Court has overseen the organisation of the meetings of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the European Union's Supreme Audit Authorities on the reform of the EU's budget and the renewed Lisbon Strategy, and has also played a host role in recent EU-ORKB-related workshops in the context of the action taken in response to the current financial crisis.
Following rapid changes in the audit environment, the Court is forced to adapt through internal reforms in order to better fulfil its obligations under the Treaty and to fulfil its tasks effectively.
In 2008, the Court took significant steps to implement its mandate and its action plan to develop the audit strategy for 2009-2012.
The audit strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of controls and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will be essential for the Court's work programmes during this period, as well as its efforts to continuously improve and exploit the main challenges and opportunities to exploit the potential for improvement as set out in the peer review procedure.
Through their competences and involvement, the Court's staff have a key role to play in carrying out the Court's audit work as an independent guardian of the citizens' financial interests in order to improve financial management.
On behalf of the Court and on my own behalf, I would like to thank all the workers for their commitment and professional work last year.
Special thanks for his personal commitment and commitment are due to our former secretary-general, Michel Hervé, who was expelled at the end of 2008.
I wish you a pleasant look at this annual activity report, which will give you insight into the Court and a review of the actions taken in 2008.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5

THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK THE COURT'S WORK IS THE EU BUDGET The European Union's budget is around EUR 120 billion, representing around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of the 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States EU funding plays an important role in funding public actions, which corresponds approximately to the GNI of some Member States.
The European Union's revenue consists mainly of contributions from Member States from their gross national income (GNI of 65,4%) or VAT collected by Member States (VAT of 16,9%).
Customs duties and agricultural duties (so-called traditional own resources. 16,5 %) also represent a significant part of revenue.
Over time, the structure of the budget has changed and agricultural and cohesion policy are the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).

The EU budget is financed by Member States' financial contributions (mainly on the basis of national GNI) and by agricultural duties and duties.
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than the national budget, partly due to differences in competence.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually represent a significant part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, usually in the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has been the main part of the budget expenditure, although it is currently in decline.
In 2009, 45.3% of the budget for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development, was foreseen.
Since the 1980s, a significant part of the expenditure on cohesion policy, i.e. regional and social development, has been earmarked for co-financing various projects, ranging from road construction projects in Poland to training for unemployed people in Spain.
For 2009, sustainable growth expenditure of 39.6% of the budget is foreseen, of which cohesion policy is part.
This budgetary area also covers the majority of the EU's research budget.
Furthermore, to a large extent, EU funding is devoted to development aid and humanitarian aid, as well as to countries which have close relations with the Union or are candidate countries.
6.7% of the budget is allocated to the management of the Community institutions.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice The European Union, as an international partner The management of agriculture for the conservation and management of natural resources 45.3 % 1.2 % 7.2 % 6.7 % of EU expenditure on cohesion for sustainable growth Source: European Union general budget for the financial year 2009 (OJ L 69, 13.3.2009). 39.6%
The budget shall be approved annually by the Council on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and by the European Parliament, on a proposal from the European Commission.
The Commission shall draw up the budget and be responsible for its implementation.
Most of the budget, in particular, in particular, in the field of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure, shall be conducted in cooperation with Member States.
A specific feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments on the basis of applications of the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers, across the Union8.
Democratic society needs complete and reliable public information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
The EU, like its Member States, has an external audit body, which acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens.
The European Court of Auditors, acting as an external EU auditor, ensures that EU funds, wherever they are used, have been properly booked and spent in accordance with the law, taking due account of the optimal spending of funds.
The Court's audit work is used by Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States to improve the EU's financial management.
The Court's work provides an important basis for the annual discharge procedure during which Parliament, on the basis of Council recommendations, decides whether the Commission has fulfilled its responsibility for the implementation of the budget during the previous year.
Despite its name, the Court has no judicial powers.
In the budgetary areas where shared management is carried out, Member States shall cooperate with the Commission in the establishment of monitoring and control systems, i.e. internal control, in order to ensure the proper and proper use of the funds.
Internal control therefore has a European and national dimension.
In addition to the Court's activities, many national audit authorities check whether EU funds are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.

2 In accordance with the Treaty, the Court is required to issue such a statement or a review opinion on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
In this context, the underlying transactions are usually payments to final beneficiaries from the EU budget.
The annual statement of assurance is commonly known under the acronym DAS (e.g. Déclaration d.Assurance).
Unlike practices in the Member States, the Court makes such a statement on the EU budget as a whole.
3 The European Development Fund (EDF) is based both on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP)
The Court carries out an audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with the International Audit Principles (ISA), which apply both in the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international control rules do not fully cover the Court's compliance control.
The Court, in cooperation with national audit bodies, actively participates in the development of international audit standards promoted by standardisation bodies (INTOSAI, IFAC) 4.
In order to ensure compliance of payments with the rules and legal framework, the Court is based on the results of an analysis of both supervisory and control systems to prevent and detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and on the sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Where systems are reviewed and are considered reliable, the number of transactions which the Court must examine in order to obtain reliable conclusions on their legality and regularity.
Other sources, such as the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In the case of performance control, the Court uses a number of control methods to assess management and monitoring systems and to assess performance data on the basis of the criteria under the rules on sound financial management.
With regard to the selection of topics for performance control, the Court seeks to identify the control areas for which the greatest impact can be expected in the form of the exposed potential for improvement in the savings, efficiency and effectiveness of EU expenditure. 11 the Council decision on the association of overseas countries and territories (OCTs) is closed.
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see the policy areas "External relations, development and enlargement') and partly through delegations in beneficiary countries.
The Investment Facility under the EFF shall be managed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and shall not be audited by the Court.

Therefore, in order to obtain results representative of the population as a whole, in connection with the preparation of DAS, it uses statistical sampling methods.
The sample shall be carried out by random selection of a representative sample of transactions underlying the underlying transactions from all areas of the Union budget, such as agriculture, in order to carry out a detailed assessment.
The Court monitors these operations up to the final recipient of the aid, for example the farmer in France.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks, for example, to determine whether the relevant information contained in the proposal is in line with the reality.
Where the statistical sample is statistical, the results may be calculated for the population concerned, i.e. for a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and may, together with the information resulting from the evaluation of the system, form the basis for the overall assessment.
In order to determine how the audit opinion must be issued, the Court, in practice, compares the results of statistical checks in trials with the specific ceiling it considers acceptable in relation to the so-called materiality threshold.

The Court of Auditors shall act as a collegial body consisting of 27 members from each Member State.
All audit reports and opinions shall be adopted by the College.
The Court shall consist of five audit groups to which individual members shall be assigned.
As is apparent from the organisational chart (see page 17), there are four thematic control groups covering different budgetary areas (protection and management of natural resources and structural measures, transport, research and energy, external resources, income, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The Fifth Audit Group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for horizontal issues such as coordination in the field of assurance, quality assurance, the development of the audit methodology of the Court and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, the Management Committee shall be responsible for preparing all administrative matters requiring a formal decision of the Court.
MEMBERS of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a six-year term, as proposed by each Member State, with the possibility of re-election.
Members shall carry out their tasks in the full independence in the general interest of the European Union.
In addition to the functions of the College, which is responsible for final decisions on audits and opinions, as well as on broader strategic and administrative issues, each member shall be responsible for its specific tasks, particularly in the field of audit.
The proper examination work is usually the task of examiners in each examination department and is coordinated by the relevant member with the support of his office.
The member shall then adopt the report in the audit group or in the Court and after its adoption in the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties.

SUMMARY OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINION5 OF THE ANNUAL REPORTS FROM THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2007 OF THE ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET AND THE BUDGET
The limits set out in last year's annual report on the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2006 no longer apply due to improvements made in 2007.
In certain areas, such as the Union's administrative expenditure, the Court gives unlimited opinions on legality and regularity.
However, the Court cannot deliver an unlimited opinion on most expenditure areas.
Although most of the payments audited by the Court have been carried out in accordance with the rules, the Court still considers that the level of error in payments to final beneficiaries, such as farmers and beneficiaries of projects financed by EU funds, is too high.
Except for cohesion policy measures whose error rate is at least 11%, the error rate estimated by the Court is between 2 and 5% in these thematic areas.
In some expenditure areas, in particular in areas previously covered by internal or external policies, the estimated error rate has decreased but would not change the overall picture in this way.
The result does not imply that these infringements result from fraud or that most transactions in these areas are illegal or illegal.
SITUATION IN CERTAIN AREAS In three areas: In the era of administrative and administrative, economic and financial expenditure and revenue, the Court's audits of a representative sample of transactions showed a low estimated error rate.
In the largest area of expenditure of the Union, hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy hy h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h h
The disproportionately high proportion of this error rate lies in rural development, including often complex schemes.
In the case of expenditure of the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF), the error rate estimated by the Court is almost below the materiality threshold of 2%.
As in previous years, cohesion policy, representing more than one third of the budget, is the area in which the biggest errors occur.
On the basis of the Court's random estimates, at least 11% of the total amount of the refund should not have been paid.

19 RULES FOR IMPROVING MONITORING AND CONTROL The high level of error in areas such as cohesion is partly due to inherent risks arising from a large number of beneficiaries applying for EU funding under complex rules and regulations.
The shortcomings in the design and functioning of the systems also contribute to the shortcomings identified.
Most EU funded programmes contain provisions on corrective actions which, on a multi-annual basis, provide for the recovery of funds unduly paid for errors.
However, there is no information on the impact of these measures.
This means that it cannot be established whether the proportion of illegal or illegal expenditure can be effectively reduced.
Since 2000, the Commission has been working on a reform programme to improve the management of the EU budget, including the 2006 Action Plan.
By the end of 2007, the Commission carried out two thirds of the sub-measures provided for in the Action Plan.
However, it is too early to assess the impact of these measures.
Improved high-level controls, for example, monitoring by the Commission of Member States' controls at Member State level do not compensate for inadequate controls at lower level, such as on-the-spot checks.
However, the benefits of increased on-the-spot checks should be considered in relation to costs.
The Court recommends that the Union's political bodies determine the appropriate level of risk of error.
In order to reduce the level of error in EU payments, the Court recommends simplifying legislation and legislation, improving internal control measures and improving monitoring and reporting.

Persecution and Effectiveness Public control plays a key role in promoting accountability and contributes to public debate.
The control activities shall be transmitted to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, in order to determine whether their taxpayers' money is spent properly and properly.
The Court's audits serve decision-makers in the institutions concerned in the European context in particular to Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States, as a direct source of information.
On the basis of this information, they may take action with or without reference to the conclusions of the checks.
Although the Court's audit activities have a significant impact on the published reports, the impact on the entire audit process is already certain.
In its replies, the audited entity often takes into account the problems identified by the Court and presents the steps it intends to take to resolve them.
Following the completion of the audit work and the publication of the report, the audit results shall be evaluated and used by Parliament and the Council to carry out their policy tasks to monitor the use of budgetary resources.
In the framework of the Court's annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form the basis for the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision.
29 Examples of this are found in the discharge procedure for the implementation of the 2007 budget, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to make efforts to simplify and further clarify the rules in order to reduce the risk of errors, to improve controls and to reduce costs.
This applies both to shared management areas and to expenditure on agriculture and cohesion policy, as well as to direct management areas, as well as expenditure on research, culture and education.
Special reports shall also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, as they are published during the year, the presentation of special reports and the discussion of them were usually held at Parliament and Council meetings at an earlier stage.
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by their involvement in the relevant media, which will increase their attention and encourage public debate.
As a general rule, the media reports for the Court's annual report are quite extensive, but the press has also followed some special reports with interest.
An example of this is the special report on cross compliance (No 8/2008), which was published at the time of the adoption of the Health Check of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
Due to the importance of cross compliance and its key role within the CAP and the moment of its publication, in various media, the report gives a broad picture: TV, newspapers, specialist newspapers, Internet publications (press, farmers' associations, MIP websites, Internet blogs, etc.).
The report has also been widely discussed in the European Parliament and almost all the recommendations of the Court have been taken into account in the draft report on discharge.
Detailed information on the follow-up to the Court's earlier observations can be found in the relevant chapters of the Court's annual report.
The most frequently reported statement of the Court in its most recent annual report is that, despite the actions taken, the shortcomings identified in the previous year have only been partially resolved.
The Court's objective is to examine the long-term effects of its work more and more and its views.
An example of this is the fact that the Court uses the Commission's database, which is the basis for assessing the impact of its audits, together with the actions to be taken with regard to the audit recommendations.
The evaluation may lead to separate detailed studies leading to further findings and recommendations.
They may be taken into account in the special report on the field concerned or in the report on the follow-up and impact of the recommendations on financial management.
The Court's position on the conclusion of the DANGEROUS RISK As a result of the development of the Community internal control framework, in its opinion No 2/2004, the Court stated that it was up to the political authorities to decide on the level of risk that they are prepared to accept when approving the Union's expenditure systems.
The Court proposed that Parliament and the Council agree on the right balance between the costs and the benefits of control, in other words, with the acceptable residual risk of error in expenditure.
The costs of controls should be proportionate to the monetary and political benefits they bring.
Since this opinion was published, both the European Parliament and the Council have expressed their willingness in their resolutions on discharge to take further action on this issue and to have a common understanding of the acceptable level of risk.
At the end of 2008, the Commission issued a communication entitled "Towards a common understanding of the concept of tolerated risk of error. "
The Court welcomed this communication and forwarded the Commission's reply indicating certain limitations and presenting the main aspects to be taken into account in the future follow-up to this case.
In its Communication, the Commission notes that any decision on the acceptable risk of error should, inter alia, be based on the potential for further simplification.
The Court also stresses the importance and benefits of further simplification and the potential impact on the reduction of errors and irregularities.
The concept of error risk which can be diversified must be clearly separated from the concept of materiality threshold, defined and applied by the Court, which falls within the competence of the external auditor10.
The Court considers that an analysis of the costs and benefits of expenditure programmes could provide information not only on the acceptable risks but also on the review of the regulatory framework and the governance structure of the programmes concerned.
In this context, an important issue may not concern whether there is an acceptable risk of error, but whether there is such a high risk of error that there is a need to abolish/regulate or substantially change a given system or programme.
In developing expenditure or revenue schemes or programmes, particular attention should also be paid to the concept of acceptable risks.
It would be useful if there were sufficient information at the time of the adoption of the expenditure programmes on the risks involved and on the costs of the planned controls in order to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.
In this way, decisions would be made in an informed manner, in a clear way, taking into account the risks and costs involved.
The budgetary reform process may be an opportunity to reflect on how the Court proposed reform, a change in Europe, in response to a Commission communication entitled "Budget"11.

The Court's strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of controls and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a significant impact on the Court's work programmes during this period and on its efforts to continue to improve.
The Court seeks to maximise the overall impact of the audits over a given period by selecting and drawing up audits which focus on the risks and which are of the greatest interest to the Court's addressees; • continue to submit and verify the conclusions of the audits and useful proposals for improvements to be implemented; • carry out a wider spectrum of audits and submit new types of control products which complement the current annual and special reports; • develop more special reports which are close to and facilitate their use; • maintain relations with the main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public; in this period the Court seeks to improve efficiency by making the best use of resources.
This includes: • better management; • effective and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of control tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • improvement of expertise; • improvement of relations with audited entities34.
The 2009 work programme includes the preparation of annual reports which show the results of the audit of the accounts which the Court must carry out in accordance with the Treaty and other EU legislation.
In 2009, the Court identified a number of audit topics concerning the development of EU financial management policies and issues.
With regard to the development of EU policies, the following topics have been selected: • growth and employment; • climate change and sustainable development; • Europe as an international partner; • better regulation.
In addition, the Court draws attention to the following issues in the area of EU financial management, which, in its view, deserve special attention: • the completion of expenditure programmes for 2000-2006, in particular in the area of the Structural Funds; • the responsibility and reform of the EU; • the progress made in implementing the Commission action plan for an integrated internal control framework, taking into account the concept of acceptable risks; • management and control activities at Member State level.
The Court's objective is to address these issues from 2009 in the framework of annual reports, special reports and some new types of reports (see below).
The Court intends to publish a number of special reports and related new reports drawn up on the basis of the audit tasks it has chosen.
The planning and implementation of the selected control tasks and the reporting of these tasks usually lasts longer than one year.
Most reports published in a given year are therefore based on the audit work launched in previous years.
Box 5 contains selected audit tasks which have been completed or to be completed and should therefore be published in special reports in 2009 or early 2010.
35 12 A more detailed and detailed review of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2009 work programme, available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
Follow-up to recommendations is an important tool for the Court to actively contribute to improving financial management.
This report will analyse the extent to which our recommendations have been followed and, where appropriate, assess the effectiveness of the actions taken.
It is expected to be published around the same time as the annual report, at the same time as the annual report, in the second new type of report, which the Court intends to present, is the report on high-risk areas related to EU financial management.
The report is addressed to the new Commission, which will start work at the end of the year, and is intended to serve as guidance to the Commission.
In 2006, the Court carried out a self-assessment which identified its strengths and weaknesses.
An action plan was then drawn up to address shortcomings.
The Action Plan included a number of actions which led to the Court to define how, its mandate, strategic objectives and strategic planning, • develop internal performance indicators to be implemented gradually (see section below); • adopt an internal communication strategy which is already being implemented and open up new channels to improve the dissemination of information within the institutions; • adopt a number of actions to improve the quality of its reports, for example through new graphic planning to improve the legibility and external evaluation; • adopt a strategy to improve the Court's relations with its addressees, the press and the wider public.
In 2009, as part of its efforts to improve, the Court will seek to take into account the observations and recommendations contained in the international report on the peer review of the European Court of Auditors, published in December 2008, which represents an important step in the Court's ongoing reform process.
The expert assessment of colleagues (peer review) was carried out by representatives of the national control bodies of Canada, Norway, Austria and Portugal.
In 2008, the co-workers carried out work and contacted the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control in this context and the final report was presented at the end of 2008.
The purpose of the peer review procedure was to assess the concept and functioning of the control framework established by the Court.
The evaluation covered the following areas: • planning and control procedures for auditing accounting checks and performance checks; • reporting on the results of the audit; • the services assisting the Court in achieving its objectives.
The peer review team concluded that the structure of the control framework established by the Court is in line with international control rules and good practice for the highest control authorities.
In addition, experts have found that • the Court carries out its activities in an independent and objective manner; • the Court's audit reports are based on appropriate and appropriate audit evidence, in accordance with international audit principles; • the parties concerned are based on high confidence in the Court's reports and generally consider them to be fair, objective and objective.
The Court welcomes the constructive comments and recommendations of stakeholders which show how it can continue to strengthen its role as the Supreme Audit Authority and highlight the challenges involved.
This includes, inter alia, the need to:• develop a culture that focuses on the Court's uniform approach as an audit body;• strengthen quality assurance and quality control activities to develop a coherent interpretation and application of its strategy and control methods;• develop risk-based control strategies to make the best use of resources to meet the different needs of the addressees.
The peer review report concluded that most of the recommendations were already foreseen in advance in the action plan drawn up before the start of the procedure.
The Court intends to incorporate the other recommendations in its audit strategy for 2009-2012 after the exchange with employees and addressees and will make every effort to implement them in that period.

INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION WITH NATIONAL EU CONTROL AUTHORITIES In accordance with the EC Treaty, the ECA must carry out checks with the highest control authorities of the Member States (ORKB) and then add to the Amsterdam Treaty: ECA and national control authorities cooperate with each other with full confidence, respecting their independence.................................................................................................................................................................................................................... and................................................................................................mm................................mm....mm....................................................................................................mm................................................................................................................................................................m..................................................m.................m.................m.................m.................................m.................m.................................................m.................................m.................................m..................................................m.................................m.................................................m.................m.................m.
In December 2008, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the EU-ORKB Contact Committee.
The meeting focused on the reform of the EU budget and on the renewed Lisbon Strategy for the period 2008-2011.
The Contact Committee shall seek to strengthen cooperation between its members in order to improve external control and accountability in the EU area.
Over the years, the role of the Contact Committee has developed in parallel with European integration.
In addition to facilitating the exchange of information between the OPCW and the OPCW, the Authority has made significant progress in the effective cooperation between the different control bodies.
At its 2007 Helsinki meeting, the Contact Committee recognised the need to address emerging or new issues in due time and agreed to establish a permanent agenda item in order to address such current issues.
In this context, the Contact Committee discussed the economic and financial crisis at its meeting in 2008 and agreed to organise workshops on the role of the EU-ORKB in the context of the crisis.
A network was subsequently set up to promote cooperation on controls related to the Lisbon Strategy and EU crisis management activities.
The Court participated in the meetings of the ORKK network of candidate and candidate countries in the field (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro).
These meetings were held at the same time as the liaison officers' meetings in May and October.
In addition, the delegation of the Court participated in the workshops organised by the Ankara network in Turkey on 8 and 9 July in order to examine/assess the internal control systems of public finances.
Throughout 2008 the Court has actively participated in the various working groups set up by the Contact Committee.

Since December 2008, the Court has taken over the (mobile) presidency of the Working Party on VAT and the network of agricultural experts has resumed its activities under the leadership of one of the members of the Court.
The Court continued to actively participate in the improvement of international control rules and procedures through membership of European and international organisations of public financial control bodies, including EUROSAI and INTOSAI.
The delegation of the Court took part in the VII Congress of EUROSAI, which took place on 2-5 June in Krakow (Poland).
Among the main topics of the discussion were the introduction of quality management systems, which will be based on evaluation, the review of social programmes in the field of education and vocational integration of people with disabilities.
The President of the Court has contributed to the role of the management of the quality management system in the audit field.
Within EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Working Party on the Environment and the Working Party on Information Technology and participates in the EUROSAI Education and Education Committee.
It also participates in the work of the Working Group set up at the 7th EUROSAI Conference in order to develop a guide on best practices in order to achieve quality within the ORB.
The Court is also a member of the EUROSAI Task Force on the control of civil protection assistance measures. 42
At the EUROSAI Congress, the European Court of Auditors, together with the highest audit authority of the Slovak Republic, was appointed auditor for the period 2009-2011.
Since joining INTOSAI in 2004, as a full member of the Court, he has been actively involved in the work of the Sub-Committee on the Financial Audit Guidelines (FAS), the Sub-Committee on the Control of Compliance with Legal Standards (CAS) and the Sub-Committee on Economic Control (PAS).
The Court has contributed to the subcommittee to promote best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Liability and Control of Civil Protection Assistance (the Civil Protection Assistance Authority of the INTOSAI Task Force on tsunami).
The first meeting of this working group was organised by the Court as host of the period from 30 June to 2 July 2008.
This meeting discussed and adopted the draft work programme for the period 2008-2010.
The main objective is to develop guidelines on accountability and control in this area, and all stakeholders should be developed in this area through the competent standardisation bodies.
In addition to the coordination function, the Court has assumed responsibility for a number of tasks, two of which, in cooperation with the Norwegian Court of Auditors.
The Presidency of this working group also requires the Court to be represented at INTOSAI Bureau meetings 43.
Among the 857 staff (officials, temporary and contract staff, but without members, seconded national experts and trainees) who served actively on 31 December 2008, 501 served as an auditor and examiner, 163 served as an interpreter and 173 served as an administrative assistant and 20 served as an assistant to the Chair.
They have a broad academic and professional background and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's findings.
As regards the human resources sector, the Court identified the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's employees as the main performance indicator (CL 9).
A study was carried out with satisfaction with the aim of providing information on the subject and supporting the decision-making process in this area.

In 2008, the Court had 97 staff: 48 officials, 18 temporary staff and 31 contract staff.
Recruitment depends on the availability of reserve lists from EPSO competitions.
Due to the deficit of the relevant candidates, the Court was unable to employ as many new workers as was planned, so at the end of 2008 the total number of job vacancies (69) was higher than at the end of 2007.
However, it should be noted that there was a significant number of recruitments at the end of the year, and the workers concerned should start working in the first quarter of 2009.
The Court is currently working to shorten the time limits for recruitment procedures.
Translation is an important administrative task that enables the Court to achieve its communication objectives and is in line with the legal obligation to publish in 22 languages.
In 2008, the number of translations increased by 17%, mainly due to the adoption of more special reports.
The vast majority of translations are made internally and during peak periods during which normal translation capacity has been exceeded, translation orders are given to the Translation Centre (CTOU) or to external translation agencies.
In addition, translators participate in examinations visits and support examiners before, during and after examinations trips, including in subsequent phases of the preparation of test reports.
Translators provide constant assistance in updating intranet content and website in English and French.
They also support INTOSAI working groups and meet other specific needs related to the Court's activities.
The Translation Directorate of the Court actively participates in the work of the Interinstitutional Translation Committee (CITI), is a member of international committees and participates in international conferences on the development of electronic translation and documentation tools.
CONTROL During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and to other beneficiary countries of EU funds to obtain appropriate evidence.
These visits normally apply to central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds, as well as to final beneficiaries.
The team of controllers usually consists of two to three controllers and the length of the examination trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
In the EU, controls are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support 47.
In 2008, the cost of the check-up trip was 3.29 million euro.
This extensive investment is essential to ensure sufficient coverage of all levels and location of EU fund management.

4 SUBMISSION OF THE PRESIDENT 4 Welcome to the 2009 annual report on the activities of the European Court of Auditors.
The purpose of this report is to provide readers with a review of the main results and progress achieved by the Court this year and to inform them of significant changes in the control and internal organisation environment.
2009 was an important year of renewal for the EU, which was the result of the election of the new European Parliament, the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and the start of the process of the election of the new European Commission.
The new Treaty reaffirms the role and mission of the Court and its status as EU institutions and introduces changes in the management and control of EU funds, strengthening the role of the European Parliament and stressing the responsibility of the Member States for the implementation of the budget.
The Court expects these changes to provide an opportunity to improve the EU's financial management.
