Improving the quality of EU spending plays an important role.
This year we have made significant progress in implementing our control strategy for 2009-2012 and in achieving our objectives We have strengthened our work effectiveness and We have made significant use of our resources this year.
An important step was our decision to present to the Council of the European Union a new regulation to be approved in order to improve our procedures for the adoption of reports and opinions.
In addition, the Court's reports increased from 42 in 2008 to 57 in 2009.
I am also pleased to say that our main product, our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, has once again met with positive acceptance among our main institutional addressees, who have agreed with many of our recommendations.
In 2009, the Court continued its active cooperation with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member States (ORKB) to develop common approaches to the control of EU funds and to consider how the CRKB can help governments deal with the financial and economic crisis.
The Court's results depend on the competence and motivation of 880 employees.
Their satisfaction is a key factor in the success of the Court and is set out in this report for the first time.
I would like to thank the Court's staff for their tirelessness and commitment to the work to enable the Court to carry out its tasks.
6 6 ORDERS, ORDERS, VALUES AND OBJECTIVES OF STRATEGIC ORDERS, ORDERS AND OBJECTIVES OF STRATEGIC ORDERS The European Court of Auditors shall be responsible, in accordance with the Treaty, for the control of the EU's finances.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management, while at the same time an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
Independence, INTEGRATION AND Independence, integrity and impartiality of an institution whose members and employees provide their addressees with adequate audit results, with all forms of interference through instructions or external pressures being rejected PROFESSIONALITY Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of their work EXCELENC AND EFFECTITY Producing adequate and timely high-quality reports based on reliable findings and evidence, taking into account the interests of its addressees and taking into account important and indicative statements which include recognition of the values of the individual, helping to develop specific skills and rewarding results Active participation in the development of public control at EU and worldwide level by promoting a team spirit through effective communication with a view to increasing efficiency in all aspects of its work, its participation in the effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and contributing to increasing accountability in the management of EU financial resources.
STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES 7 IMPLEMENTATION OF IMPLEMENTATION OF IMPLEMENTATION AND GROWTH COMPLETED control methods, adequate control strategy, further development of public sector audit practice, development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards for EU funds, cooperation with EU-ORKB, an effective Community control framework for the selection of relevant control topics, approximation of time, clarity and clarity of reports, quality of performance control, increased effectiveness of reports on strengthening relations with audit entities, with a view to better understanding of the audit process and better acceptance of audit results, with a view to the use of peer review experience to strengthen and strengthen the organisation, methods, procedures and audit results, and to achieve maximum effectiveness in strengthening contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as a budgetary and discharge authority, in order to achieve high quality and better quality of audit results; modernisation of infrastructure Effective communication with EU citizens.
8 THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK 8 THE COURT'S POSITION IS THE EU BUDGET The European Union's budget in 2010 is around EUR 123 billion, representing around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of the 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States EU funds play an important role in the financing of public actions and, compared with the GNI of several Member States, the overall budget is significant.
The revenue of the European Union consists mainly of contributions from Member States from their gross national income (GNI 76%), from customs duties and agricultural duties (so-called traditional own resources. 12%) and VAT (VAT 11%) collected by Member States.
BOX 1 FOR WHAT IS THE EU GOING TO EXPECT THE EU'S HIS WAYS?
The EU budget is financed by contributions from Member States (mainly based on national GNI), customs and agricultural duties and VAT contributions.
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than the national budget, partly due to differences in competence.

The European Commission shall draw up the budget and shall be responsible for its implementation.

10 WHEN DOES THE COURT HAVE THE ROLE?
Democratic society needs reliable, publicly available information, which will form the basis for discussion and decision-making, both in order to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
The European Court of Auditors shall act as an external EU auditor, ensuring that EU funds, regardless of where they are used, are correctly booked and spent in accordance with the relevant provisions and with due regard to the requirement to make optimal use of the funds.
The Court's audit work is used by the Commission, Parliament and Council and by the Member States to improve the EU's financial management.
In addition to the Court's activities, many national audit authorities examine EU funds, provided that they are managed and issued by public authorities in the Member States.

12 HOW DO THE COURT TAKE CARE OF THE CARRYING OF THE CARRYING OF THE CARRYING OF THE CARRYING OF THE CARRYING?
The Court carries out an audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with the international audit rules that apply both in the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international control rules do not include the Court's conformity check.
The Court actively participates in the development of international audit rules promoted by standardised organisations (INTOSAI, IFAC) 4.
In order to ensure that payments are compatible with the legal framework and other legal frameworks, the Court is based on the results of the analysis of both the supervisory and control systems to prevent and detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and on the sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Other sources, such as statements by the management of the audited bodies in the form of annual activity reports of the Directors-General of the Commission and the work of other auditors, shall also be used to support the Court's conclusions.
In the case of performance control, the Court uses a number of control methods to assess management and monitoring systems and to assess performance on the basis of regulatory criteria and taking into account the principles of sound financial management.
With regard to the selection of topics for performance control, the Court seeks to identify the areas of control for which it can be expected that it will be most likely to improve the most visible improvements in terms of savings, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending.
3 The European Development Fund (EDF) is based both on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and on certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and on Council decisions on the association of the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see external relations, development and enlargement) and partly through delegations in beneficiary countries.
4 INTOSAI (International Audit Organisation of Supreme Organisation of Audit Institutions) (IFAC) (International Accountants) (International Accountants) (International Audit Organisation of Audit Institutions) (International Audit Organisation of Audit Institutions).
BOX 2 WEEKS OF EU BUDGET PAYMENTS BY THE COURT 13 The Court does not have the resources necessary to examine in detail all operations relating to the EU budget.
Therefore, it uses statistical sampling techniques to present the results representative of the population concerned.
The Court monitors these operations up to the final beneficiary of the grant, for example the project promoter in Italy.
The Court then examined on the spot on several occasions whether the proposal was compatible with the reality.
Where the sample is representative, the results may be calculated for the population, i.e. for a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and may be used as a basis for the general assessment, together with the information resulting from the assessment of management and control systems and other sources.

14 TASKS AND TASKS5 14 STRUCTURAL STRUCTURAL AND ORGANISATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body comprising 27 members, each of which consists of one member per Member State.
Members shall elect a President from among themselves for a period of three years, with the possibility of re-election.
The five audit groups to which individual members of the Court are assigned shall prepare reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
As the organisational chart shows, there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas, as well as another audit group dealing with horizontal issues.
In addition, the Management Committee, composed of the members of the Court, shall be responsible for preparing the Court's administrative decisions.
At the end of 2009, the Court submitted to the Council a proposal to amend the Rules of Procedure in order to allow the adoption of certain categories of Court opinions and reports instead of the entire College of Chambers.
These changes will improve and improve the Court's decision-making process, including by reducing the time needed for the adoption of the decision.
Each Chamber has two areas of competence: the first field includes the adoption of special reports, special annual reports and opinions, the second - the preparation of draft comments on the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund, and draft opinions to be adopted by the College.
As in the case of the Court, decisions shall be taken by a majority of the Members of the Chamber.
Members may attend meetings of all chambers but shall have the right to vote only in the Chamber to which they have been assigned by the Court.
Of course, the entire college continues to meet to discuss and adopt the documents for which the Court is responsible, such as the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund.
The role of the Management Committee will be strengthened.
The Committee shall consist of the President of the Court holding the Presidency and the President of the Chambers.
The Committee shall prepare administrative matters requiring decisions of the Court and decisions on procedures, rules or strategic matters before they are submitted to the Court for approval.
The member shall then report to the audit group and to the Court and submit it to the European Parliament, the Council and the other interested parties following the adoption of the report.
For more details, see the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
THE COURT'S STAFF FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2009 provides for 880 posts for the European Court of Auditors (at 31 December 2009).
The task of the Court's staff working in the field of audit shall be to plan and carry out audits and to prepare draft reports in connection with them.
Auditors work in different groups: for certain specific audits, the panel shall consist of four or five auditors, while for some of the broader audits of the Court (e.g. accounting audits/compliance checks on agricultural expenditure and consistency in order to produce an annual statement of assurance) at least 20 auditors shall participate.
In general, auditors must obtain evidence of checks under various procedures: documentary checks in Luxembourg, visits to the European Commission, visits to the place and place in the Member States where revenue is generated from the EU budget and where actions financed from the EU budget are carried out.
The Court's reports and opinions must be accessible to readers throughout the Union and throughout the Union, during the audit work, the Court must maintain contacts with authorities and other bodies throughout the Union.
This would not be possible without the Court's interpreters who translate its reports and opinions (in almost all cases drawn up in English or French) into 22 official languages of the Union.
They shall also translate correspondence between the Court and other bodies, as appropriate, and, in certain cases, assist in carrying out inspection visits in the Member States.
The Court's administrative staff shall be responsible for a number of supporting tasks carried out in international organisations operating in the EU context.
This applies to finance, accounting, budget, buildings, information technology, transport, security, etc. The Secretary-General is the Court's senior staff and is responsible for the management of human resources and the management of the Court. 15

24 SPECIAL REPORTS7 The choice and development of the subject of performance and compliance checks are based on criteria such as the risk of cost-effectiveness of certain revenue and expenditure or compliance with the rules, the volume of expenditure, the date of the last check, the forthcoming changes in the regulatory or operational framework, as well as the political and public interest.
Since performance and compliance checks are complex and require a large number of detailed work, their full implementation usually takes more than a year, from the initial examination to the final report.

EMPLOYMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES • No 6/2009 EU food aid for the most deprived: Assessment of the objectives, measures and methods used • No 10/2009, information and promotion measures for agricultural products • No 11/2009, • Sustainability and management of LIFE-Nature projects by the Commission • No 14/2009, have the milk and milk market management instruments achieved their main objectives?
26 Have the management instruments for the market in milk and milk products achieved their main objectives?
The Court has reviewed the functioning of the milk and milk products market since the introduction of milk quotas in 1984 and examined the Commission's approach to managing the gradual deregulation of the dairy sector, which started in 2003.
The situation at the end of 2008 is the basis of the Court's recommendations to the Commission: to prevent new overproduction, to monitor the price-setting process in the food chain, to deepen the reflection on the future of producers in less-favoured areas, and on the impact of geographical concentration of milk production on the environment, to further target milk production to meet the needs of the European internal market and on high-value added milk products that can be exported to the world market without budget support.
CITIZENSHIP, CITIZENSHIP, SECURITY AND LAW • No 2/2009 under the EU Public Health Programme (2003-2007): An effective way to improve health? Under the EU Public Health Programme (2003-2007): An effective way to improve health?
The Court examined the European Union Public Health Action Programme 2003-2007.
The Court's audit sought to determine whether the framework conditions for projects financed by the EU budget were defined in a way that effectively complements Member States' efforts to protect and improve public health.
The report shall contain detailed conclusions and recommendations on the development, implementation and management of the programme.
In the light of its findings, the Court questions the benefits of certain elements of the European public health programmes, such as the PHP.
The Commission and the Member States are invited to reconsider the EU approach to public health funding.
EU AS A GENERAL PARTNER EU • No 1/2009 • Banking activities in the Mediterranean under the MEDA programme and previous protocols under the MEDA programme • No 4/2009 in the framework of the Commission's management of non-state actors' participation in development cooperation between the Community • No 12/2009 in the framework of the effective management of Commission projects in the field of justice and home affairs for the Western Balkans • No 15/2009 in the framework of EU assistance through the United Nations organisation for decision-making and control under the Development Assistance Programme for Turkey in the framework of the management of pre-accession assistance for Turkey by the European Commission under the European Commission's programme • No 12/2009 in the framework of the EDF programme for regional economic integration in East Africa and West Africa in West Africa in 27 The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance for Turkey has examined the management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission.
In particular, the first period of implementation of pre-accession assistance (2002-2006) was characterised by many shortcomings, which have already emerged in previous pre-accession programmes.
The objectives set by the Commission for grants were not specific enough to allow for an impact assessment of the project and the Commission did not have the information necessary to demonstrate the effectiveness of pre-accession assistance.
Nevertheless, the projects audited have produced the planned results and the results of the projects are likely to be sustainable.
The Commission has already made some significant improvements, but the Court makes recommendations on further corrective actions.
Among the areas where improvement is most needed is the definition of strategic grant targets, the definition of more realistic deadlines for achieving the objectives and the monitoring of the real results of projects and the results of projects based on clear objectives and relevant indicators.

Special reports shall also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
As they are published during the year, the presentation of special reports and the debate on the subject were usually held at Parliament and Council meetings at an earlier stage.
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by their involvement in the relevant media, paying more attention and encouraging public debate.
Overall, the media report on the Court's annual report is quite extensive.
This was also the case in 2009, with the media focusing primarily on improving agricultural spending.
The press also followed several special reports with interest.
For example, the special report on the milk market (No 14/2009) which assessed the extent to which the management instruments for the milk and milk products market had achieved their main objectives was the subject of intensive discussions in the Council and in Parliament, and at a time when the sector was confronted with various problems, in the media and in the professional groups concerned, a broad echo in the media.
The Court is working on a further analysis of the impact of its activities.
In 2009, he started working on the process of systematic monitoring of his special reports to identify and document the progress made in addressing the shortcomings identified and in implementing the recommendations made.
This procedure will provide the Court, as will Parliament and other interested parties, with additional feedback on the effects of its activities.
31 OPINION OF THE COURT OF OPINION No 1/2010 OF THE POWER TO THE FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION: RISKS AND CHALLENGES In February 2010, the Court gave its opinion for the first time on measures to reduce the level of irregular payments at the level of the EU budget and to improve the quality of expenditure (savings, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court found that in order to increase recent progress in reducing the level of irregular payments, rules in high risk areas should be simplified and control systems should be put in place more cost-effectively.
Such reforms should be carried out in the context of the ongoing broader review of the EU spending system.
The Court considers that improving the quality of expenditure is of great importance, which can be achieved by applying the concept of European added value in the definition of expenditure priorities and by addressing the problems identified by the Court in the selection, design and implementation of expenditure programmes and grant programmes.

Most irregularities are based on reporting on ineligible expenditure by beneficiaries, reporting on excessive eligible expenditure and non-compliance with payment conditions, for example on public procurement rules.
These are mainly due to the complexity of payment systems and conditions and to shortcomings in risk control systems at the level of final beneficiaries.
The Commission should address the specific systemic shortcomings identified by the Court in high risk areas and improve its supervision.
However, with an increasing number of controls and, as a result, a decreasing error rate, a point was reached at a certain point where the cost of controls was no longer proportionate to the benefits obtained.
Simplification should therefore remain a priority.
The rules and regulations to be interpreted clearly and easily may not only reduce the risk of error but also reduce the costs of controls 31.
32 IMPROVING THE CONCEPT OF EXPENDITURE PROGRAMMES In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure clear objectives for the review of existing and for the development of new actions.
It is often necessary to increase the sense of reality and to increase transparency and accountability.
To this end, the Commission could further strengthen the existing procedures for the development of future strategies, in particular ex ante evaluation and impact assessments.
Given the European added value in defining expenditure priorities, the Court proposes clarifying the concept of European added value in the relevant political declaration or EU legislation in order to give guidance to EU political bodies in defining expenditure priorities.
The Court considers that the Commission should complete the budget review as soon as possible and take account of its results when drawing up the financial framework starting in 2014.
Improving the quality of expenditure should be of great importance to the institutions of the European Union and thus be the main objective of the new Commission.
33 THE COURT'S WORK PLAN FOR 201010 The Court presents its future audit work in the work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and available to the public on the Court's website.
The work programme shall provide stakeholders with information on new and ongoing audits and on the planned reports.
The Court has developed a control strategy for 2009-2012, which is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of controls and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will be essential for the Court's 2010 work programme and for its efforts to continue to improve.
The Court seeks to maximise the overall impact of the checks over a given period by selecting and drawing up checks which focus on the risks and which are of the greatest interest to the Court's addressees; • it continues to present conclusions from the checks and useful conclusions on the improvement of whether these proposals are implemented; • it carries out a broader scope of checks and presents new types of control products that complement the current annual and special reports; • it develops more special reports that are close to time and more user-friendly; • it maintains relations with the main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public; the Court seeks to improve efficiency by making the best use of resources during that period.
• Better management; • effective and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of control tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • improvement of expertise; • improvement of relations with research bodies.

CLI aims to increase internal and external responsibility and to increase productivity and quality of work. INTERMEDIARY IndicatorS • To inform management of how effectively the Court carries out its activities as an authority; • to support the decision-making process by focusing the institutions' attention on performance issues and by supporting improvements; • to inform the group of addressees of the relevant issues related to the Court's performance.
The main concerns of the CLI are the achievement of the Court's strategic objectives, as they concern the quality of the Court's audits, results, impact and management of the Court's resources.
They form an integral part of the Court's management system.

The Court has contributed to the annual meetings of these organisations and to the improvement of international control rules and procedures and has actively participated in the committees and working groups set up by these organisations.

40 STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES The Court's most important capital is its staff.
At 31 December 2009, the Court's staff was 880 staff (officials and temporary staff but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the 525 staff (including 115 staff in the members' office) the audit tasks were dealt with; 163 as translators; 171 as administrative assistants; and 21 as assistants to the president.
The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional context and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's results.
ENLARGEMENT OF THE COURT'S PLANS TO 31 DECEMBER (busy and vacant) Translation Administrative support The Court has committed itself to achieving its strategic objective of improving its efficiency by making the best use of its resources.
In 2009, he continued to analyse and exploit the potential for productivity growth in all his activities, simplifying procedures and improving services.
In particular, the resources of the support services, which have been made available through efficiency gains, have been removed as far as possible from these services and made available for audit tasks.
This process is not yet completed and its effects will be even more visible in 2010.
As regards staff, the Court identified as the main performance indicator (ZLI 9) the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's staff (see page 37).
To this end, a satisfaction study was carried out to provide information on this subject and to support the decision-making process in this area.
The Court is currently implementing measures to ensure that the opportunities to achieve better results in the coming years are fully exploited.

TERMINATION The Court's employment policy complies with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the Court's staff are composed of both officials and contract staff.
The general procedures for the selection of posts at the Court are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
In addition, the Court provides a limited number of traineeships for university graduates for a period of between three and five months.
In 2009, the Court had 112 employees: 69 officials, 14 temporary staff and 29 contract staff.
Recruitment depends on whether the reserve lists are available and whether they are sufficient.
In 2009, the Court managed to employ an adequate number of new workers.
73 jobs that were not filled on 31 December 2009 were reduced by 33% to 49 by 26 January 2010 and the number of job vacancies in the coming months will continue to be significantly lower as the recent wave of recruitment will bring other workers to work.
At 31 December 2008, 68 posts were not planted.
The list of recruitment reserves based on the EPSO selection procedure AD/126/08 was published in August and the first candidates who took part in the competition were called in early November, which was only three months later.
BORROWING EDUCATION The profession of examiner requires continuous training.
Moreover, due to the specific nature of the Court's audit environment, auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2009, the Court's staff completed an average of nine days of vocational training.
Language courses accounted for 64% of the total number of training days in 2009 (compared with 48% in 2008).
In 2009, without taking into account language courses, the auditors completed four days of vocational training (see ZLI 10 on page 38).
This figure is expected to increase in 2010 as new staff will have to undergo a compulsory training programme.

BOX 5 WEEKS WEEKS OF KNOWLEDGE IN BALKEN IN WESTERN BALKEN The Western Balkans were characterised by violence in the past.
The European Union's interest in this region is to promote security and long-term stability.
The rule of law, border security and the fight against corruption are a fundamental condition for EU accession and are a huge challenge in the Western Balkans.
The European Commission is the main donor of funding in the region.
The Court's 2009 report on the effectiveness of the Commission's projects in the area of justice and home affairs for the Western Balkans (Special Report No 12/2009) has shown the situation in this particularly important area.
The audit concerned both investment projects and institutional development projects in four areas: asylum, integrated border management, judiciary and police.
33 Completed projects have been evaluated on the spot, including the asylum centre, the prison in Albania and the court responsible for human rights and war crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Several border crossing points have also been visited in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia, funded by EU funds, in order to assess whether EU action has led to improvements in the situation.
The study team worked closely with the rapporteur member, Maarten B. Engwirt.
The head of the control department was Raija Peltonen and Ossi Louko, and the head of the team was Jussi Bright.
Enrico Grassi and Miroslav Matej were involved, and Horst Fischer and Jan Pieter Lingen from Maarten B. Engwird also played an important role.

Translation Translation is an important action to support the audit, which enables the Court to carry out its mission and to achieve its communication objectives.
In 2009, total translation volumes increased by 5.2% compared to 2008.
The share of translation services provided within the prescribed time limit exceeded 95%.
Language support for auditors for inspection visits and for reporting has been strengthened.
The Translation Directorate also supported the INTOSAI Working Groups and related to other specific needs related to the Court's audit activities.
In January 2010, a new IT application (artemis) was introduced to improve the efficiency of translation management.
INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology provides controllers with basic tools and services.
The main changes in 2009 were the following: • simplifying the processes and continuing the transition to a paper office through the use of automated electronic permits and forms, the introduction of electronic signatures and the start of work on the creation of a database of archives; • enhancing the security of the Court's IT infrastructure by setting up a data recovery centre and archiving the advanced version of the lotos-notes platform, the database and the Court's control and archiving systems; • adopting a long-term IT plan for the period 2010-2012 in order to adapt IT technologies to the main strategic objectives of the Court's audit and continuing efforts to provide high-quality services. 45

CONTROL During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and to other countries benefiting from EU funds to obtain appropriate evidence.
Visits are usually carried out by central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds, as well as by final beneficiaries.
The team of controllers shall normally consist of two or three controllers and the duration of the examination trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
In the EU, controls are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support.

50 SERVICE REVISION The internal audit agency of the Court aims to support the Court in the achievement of its objectives through a systematic and methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
Furthermore, the Internal Audit Department presents proposals to improve the effectiveness of the Court.
This requires a continuous assessment of the internal control systems within the Court in order to assess their effectiveness.
In 2009, the Court's internal audit services focused mainly on accounting checks (accounting checks), ex ante controls, checks on the payroll and trust accounts, monitoring contracts and procedures for the award of public contracts and analysis of the transport process.
Most audit recommendations issued by the internal auditor in 2009 were adopted by the evaluation bodies and incorporated in the corrective action plans.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee shall supervise the internal auditor's activities and ensure his independence.
In addition, it shall examine and approve the work programme and internal auditor's reports and, if necessary, entrust them with specific audit tasks.
In 2009, the department.. Internal review... was tested and certified by the independent auditor Deloitte S.A.
THE COURT'S EXTERMINATION The independent auditor's report on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2008 was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 23 October 2009.
In its audit opinion, the Court's independent auditor (PricewaterhouseCoopers SRL) presented the following conclusions: As regards the financial statements: In our view, the annual accounts provide a true and fair view of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2008 and the financial situation and cash flows at the end of that period, in accordance with Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 of 25 June 2002 and Commission Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 2342/2002 of 23 December 2002 laying down detailed rules for the implementation of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 2342/2002 of 23 December 2002 laying down detailed rules for the application of the Council Regulation and the accounting rules of the European Court of Auditors. As regards the use of resources and control procedures, we did not refer to situations where, in all relevant respects and taking into account the above-mentioned evaluation criteria: (a) the funds allocated to the Court for the purposes and (b) did not ensure that the financial operations were carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations.
52 DECLARATION OF POWERS OF POWERS The undersigned Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors hereby declares that, as authorising officer by delegation, • that the information submitted to the Court for drawing up this report is correct and accurate13, and • is sufficient to confirm that the appropriations submitted for the actions described in this report have been used for the purposes and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management and that the control procedures implemented give the necessary guarantees of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions14.
Such reasonable assurance shall be based on the assessment of the signed and the information available to it, such as the results of the ex post checks, the internal auditor's reports and the reports of the independent auditor of the previous financial years.
The undersigned confirms that he is not aware of any unsigned circumstances that could harm the interests of the institution.

European Court of Auditors Annual Activity Report 2010
The European Court of Auditors has adopted the following principles: the European Court of Auditors shall be responsible for the control of the EU's finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving the EU's financial management while, at the same time, it is an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency.
The independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, which is characterised by fairness and impartiality, which is considered professional, as well as the quality and impact of its work, and which provides its addressees with valuable support for improving the EU's financial management.
INDEPENDENCE, INTEGRATION AND INDEPENDENCE PROFESSIONALITY MORE MAJORITY MAJORITY OF INDEPENDENCE AND EFFIVITY Independence, fairness and impartiality of institutions whose members and employees draw up adequate and timely quality reports, based on sound arrangements and evidence, taking into account the needs of the recipients, and containing important and directional statements containing the recognition of the values of the individual, helping to develop specific skills and rewarded results in support of the team spirit through effective communication, providing the addressee with adequate audit results, with all forms of interference with the management of EU funds being rejected from the outside, while maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of its work, actively contributing to the development of public control at EU and worldwide level, and increasing efficiency in all aspects of its work, by contributing to effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and contributing to increasing the management of EU financial resources.

4 PRESENTATION OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to the reading of the fourth annual report of the European Court of Auditors. This year we have used the opportunity to re-distribute the content into two main sections of the activity::.................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................... In 2010, the Court of Auditors had two important opportunities to participate in the debate on the reform of EU financial management.
At the beginning of the year, the Court presented an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges of improving EU financial management and, at the end of the year, an opinion on the Commission's proposals to amend the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the EU.
In the perspective of 2011, the Court will continue to implement its values and continue to develop the results and results achieved.
We will once again present high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions that will contribute to improving EU financial management and contribute to greater accountability and transparency and, in particular, will continue to closely monitor the development of the EU's economic governance and will deal with new legislative proposals that will have an impact on the EU's financial management after 2013.
We are planning to publish 45 annual reports, i.e. annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and the European Development Funds, as well as specific annual reports on agencies, institutions and other bodies.
Special reports provide an important opportunity to provide added value, as they focus on areas where there is an increased risk, and on areas of particular importance to the addressees, in particular as regards the quality of EU spending in different areas, ranging from the financial instruments and the SME guarantee instrument, to projects funded by the EU in the field of electronic administration and the single payment scheme in agriculture.
While implementing the 2009-2012 strategy, the Court hopes that it will be able to make full use of the benefits of recent reforms, including improved decision-making procedures, and that the Court will continue its efforts to recruit appropriate staff, to minimise the number of jobs and to promote the professional development of its staff.
Without the involvement and professionalism of all the Court's staff in 2010, we would not have achieved what we have achieved.

9 OUR CONTROL REPORTS AND NOTES The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: o o Annual reports: o Annual reports on the audit of financial statements and on the control of compliance with the rules for each financial year (including special annual reports published separately for the agencies, institutions and other bodies of the European Union); o special reports are reports that can be published at any time during the year, together with the results of selected audits, mainly the control of economic efficiency with a view to assessing savings, economic efficiency and effectiveness in selected areas of EU revenue and expenditure; o opinions on draft legislative acts with financial implications.

The Court published its annual report on the European Development Funds for 2009 on the European Development Fund (EDF) for 2009 on 9 November 2010 together with its annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for 2009.
In December 2010, the Court published 40 special annual reports on EU agencies, institutions and other bodies for the financial year 20092.
The Court found that the supervisory and control systems are partially effective in ensuring the regularity of payments and that in the report the Court recommends improving certain aspects of EDF financial management, including the cost-effectiveness of control of expenditure, the control of annual audits of completed projects and the control of the use and monitoring of budget support.
12 Special reports adopted in 2010 The Court always seeks to achieve the maximum impact and to make the best possible use of the resources allocated to these tasks when selecting and shaping its tasks in the field of performance control and compliance.
The Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the field of income or expenditure; • the level of income or expenditure; • the time elapsed since possible control; • changes in the legal or operational framework; • the political and public interest.
In order to obtain the necessary control evidence, it is necessary to carefully plan and carry out the selected performance and compliance checks and, before the report is published, the Court gives the audited authorities the opportunity to comment on its findings and its replies.
As a result, these checks usually last longer than one year.

18 Protection and management of natural resources Due to a budget of EUR 413 billion for 2007-2013, the EU has a wide range of powers and political responsibility for agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment; three quarters of the resources are allocated to agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers; these payments are financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF), the most pillar of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of expenditure comes from support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second pillar of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development shall be managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Implementation of the Leader approach in rural development (Special Report No 5/2010) Leader is a bottom-up approach based on local rural development partnerships. • The evaluation assessed whether the Leader approach was implemented in such a way as to bring additional benefits compared to the traditional top-down approach, while minimising the risk of sound financial management. • Has the reform of the sugar market achieved its main objectives?
(Special Report No 6/2010) of the 2006 EU has carried out a thorough reform of the sugar sector in order to ensure the competitiveness of the EU sugar industry, stabilise markets and supply and ensure an adequate standard of living for the rural population.

The Court has actively participated in the meetings of the CMR network of candidate countries and potential candidate countries (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Montenegro, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia) 4 in parallel with the meetings of the Contact Committee.
The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international audit rules and procedures through membership of European and international organisations of public financial control bodies, in particular INTOSAI5 and their European regional group EUROSAI.
The delegation of the Court took part in the 20th INCOSAI Congress in South Africa on 22-27 November 2010.
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of INTOSAI, it has actively participated in the sub-committees on various types of audit, and the Court has also contributed to the subcommittee on the promotion of best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews in order to promote more intensive efforts to improve the competences of INTOSAI members.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on the control and control of civil protection assistance.
An important objective of these working groups is to develop guidelines on responsibility for civil protection assistance and to identify and disseminate best practices, focusing on actions aimed at stakeholders ( multilateral bodies, relief organisations, governments, private controllers), and the working group's interim report was presented to the INTOSAI Congress in November 2010.
In 2010, the Court also participated in INTOSAI-Taskforce in the Global Financial Crisis. In the framework of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Working Group on the Environment and the Working Party on Information Technology and participates in the EUROSAI Education Committee.
The Court also participated in the work of the working group set up at the 7th EUROSAI Conference in 2008 in order to draw up a guide on best practices in order to achieve quality.

Following the Council's approval of the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure on 1 June 2010, chambers of the Court's members were set up to adopt special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft legislative acts, and earlier all of these reports and opinions were adopted by all the Colleges and continue to take place in the case of annual reports on the EU budget and the EDF.
Although most of the Court's reports are now approved by the chambers, the chambers are given the opportunity to refer their documents to the Court for adoption.
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they do not belong without the right to vote.

The Court has gradually developed a set of key performance indicators (CL) in order to inform the management of the progress of the 2009-2012 objectives; to support the decision-making process; to provide information on the results among the Court's addressees.
Since a review of all indicators is available for the first time in 2010, this year is the reference year for future progress assessments. The Court is very pleased with the results achieved in 2010 with regard to key performance indicators, in particular with regard to the quality and impact of its work.
More importantly, indicators clearly identify areas where progress is needed and the problems that need to be addressed in order to achieve future productivity growth.
29 The quality and impact of the Court's work shall be assessed by the Court on the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of the assessments carried out by the addressees and by experts and by monitoring its recommendations.
Evaluation of addressees The Court asked the main addressees of its reports (the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgets of the Council) and the main bodies audited (mainly European Commission staff) to assess the quality and impact of the annual reports published in 2009 (in relation to the general budget and the EDF) and the special reports.
The evaluation should be based on a five-stage scale (1 in a very bad, 2 in a bad, 3 in a suitable, 4 in a good, 5 in a very good).
2010 A deliberate assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's reports by the main addressee 4.2 ≥4 The assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the audited entity The result is that the main addressees of the Court's reports consider them to be good and good on average.
The Court seeks to maintain or improve this level.
Reviews carried out by experts The two external bodies reviewed the content and presentation of the sample of the Court's reports published in 2009 and 2010. The reviews assessed the eight special reports and the annual reports on the general budget and the EDF for both years and assessed the quality of the different aspects of the reports on a four-stage 30 Follow-up of the recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations to improve financial management; in order to amend the Court's recommendation, the evaluation bodies must first adopt and subsequently implement the evaluation bodies, and this indicator is based on recommendations published in 2009, i.e. the latest available, annual and special reports.
In 2010, the objective of 90% ≥ 90% of the audit recommendations adopted by the audited body the Court seeks to maintain or even improve this high level of acceptance of the recommendations.
In 2010, the Court established a system for monitoring the implementation of recommendations by the evaluation bodies.
In the coming years, the system will form the basis for a further indicator of the scope of practical implementation of the recommendations and will form the basis for improvement.
Moreover, the Court will provide valuable information to improve the quality of its recommendations and thus to improve their acceptance among the bodies that have been audited.
31 The effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources The Court assesses the effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources, depending on the extent to which it is able to report and audit reports in good time, to fulfil its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff.
For the purposes of the publication of the annual reports and the detailed annual reports, the time limits laid down in the law should be respected.
In the case of special reports for which there is no publication date specified in the provisions, the date of their adoption shall be deemed to be the date of their adoption.

Members shall be assisted by their cabinet representatives and a team of auditors appointed for their examination tasks.

European Court of Auditors Annual Activity Report 2011
THE EUROPEAN COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF Auditors shall be responsible for the control of the EU's finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving the EU's financial management and, at the same time, it is an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
The independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, which is characterised by fairness and impartiality, which is recognised as professionalism, quality and impact of its work, and its addressees provide valuable support for improving the EU's financial management.
Independence, INTEGRATION AND Independence PROFESSIONALITY MORE EXTERNAL VALUE AND EFFIence Independence, honesty and impartiality of institutions, their members and employees.
Unbiased examination, taking into account the views of the stakeholders, but rejecting any form of external influence by means of instructions or pressures.
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
contribute to the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
preparing adequate and timely high quality reports based on reliable findings and evidence, taking into account the needs of the recipients, taking into account relevant and relevant comments and guidance.
contribute to the effective improvement of EU governance and contribute to increasing responsibility for the management of EU funds.
Promoting team spirit through effective communication.
increase efficiency in all aspects of his work.

4 PRESENTATION OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to the reading of the annual report on the European Court of Auditors' activities for 2011.
The economic and financial crisis led to significant changes in the EU's economic governance, which have a significant impact on the future use of public funds.
In this context, the Court published a position paper in May on the impact of the measures taken in response to the financial and economic crisis on accountability, transparency and financial control.
Later that year, the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Authorities (ORCB) of the EU Member States and the European Court of Auditors called on EU decision-makers to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and financial control of the EU Member States and the European Court of Auditors are properly respected, as far as the use of public funds is concerned.
In particular, the euro area ORKB called for the introduction of the relevant provisions for the public external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
This led to a decision to set up an audit committee for the Stability Mechanism, to which a member proposed by the Court will join.
Also in 2011, the results of our key performance indicators are encouraging, in particular with regard to the monitoring of recommendations made by our units, as well as to the evaluation of our control activities by the addressees and external experts.
We have managed to increase our performance with regard to the number of audit reports and opinions adopted in 2011, but we have failed to achieve ambitious targets in terms of timely reporting.
Our annual reports now included even more detailed information and a new chapter on results, as well as 42 annual reports and 16 special reports, together with seven opinions and a position paper.
The scope of the audit powers of the institutions in respect of Union revenue and expenditure, in particular in respect of VAT-based own resources in the Member States, was confirmed by the European Court of Justice in November 2011.
Since 2012, we will be able to inform you of the extent to which our recommendations will be implemented in practice.
In addition, our methods of performance control will be peer reviewed in order to further improve the preparation of special reports.
In 2011, we published ethical guidelines to further strengthen the Court's audit management framework and to improve the audit strategies and guidelines of the Court's audit to improve the audit and reporting process.
In addition, we will launch a new hearing on employee satisfaction in 2012.
In the future, in 2012 we will complete the preparation of our strategy for 2013-2017.
Some of the most important challenges are already apparent: the EU regulatory framework will continue to develop and we must continue to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control are properly respected.
The need to ensure a high quality and timely guarantee of the use of EU funds is growing and we need to improve our audits and reports accordingly.
As the EU is constantly changing, we, too, will try to make the best of our audit experience to help policy makers improve financial management.
Strengthening EU financial responsibility is an objective that we have in common with other actors and we will seek to combine our efforts through strategic partnerships.
Finally, like other EU institutions and bodies, we must be able to achieve less in order to make our organisation more effective.
These challenges will depend to a large extent on the efforts of all the Court's staff.
The development of excellence of our employees in our institutions is important for us.
With regard to professionalism, commitment and past performance of our employees, I am convinced that the Court will be able to achieve these future objectives.
Vítor Manuel da Silva CALDEIRA President 5

As a result, the 2010 Annual Report, including the 17th Statement of Assurance (DAS), was published on 10 November 2011.
The annual report 2010 contained some changes to improve clarity and clarity of information.
These include the recasting of thematic groups (and the corresponding annual chapters), of which the Court groups expenditure, the publication of estimated error rates per policy area (see below), the focus on recommendations on improving financial management and the new chapter on results.
The Court first published estimates of errors for both the EU budget as a whole and for the various thematic groups.
The error rate shall be determined by extrapolating the quantifiable errors found in the audited transaction trials.
The Court compares the estimated error rate with the materiality level of 2% to determine whether the error is material, taking into account further evidence that the error is material.
The error rate is not an indicator of fraud, but reflects the Court's estimates of non-compliance with the rules on expenditure.
This includes breaches of public procurement rules, ineligible or miscalculated costs for projects co-financed by the EU, or cases where farmers provide too much information on areas.
The 2010 Annual Report provides the following main information: the 2010 Annual Financial Report presents the financial situation of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for 2010.
On the other hand, the payments underlying this financial report are largely affected by errors; the estimated error rate in the EU budget as a whole is 3.7%.
The control systems were partly effective in ensuring the regularity of payments in general. The error rate estimated by the Court in the area of cohesion, energy and transport policy (the most defective area of expenditure in the EU) was 7.7% higher than in 2009 and the error rate remained relatively stable in the remaining areas of expenditure in the EU.
In the policy group Agriculture and natural resources, the estimated error rate was 2.3%, i.e. above the materiality threshold.
However, direct payments to farmers did not show any significant errors. o Share of pre-financing did not. not in the EU budget significantly increased.
Accounting rules and supervisory rules have not been properly adapted. o When planning EU spending programmes, the Commission and the Member States should pay more attention to setting SMART targets, i.e. specific, measurable, achievable, proportionate and timely targets, as well as to identifying and reducing risks that may arise in the course of implementation.
ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND 2010 In its annual report on the European Development Fund (EDF) for the financial year 2010 (published on 10 November 2011), the Court concluded that the financial statements of the EDF for 2010 constitute, in all material respects, the appropriate financial situation of the EDF and the results of its operations and cash flows, in accordance with the Financial Regulation.
EDF revenue is not affected by serious errors.
The EDF's commitments were legal and correct, regardless of the non-quantifiable errors found in the field of public procurement.
However, EDF payments for projects were largely affected by errors, with an estimated error rate of 3.4%.
The error detected concerned non-compliance with eligibility conditions.
The Court has assessed that the control systems established under the EFF ensure, to a limited extent, the regularity of payments in general.
In December 2011, the Court published special annual reports on the 2010 financial year for all 42 agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. joint undertakings) and other EU bodies (in particular the efficiency of the management of the European Central Bank).
The Court delivered an unqualified opinion for all units audited, with the exception of the European GNSS Agency, as some of the assets were not included in the accounts and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking, as the report on the results was not included in the accounts.
Agencies and decentralised EU bodies were set up by the EU legislator to carry out specific tasks.
Each agency has a mandate, a board, a director, staff and a budget.
Agencies operate in many areas such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and travel.

12 SPECIAL REPORTS ADOPTED IN 2011 In addition to the annual reports, the Court shall publish, during the year, specific reports containing the results of the performance and compliance checks in the budgetary areas or management areas selected by the Court.
In selecting and selecting audit tasks, the Court seeks to achieve the maximum impact and make the best use of its resources.
In selecting the subjects, the Court takes into account the following factors: the risk to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the area of income or expenditure; the level of income or expenditure; the time since the possible prior assessment; the future changes in the legal framework; the political and public interest.
In 2011, the Court adopted 16 special reports on a number of issues, which means an increase compared to the 14 special reports adopted in 2010.
Special reports will be presented in summarised form below, in the corresponding headings in the financial framework of the EU multiannual budget in j. SUSTAINABLE GROWTH 13 Sustainable growth is geared towards growth and employment and covers two issues: competitiveness includes support for research and technological development, creation of European networks, vocational education and training, promotion of competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, social agenda and decommissioning of nuclear facilities.
EU expenditure on growth and jobs for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 89.4 billion, i.e. 9.2% of the total budget, of which almost two thirds are R &amp; D. Cohesion for growth and jobs mainly concerns cohesion policy in the form of funds for specific areas of activity, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund.
The Commission and the Member States shall use the resources under shared management.
The EU budget for cohesion for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 344.4 billion (35.7% of the total EU budget).
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: on the effectiveness of the SME Guarantee Facility (Special Report No 4/2011) in relation to their design and planning and management of related operations and their implementation.

17 SUPERVISION FOR THE REVIEW OF 5/2011 THE OPERATIONAL PAYMENT PROGRAMME: SUPERVISION FOR BETTER FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT This cost-effectiveness review concerned sound financial management of payments under the single payment scheme, which is currently applied in 17 of the 27 EU Member States.
The expenditure related to this programme amounted to around €28,8 billion in 2009.
The introduction of the single payment scheme was a key element of the reform of the EU's common agricultural policy in 2003.
The aim of this programme was to encourage farmers to respond better to market demand and to provide income support to farmers.
The reform broke the link between support and production (it was claimed that production was separated from Vietnam production from Vietnam production).
Instead, farmers must have eligible agricultural land and payment entitlements of this kind.
Since 2006, the Court has carried out a number of checks on the procedures laid down by the Commission and the Member States to ensure the accuracy of payment entitlements and the accuracy of payments to farmers.
These checks covered all 17 Member States applying the scheme, the results of which were taken into account in the annual reports for 2006 and 2007 on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court decided to carry out, on the basis of these results, a performance check, which focused on the following aspects: beneficiaries of the scheme, access to payments on the holding and the definition of eligible areas; the contribution of the scheme to the objectives of income support to farmers and the maintenance of agricultural land in good agricultural and environmental condition; the particular impact of the application of the different models of implementation of the scheme.
Verification visits were carried out in 2009 and 2010 at the Commission, France, Italy and the United Kingdom.
Special Report No 5/2011 states that the single payment scheme has contributed to the two main objectives of the common agricultural policy: farmers were encouraged to respond better to market demand and the incomes of the agricultural sector as a whole were taken into account.
However, in general, the implementation of the scheme has revealed a number of questionable features concerning the definition of beneficiaries of the policy, the nature of eligible parcels and activities, the environmental impact of the scheme, the distribution of aid between Member States and within Member States and the specific impact of the historical and regional model.
18 The Court recommends in the report that the payment of farm payments should be better granted to active farmers and that payments be excluded from the aid of parcels and non-agricultural activities which do not contribute to the efficiency of agricultural holdings or to the maintenance of the ecological value of land.
Furthermore, the Court recommends that the level of the single payment should take account of environmental costs and other externalities, and that the level of the aid be more balanced between farmers.
The calculation of operational payments should be based on current management conditions.
The audit was carried out by a multidisciplinary team consisting of eight controllers from Chamber I. The audit work provided further information not only on the concept of non-production-related payments but also on the impact of the conversion process from the previous production-related support system on the current system.
According to Sven Kolling's team leader, the examination of the various models and options existing under the single payment scheme to implement the scheme together with national and regional administrative strategies and their impact on the cost-effectiveness and effectiveness of the premium is a particular challenge.
Verification visits to final beneficiaries and on-the-spot checks on holdings have proved necessary to obtain evidence to support findings and conclusions.
Many of the Court's recommendations are reflected in the Commission's proposals for the reform of the common agricultural policy after 2013 (at the time of the preparation of this report in the debate), including the definition of an active farmer and non-agricultural activity in certain areas, in the breakdown of the premium payments per beneficiary, in the reduction of the number of models for the implementation of the single payment scheme and in the better consideration of environmental externalities in the calculation of the single payment.

22 THE COURT'S INFLUENCES: THE ASSESSMENT OF THE COURT'S COURT'S FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC CRISIS FOR THE PUBLIC ACCOUNTING AND PUBLIC FINANCIAL CONTROL IN THE EU AND THE COURT'S ACCOUNTING ACCOUNTING AND CRISIS: THE EU'S ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTING FOR THE EU'S ECONOMIC INFUSIONS AND THE EU'S ACCOUNTING OF THE FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC CRISIS'S ACCOUNTING OF THE FINANCIAL AND CRISIS IN THE EU'S ACCOUNTING OF THE EU'S ECONOMIC INFLUENCES AND ACCOUNTING OF THE FINANCIAL NATIONAL AND THE EU'S ECONOMIC CRISIS had serious consequences for the European Union.
In order to deal with the crisis, the EU has taken action to ensure the long-term sustainability of the financial sector, to promote economic recovery and growth, to provide financial assistance to the Member States and to strengthen financial and economic coordination between Member States.
In addition, these measures have a decisive impact on the use of public funds, i.e. taxpayers' money of EU citizens, in the Union.
The changes in the regulatory structure of the Union pose new challenges in terms of accountability, transparency and public financial control.
The Court considers that the implementation of these new measures is in line with the principle that, whenever the use of public funds is concerned, appropriate rules of transparency, public responsibility and public financial control should be laid down.
Therefore, on 19 May 2011, the Court adopted a document on the impact of the current financial and economic crisis on public responsibility and public control in the EU and on the role of the Court.
In that document, the Court stated that, as far as possible, it would include new supervisory authorities, support mechanisms with EU budgetary guarantees and, where possible, within the European Semester in its audits of the Commission's activities within the European Semester.
The Court considers that the agreement establishing the European Stability Mechanism should provide for the form of external public control.
Finally, the Court concludes that, in many cases, the issues of accountability and transparency must be examined by the relevant EU institutions, in particular by the European Parliament and the Council.

28 The different actions of the European Court of Auditors in the Court of Auditors in relation to the examination of own resources VAT On 15 November 2011, the Court of Justice delivered a judgment in Case C-539/09 Commission v Federal Republic of Germany on the control powers of the European Court of Auditors in respect of VAT own resources.
This is due to the refusal by the German Ministry of Finance to authorise the European Court of Auditors in 2006 to carry out checks on administrative cooperation in the field of VAT in Germany in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003.
In preparation of Special Report No 8/2007, the Court decided to carry out audits in eight Member States, including Germany.
Germany contested the Court's right to carry out that review.
The German Government has stated that the cooperation referred to in Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 between the administrative authorities of the Member States has no direct link with the EU's revenue, since value added tax must be distinguished from national VAT and therefore VAT.
The latter are determined on the basis of a number of calculations and represent a relatively small proportion of the amounts charged by the Member States as VAT.
The Court strongly rejected the argument of the German Government, which is based on the strict contrast between the VAT revenue of the Member States and the Union's own resources on value added tax.
In the light of the arguments put forward by the Commission, the European Parliament and the European Court of Auditors, the Court of Auditors stressed the dependence of VAT own resources on the revenue of the Member States.
The Court of Justice confirmed that the scope of Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 on administrative cooperation in the field of value added tax included the establishment of cooperation mechanisms between Member States that would enable them to combat VAT evasion more effectively and the collection of value added tax more effectively.
This also affects the availability of own resources for VAT for the EU budget.
If cooperation between national authorities is effective and in line with the Regulation, it may contribute to the reduction of fraud and the effective collection of VAT in the Member States and to the maintenance of VAT own resources at the level required by the various relevant EU legislation and thus to the maintenance of the overall level of own resources.
The Court found that the Court of Auditors was entitled to carry out a planned audit in connection with administrative cooperation in the field of VAT as it referred to the EU's revenue as regards legality and sound financial management and was therefore directly linked to the powers conferred on the Court of Auditors under the Treaty.
In Case C-539/09, the Court had, for the first time, to clearly define the scope of the Court's audit powers.
The ruling of the Court of Justice is valuable and encouraging as it clarifies and strengthens the powers of the institutions in the field of control vis-à-vis the Member States.
In 2010, the Court awarded the first prize for the research work in the field of public sector audit in order to establish contacts with universities and to support the development of public control in Europe.
This first award was an expression of the memory of Jesús Lázaro Cuenca, the former director of the Court, who for many years contributed to the development of methods and methods of control of the institution.

31 OUR MANAGEMENT FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STRATEGIES FOR 2009 In the last few years, the Court has launched an internal reform process.
This includes the development of its first strategy for the period 2009-20122 to achieve the following general objectives: to maximise the overall impact of controls; to improve efficiency through the best use of resources.
Many of the priority actions foreseen in the strategy have already been completed; the remaining actions in 2012 will be published in the 2 audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 on the website www.eca.europa.eu. The main achievements achieved in 2011 are: an increase in the number of special reports; an average of 16 special reports have been published in 2009-2011, which exceeded the annual objective of 12-15 reports; a major contribution to the reform of the EU budget; an increase in the preparation of regular reports on the follow-up of previous findings, including the general follow-up report to be carried out in 2012; a renewed audit strategy and guidelines; an increase in the emphasis on fundamental actions through the posting of staff from audit support services; a publication of a document on follow-up to the current financial and economic crisis for public responsibility and financial control in the EU and the role of the Court.
The Court strengthened its audit management framework in 2008 by adopting ethical guidelines based on the obligations and the INTOSAI Code of Conduct and the International Standards of Quality Control in the ORB3.
In this context, the Court established a procedure which would ensure, on an annual basis, sufficient assurance that its auditors meet the relevant ethical requirements.
Compliance with the values set out in the ethical guidelines, such as impartiality, objectivity, loyalty and professional secrecy, ensures that the Court's employees act in the public interest without external pressure and without affecting their personal or financial interests.
The Court's framework for professional proceedings shall promote the reliability of the information provided to it by the addressees.

The Court seeks to maintain or improve this outcome in case of similar consultations in 2012.
SUPPORTING THE CONTROL ACTION The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its specialised services.
These services provide technical knowledge and logistics enabling the Court to recruit, maintain and motivate its staff and develop their professional skills; to disseminate the results of controls in all the official EU languages; to make the best use of information technologies; to manage the budget and to maintain infrastructure; to carry out audit visits in order to obtain evidence on the spot and on the spot in the countries where EU funds are collected and used.

38 TERMINATION The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional context and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's results.
The Court's employment policy is in line with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and staff is composed of both officials and temporary staff.
The general procedures for the selection of posts at the Court are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
In addition, the Court establishes a policy of equal opportunities within its staff policy and in the case of employment, such as other EU institutions, within its staff policy and within its equal opportunities policy.
Following a steady increase in women's participation over the years, the Court has achieved a balanced participation of women and men among its employees.
In 2011, the Court recruited 75 staff: 23 officials, 24 temporary staff and 28 contract staff.
The Court has in particular managed to recruit new workers for the posts of auditors.
25 posts were serviceless on 31 December 2011, and in 2010 there was much less than in 2010 (44).
In this way, the job vacancy rate fell for the first time below 3%.

In 2011, the Court's staff completed an average of 9.3 days of vocational training.
Language courses accounted for 54% of the total number of training days (compared with 57% in 2010).
In addition to language courses, the auditors completed 6.1 day of vocational training in 2011 and thus achieved an important objective of the institutions.
In 2011, a substantive improvement in training was introduced and new courses were developed in order to adapt to the audit priorities.
The Court has also improved the system for the management of training activities.
Written translation is an important action to support the audit to enable the Court to carry out its mission and to achieve its communication objectives.
In 2011, the volume of translations was comparable to the 2010 work volume.
More than 99% of translation services were completed on time.
In 2011, further posts and staff were transferred from the Translation Directorate to the Audit Service.
