40 INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology (IT) plays a key role in achieving the overall objectives of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following measures: to strengthen investment in knowledge management by launching a new version of the training support instrument (the "Assyst2 in 2011") on the basis of a recently established cooperation platform; to actively continue to work on improving internal procedures through electronic working processes in areas such as business travel management and training; and electronic archiving of personnel documentation in order to continuously increase efficiency and efficiency; to continue to support mobility through the use of smartphones and laptop computers; and to start working on an extranet project, which will also play a key role in facilitating electronic exchanges with the Court's numerous partners (e.g. with stakeholders, budgetary authorities, new employees, suppliers).
These developments have been achieved while increasing operational and security security in emergency situations in order to ensure the availability and quality of all IT services provided by the Court.

In April 2011, this was done by replacing an external security service provider with a small team of contract staff.
The annual costs will be more than EUR 0.5 million lower in 2012 than in 2009.
CONTROL During the Court's audit work, auditors must go to the Member States and to other beneficiaries of EU funds, as well as to the headquarters of international organisations such as the United Nations.
The purpose of these inspection visits is to obtain direct control evidence.
Visits are usually carried out by central and local authorities involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds, as well as by final beneficiaries.
In the EU, checks are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the Member State visited.
The team of controllers usually consists of two to three controllers, and the duration of the examination trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
CONTROL In 2011, the Court carried out a total of 379 audit visits5 in 2011 in the Member States and in the 36 non-EU Member States in relation to audits in relation to annual reports and special annual reports and selected audit tasks.
A similar number of audit visits were carried out by EU institutions and bodies in Brussels and Luxembourg.
5 This corresponds to the number of Member States and beneficiary countries to which the audit visits have been carried out in relation to the various audit tasks.
In 2010, this figure was 376.

FINANCIAL INFORMATION The Court shall be financed by the general budget of the EU.
Its budget represents around 0,1% of the total EU expenditure and less than 2% of the total administrative expenditure.

46 INTERNAL CONTROL AND CONTROL The task of an internal audit body is to provide an independent and objective guarantee and provide advisory services in such a way as to increase and improve the added value of the Court's activities.
Supporting the Court in achieving the objectives of the institutions through a systematic and rigorous approach to evaluation and recommendations in order to improve the effectiveness of risk management, control and management procedures.
In carrying out its tasks, the Department of Internal Audit shall act in accordance with the provisions of the EU Financial Regulation, with the provisions applicable to EU officials, as well as with international standards of professional practice in the field of internal audit.
In 2009, the Court's internal audit services were checked and certified in accordance with the international standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
THE COURT'S EXTERNAL AUDIT The annual accounts of the European Court of Auditors shall be audited by an independent auditor.
This is a key element of the Court's efforts to ensure that it applies the same principles of transparency and accountability as those of the authorities it has carried out.
In 2011, the Court's internal audit services presented reports on the state of play of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy; on the implementation of key performance indicators; on the creation of a new K3 building of the Court; on the use of a trust account for payments to eligible beneficiaries; on the implementation of previous recommendations.
The internal audit services fully supported the Court's independent auditor in certifying the Court's annual accounts and the effectiveness of its internal audit procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee advises on internal control issues and monitors the related internal control environment in the framework of the institution's risk management procedures.
In 2011, the Internal Audit Committee and Internal Auditors analysed the results of audits of the internal services and of the implementation of the action plans affecting the internal control environment and the risks associated with the management of the institution.
The auditor's report at PricewaterhouseCoopers SRL on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2010 was published in September 20116.

I, the Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declare that the information contained in this report is correct and accurate, and hereby certify with sufficient assurance that the appropriations for the actions described in this report have been used for the purposes and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, and that the control procedures put in place give reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts and the proper management of the allegations of fraud or fraud.

Luxembourg, 8 March 2012 Mr Eduardo RUIZ GARCÍA Secretary-General
The European Court of Auditors shall be an independent external audit body of the European Union established in Luxembourg.
The Court of Auditors shall act as a collegial body consisting of 27 members, each of which shall consist of one member of each Member State.
Its members shall be appointed by the Council for a term of office of six years after consulting the European Parliament.
Members shall elect a President from among themselves for a period of three years, with the possibility of re-election.
The Court shall be organised in accordance with the chambers to which the members are assigned.
The Chambers shall prepare reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
The control chambers I-IV cover different areas of revenue and expenditure, while the fifth, the CEAD, is responsible for horizontal issues.
The chambers are assisted by control departments.
Since the revision of the Court's Rules of Procedure in 2010, certain categories of Court reports and opinions may be adopted by chambers and not by the entire College of the Court.
The Management Committee shall meet under the chairmanship of the chairman and shall consist of the Doyen Chambers and the Secretary-General (responsible for the administrative services and assistance of the Court).
The Committee shall act as coordinator and prepare the Court's decisions on strategic planning and management of results and on administrative matters.
Each member shall be responsible for specific tasks, in particular in the field of audit.
Members shall submit proposals for checks and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible, to the Chamber and to the Court.
Following adoption of the report, the rapporteur member shall submit it to the European Parliament, the Council and the other interested parties.
Members shall be assisted by their cabinet representatives and a team of auditors appointed for the examination of 49 tasks.

European Court of Auditors 2012 Annual Activity Report
3 THE EUROPEAN COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF Auditors THE EUROPEAN COURT OF Auditors IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE CONTROL OF THE EU'S FINANCIALS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TREATY.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management, contributes to accountability and transparency and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
Independence, INTEGRATION AND Independency PROFESSIONALITY MORE EXTERNAL VALUE AND EFFIence Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its staff.
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
preparing appropriate and timely high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the needs of the group of addressees, taking into account relevant and relevant comments and guidance.
contribute to the effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and to increasing the responsibility for the management of EU funds.
Promoting team spirit through effective communication.
5 PAGE 6 PRELIMINATION OF THE PRESIDENT 8 2012 ON PAGE 9 OF ACTION 9 OF THE AUDIT REPORT AND OPINION 30 OF THE COOPERATION WITH OTHER MAJOR ACCOUNTING AUTHORITIES 34 OF OUR MANAGEMENT 35 IN THE COURT'S AGE OF 36 DAYS OF INQUIRIES ON THE CERTIFICATE OF THE COURT 44 SUPPORT OF THE AUDIT ACTION 49 FINANCIAL INFORMATION 52 VIEWS ON THE CONTROL AND ACCOUNTING 52 VIEWS IN THE YEAR OF OPINION OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF Auditors 54 35 YEARS IN THE VIEW OF THE BETTER VIEW OF THE EU 6 THE PRESIDENT OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome TO THE TERMINATION OF THE REPORT OF THE YEAR 2012 OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF Auditors!
In 2012, the Court focused on preparing the Union for the main challenges of financial management after 2013.
At the beginning of the year, the Court adopted an opinion on some of the proposals for regulations on the common agricultural policy (CAP), which is the most famous EU policy.
The draft regulation was part of the legislative package for the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework.
In 2012, the Court issued a number of opinions and reports which actively contributed to the strengthening of the new rules which will be subject to EU revenue and expenditure during that period.
Moreover, in 2012, the Court continued to monitor to a large extent the impact of changes in the EU's economic governance on public responsibility and financial control.
This year the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism entered into force and the audit committee of the new body, including the representative of the Court, took place at its first meeting.
In December 2012, the Council of the European Union adopted a position on the establishment of a single supervisory mechanism to ensure the supervision of euro area credit institutions and the Court presented its position to EU policy makers on public responsibility and financial control.
Many changes in the EU's economic governance and budget are due to the fact that better political results are to be achieved with lower public resources, while strengthening democratic legitimacy and accountability.
In view of its unique competences and views, on the one hand, and the experience of controls over 35 years, and, on the other hand, the partnership built for this purpose, the Court is well prepared to help the EU to meet these challenges.
On the basis of the achievements achieved in recent years, the Court's objective is to maximise the Court's contribution to improving the EU's reporting obligation in 2013-2017.
The farm is now celebrating its 35th anniversary.
Since the Court started work in 1977, Europe has changed significantly.
The structure and the way in which the Court is carried out reflect these changes.
With the accession of the new Member States, the transfer of competences to the Union and the creation of many bodies at EU level, the scope of the Court's audit has been extended.
The Court has also grown up as an organ, from nine members and 120 employees in 1977 to 27 members and almost 900 employees in 2012.
This increase enabled the farm to create professional, committed and experienced staff.
2012 was the last year covered by the Court's strategy for 2009-2012.
During this period, the Court noted encouraging results.
As this Annual Activity Report shows, production has been increased and external experts consider the quality of our reports to be good and institutional experts consider them useful.
The Commission's acceptance of the Court's recommendations remains high and the Court's new monitoring report highlights the positive effects of these recommendations.
The Court can also point to an increase in administrative and translation efficiency, which led to 40 additional staff at the end of that period.
To achieve the 2013-2017 objectives, the Court will prioritise products aimed at improving the EU's reporting obligation and the development and development of partnerships, professionalism and effectiveness.
In 2013, the International peer review team will examine the practice of checking the performance of the Court's tasks and will examine the results of the previous peer review of 2008.
Other key actions that will be launched in 2013 include improving the Court's reporting procedures, as well as making better use of our common foundation of knowledge, our expertise and our expertise.
In the coming years, the Court intends to support the EU in addressing the growing challenges of public responsibility and financial control.

12 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND 2011 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are financed by EU Member States but managed outside the EU budget and are subject to financial rules.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of the EDF-funded activities.
With the European Development Fund (EDF), the European Union is assisting African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and overseas countries and territories (OCTs) in development cooperation under the Cotonou Agreement signed in 2000.
These expenditure is intended to reduce poverty and to reduce poverty in the end, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of ACP and OCT countries into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars: development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2011 annual report on the EDF was published on 6 November 2012 in parallel with the annual report on the EU budget.
The Court found that the annual accounts of the EDF for 2011 adequately reflect the financial situation of the EDF and the results of its operations and cash flows.
However, 33% of EDF operations were affected by errors, including an estimated payment rate of 5,1% affected by errors.
In 2012, the Court published 50 special annual reports covering mainly the 2011 financial year concerning agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. Joint Undertakings) and other EU bodies.
Agencies and decentralised EU bodies shall be established on the basis of EU legislation to carry out specific tasks.
President Caldeira, during the presentation of the 2011 Annual Report at the plenary session of the European Parliament (November 2012)
In 2012, in addition to the annual reports, the Court shall publish, throughout the year, special reports containing the results of the performance and compliance checks carried out by the Court in the budgetary areas or management areas of its choice.
In selecting and shaping audit tasks, the Court seeks to achieve the maximum effect and thus to make the best use of its resources.
In choosing the subject matter, the Court takes into account the following factors: the risk to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the area of income or expenditure; the level of income or expenditure; the time since the previous audit; the future changes in the legal framework; the political and public interest.
In 2012, the Court adopted 25 special reports covering a wide range of issues.
This represents a significant increase compared to the 16 special reports adopted in 2011 (and 12 in 2008).
All special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website: http://eca.europa.eu/.

In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports: the financial instruments for SMEs co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (R Regional Development Fund) (No 2/2012). The special report assessed the effectiveness and effectiveness of the financial engineering measures co-financed by the ERDF for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods. The audit concerned the sample of projects in Germany, Portugal, Slovakia, Hungary and the United Kingdom and assessed the management, monitoring and information systems of the Commission and the Member States.
The Court found that the impact on the effectiveness and effectiveness of the expenditure on financial instruments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) incurred under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) was infringed as the regulatory framework did not provide an adequate basis for the use of the various types of financial instruments.
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the EU economy and provide employment, innovation and prosperity.
However, SMEs may not be able to meet their financial needs in the required form and amount.
To support them, the EU uses entrepreneurship and cohesion policies, mainly in the form of assistance, and increasingly in the framework of the ERDF in the framework of the financial instruments.
Financial instruments are returnable and renewable instruments.
According to the Commission's figures, the ERDF allocations for financial instruments amount to EUR 1.6 billion and EUR 10.4 billion respectively for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods.

(No 3/2012) The special report examines the extent to which the Commission has put in place appropriate corrective measures, ensured their timely implementation and ensured sufficient assurance that their actions have ensured appropriate financial corrections in relation to irregularities in the past and to the improvement of the systems in order to avoid recurrence of irregularities.
The audit was carried out mainly on the basis of a review of 40 programmes for which serious deficiencies were identified.
The Court found that, with regard to the shortcomings in the management and control systems in the Member States, the Commission ensured quite well the correct application of financial corrections, but only to a lesser extent ensured that its actions led to the improvement of the systems in the Member States.

16 THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK OF THE SUSTAINABLE GROWTH OF GROWTH TO SUPPORT infrastructure projects in municipal waste management in structural actions provides effective support to Member States in the implementation of the EU waste policy objectives?
(No 20/2012) This special report assessed the results of 26 waste management infrastructure projects in the sample, including the implementation of EU waste policy objectives, as well as the implementation of accompanying actions in the eight regions in which the infrastructure is located.
The Court found that insufficient implementation of accompanying measures and shortcomings in EU legislation and guidance had an impact on the effectiveness of supporting municipal waste management infrastructure in EU structural measures.
In 2010, every citizen of the 27 EU Member States produced on average about 500 kg of waste which, if not properly collected, processed and disposed of, could have a negative impact on the environment.
The EU has introduced common standards and objectives in the form of directives on the management of municipal waste and has co-financed waste management infrastructure in certain regions.
In 2000-2013, the EU allocated €10.8 billion to waste management infrastructure. about the cost-effectiveness of investments in energy efficiency in the framework of cohesion policy (No 21/2012), the special report assessed whether the investments in energy efficiency in cohesion policy were cost-effective by examining whether planning and financing created the right conditions to allow cost-effective investments in energy efficiency and whether energy efficiency projects in public buildings were cost-effective.
The Court found that the average return on EU investment in energy efficiency is more than 50 years (in extreme cases up to 150 years), which means that funds for this type of investment could be used more cost-effectively.
The cost of increased energy consumption, the depletion of fossil fuel consumption and the impact of human activity on global climate change is the driving force of the recent EU policy to increase energy efficiency.
Since 2000, the European Union has spent almost EUR 5 billion in co-financing energy efficiency actions in the Member States in the framework of cohesion policy.

18 THE EU'S FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK FOR THE JOINING AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES is politically responsible for agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 is EUR 413.1 billion, or 42.3% of the EU budget.
The three quarters of the expenditure relate to direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF) for agricultural purposes and to the improvement of the quality of the quality and quality of the quality of the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund for Rural Development and Rural Development, and to the improvement of the quality of the quality and quality of the quality of life of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, and to the improvement of the quality and quality of life of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and Guarantee Fund for Rural Development and Rural Development.

In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: on the reform of the common organisation of the market in wine: progress so far (No 7/2012) in this special report has been assessed on progress towards one of the main objectives of the reform of the wine sector, namely progress towards a better balance between supply and demand.
The audit focused on measures under the grubbing-up and restructuring and conversion premiums for vineyards, which constitute the two main expenditure areas and which are essential for achieving the objective of achieving a better balance between supply and demand.
The Court found that these two measures were contradictory and that the structural supply surpluses were not significantly reduced.
For a period of three years of application of the grubbing-up measure ( 2008/2009-2010/2011), the EU budget was EUR 1.1 billion.
For the restructuring and restructuring period of 10 years up to 2010, €4.2 billion was allocated to target aid for the modernisation of agricultural holdings for specific purposes (No 8/2012).This special report examines whether EU aid for the modernisation of agricultural holdings was targeted at EU priorities and the specific needs of the Member States.
The Court found that measures aimed at modernising agricultural holdings would potentially be more effective, by using more targeted funds to meet the EU's priorities and the specific needs of the Member States and by making effective use of the selection procedures.
This aid concerns the financing of investments in agricultural holdings, from investments in simple products such as agricultural products or wooden fruit boxes, to investments in complex projects such as biogas.
The EU budget for this assistance (the EAFRD) for the 2007-2013 programming period amounts to EUR 11.1 billion, representing around 11% of all EU rural development expenditure. o Control of the control system governing the production, processing, distribution and import of organic products (No 9/2012) The special report examines whether the control system for organic products provides sufficient assurance of the fulfilment of the key production, processing, distribution and import requirements for organic products.
It has examined how different stakeholders (the European Commission and the competent authorities of the Member States, accreditation bodies and certification bodies) have fulfilled their tasks in the EU and in the management of import systems.
The Court found that the competent authorities in the Member States encountered difficulties in ensuring the traceability of organic products and that the system should address the shortcomings that need to be addressed in order to ensure that the system is functioning effectively and to ensure that consumer confidence is not undermined.
The objective of the EU legal framework for organic production is to provide the basis for the sustainable development of organic production, to ensure a level playing field, to protect consumers' interests while ensuring the smooth functioning of the internal market.
A control system has been introduced whereby each operator in the supply chain is controlled and certified. for direct aid for suckler, ovine and caprine cows in the framework of the partial implementation of the single payment scheme (No 11/2012) in the framework of that specific report has examined whether the aid has been targeted at the most appropriate regions in the Member States, whether it has been effective in maintaining specific production and thus in preventing negative social, economic and environmental impacts, and whether it has been subject to appropriate monitoring and evaluation by the Commission and the Member States.
The Court found that direct CAP support for maternal herds does not produce better results than non-production-related aid.
Following the 2003 CAP reform, agricultural aid previously granted in the form of direct payments linked to the production of certain agricultural products (so-called production-related aid) (so-called production-related aid) should no longer be paid, depending on production after the introduction of the single payment scheme (so-called production-related aid).
However, for certain sectors and regions, certain derogations are provided for from total separation from production in order to reduce the potential negative effects of the immediate transition to such a system.
The total budget for this direct aid for 2011 was EUR 1.0 billion.

Monitoring, targeted assistance, implementation and financing of measures to ensure compliance with sanitary rules have been examined.
The Court examined slaughterhouses in Poland, Romania, Slovenia, the Czech Republic and Hungary, which received EU funds.
While the Court found that the systems of the Commission and the competent authorities set up to monitor hygiene legislation were appropriate, the audit revealed a number of shortcomings in the implementation of those systems, which indicate that, in order to reduce risks, more severity is needed at all levels.
The Member States that joined the EU since 2004 had to ensure that their slaughterhouses complied with EU hygiene rules.
Since these rules generally contained far more stringent requirements than national rules, EU funds have been allocated to help slaughterhouses comply with hygiene rules and to modernise them.
The special pre-accession programme for agriculture and rural development (Sapard programme) allocates around €117 million to 241 slaughterhouses.
The support was then continued under the EAGGF and EAFRD. on the effectiveness of the single area payment scheme as a transitional scheme to support farmers in the new Member States (No 16/2012) under this special report examined the main shortcomings, such as payments to beneficiaries who do not carry out (or do not carry out marginal) agricultural activities, payments to farmers who have resigned from non-agricultural activities, payments to public authorities and payments focused on the few large beneficiaries.
The Court found that part of the aid had been paid to beneficiaries who had had a small agricultural activity or had no agricultural activity, including in the public sector, and that the distribution of the aid did not take account of the specificities of the regional agricultural activity or of the farmers' contribution to the production of public goods.
Moreover, a large majority of farmers receive a very small amount of aid.
The single area payment scheme is a simplified income support scheme for farmers in the Member States who have joined the EU since 2004.
In 2011, payments amounted to around EUR 5 billion.
The Court adopted the following special report in 2012: on the European Integration Fund and on the European Refugee Fund effectively contribute to the integration of third-country nationals?
(No 22/2012) The Special Report assessed whether the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund, which are part of the EU's general programme 2007-2013 (SOLID) effectively contributed to the integration of third-country nationals into the EU, whether the results were supported by effective monitoring and evaluation of the programme, whether the concept of the Funds contributed to the effective implementation of the Funds, and whether the implementation systems for the integration of the SOLID programme were properly managed.
The Court found that, although positive results were found for the various projects audited, for which inadequate systems were introduced in order to measure the success of the funds.
The effectiveness of the funds has been reduced by the programme and coordination with other EU funds has been insufficient.
The EU supports the integration of third-country nationals in the EU Member States and increases solidarity by sharing the financial burden of managing common external borders and implementing common policies in the field of asylum and immigration.
The EU budget for the Solid programme for 2007-2013 is estimated to amount to a total of EUR 4.0 billion.
21 In order to ensure the free movement of persons and to ensure a high level of protection for citizens, this policy area has been established.
It covers from the management of the EU's external borders to judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters.
It includes asylum and immigration policies, police cooperation and the fight against crime.
The expenditure for this area is estimated to reach EUR 12.2 billion for the period 2007-2013.
22 THE EU'S FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK, AS THE EU'S Global PARTNER, in the field of external relations, focuses on: enlargement, ensuring stability, security and prosperity in the neighbourhood, actively promoting sustainable development on the international stage, promoting global political governance and ensuring strategic and civil security.
The EU has committed €55.9 billion to these objectives for the period 2007-2013, i.e. 5.7% of the planned expenditure.
The Commission shall manage expenditure in most cases directly through its central services or delegations.
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: on the effectiveness of EU development aid for food security in sub-Saharan Africa (No 1/2012) in this special report examined the effectiveness of EU development aid for food security in sub-Saharan Africa by analysing whether EU aid for food security is relevant for the needs and priorities of the countries and whether EU action was effective.
The audit focused on direct EU assistance to develop three pillars of food security: food availability, food access and a sustainable diet.
The Court found that EU aid for the development of food security in sub-Saharan Africa is mostly effective and contributes significantly to the achievement of food security.
However, the Commission has not sufficiently taken into account the possibilities of EU support to other countries, which are also affected by chronic food uncertainties, and has not sufficiently taken into account the issue of nutrition.
Food security is a serious and persistent problem in sub-Saharan Africa, where hunger affects 30% of the population.
In 2002-2010, the EU financed the European Development Fund (EDF) in the region for food security measures for a total amount of over EUR 3.2 billion. for the Common Information System RELEX (CRIS) (5/2012). In this special report, it examined whether CRIS was able to meet the Commission's needs effectively and whether it was credible.
The audit included a review of the CRIS documentation available to the Commission and an analysis of the data contained in the CRIS.
The Court found that CRIS to a large extent met the Commission's needs for information on external actions.
After ten years of development, however, it still has weak points.
CRIS is an information system set up by the Commission to support the management of external actions.
The system's functions have been constantly extended since its launch in 2002.
It is currently the main reference system for the management and documentation of external actions, together with reports, and is financed both from the general budget of the EU and from the European Development Fund (EDF).
o European Union assistance to the Turkish Cypriot community (No 6/2012) (No 6/2012).This special report examines whether the Commission has developed a programme of assistance in line with the objectives of the instrument, whether appropriate implementation procedures have been established and whether the various projects have achieved the appropriate objectives.
The aim of the audit was not to assess whether the programme contributed to the objective of political unification.
The Court found that the programme met its objectives as an instrument of financial support for the Turkish Cypriot communities and that, despite significant constraints, it created an overall appropriate environment.
Some results have already been achieved, but their sustainability is often questionable, and the largest project under the programme could not be implemented.
Around a third of this amount was examined by the Court by means of its sample of agreements by the European Union for the development of drinking water and basic sanitary services in the sub-Saharan region (No 13/2012) in the context of this special report, whether the Commission managed EU development aid to improve the quality of drinking water and basic sanitary services in sub-Saharan Africa in such a way as to achieve effective and sustainable results.
The Court found that EU support improved access to drinking water and basic sanitary services.
On the other hand, less than half of the projects audited have financed the needs of the beneficiaries in a satisfactory way, and the benefits will only last if the revenue is secured and not based on charges.
Improving water supply and sanitation is crucial to achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
Supply of clean drinking water and sanitation contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction.
Between 2001 and 2010, EU expenditure on water and sanitation infrastructure in the sub-Saharan area amounted to around EUR 1.0 billion; as funding for water and sanitation infrastructure is earmarked for other areas of assistance, the Commission has, in total, provided more funding.

24 EU FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK ACTION AS A EU FINANCIAL PARTNER FOR THE CONTRIBUTION OF THE European Development Fund (EDF) TO A sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa (No 17/2012) its special report examines whether the EDF has effectively contributed to the sustainable development of the road network in sub-Saharan Africa, whether the road infrastructure supported by the EDF is sustainable and whether the Commission has effectively supported the sustainable development of road infrastructure.
The audit focused on the technical, financial and institutional sustainability of road infrastructure and 48 programmes which since 1995 have been supported under the eighth, ninth and tenth EDFs in six partner countries.
The Court found that the Commission's support for a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa is partially effective.
The partner countries visited by the Court are not making sufficient efforts to ensure the sustainable development of road infrastructure, making the roads to varying degrees vulnerable to premature consumption.
Roads and other transport infrastructures are essential for regional integration, economic growth, social development, efficient public administration and security.
In sub-Saharan Africa, road transport is the most important means of transport for people and goods and represents more than 80% of the total transport of goods and services, and the demand for transport is growing rapidly.
In this region, the EU has allocated around €7.4 billion to the EDF in 1995-2011 for the European Union's Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo (No 18/2012) (see introduction to performance control).

25 SUPERVISION ON ECONOMIC SUPERVISION European Union Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo European Union Assistance to Kosovo Border Control Assistance to Kosovo and EULEX in Kosovo © EULEX, 2011, photo of Enisa Kasemi In the framework of the EU Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo, the Court of Justice presented the mission of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the spotlight for the first time.
Kosovo is the world's largest beneficiary of EU per capita financial assistance and the place of the largest civilian crisis management operation ever launched by the Union (European Union Rule of Law Mission in Kosovo under EULEX).
The Court's Special Report No 18/2012 assessed the effectiveness of EU assistance to Kosovo in the field of the rule of law.
The audit focused on four sectors: police, judiciary, customs and the fight against corruption.
The Court also examined the coordination with other donors and the implementation of EULEX.
The study of such a complex area was a challenge.
Four verification visits were carried out in Kosovo.
There have been consultations with EULEX officials and the European Commission, as well as local officials, representatives of the international donor community and civil society organisations.
The audit team has examined projects under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and the Instrument for Stability and Monitoring, Advisory and Advisory (MMA) activities carried out by EULEX.
Meetings took place in Brussels with the Commission, the European External Action Service, the Council and NATO Secretariat.
In addition, the Court supported a team of experts.
The Court found that EU aid was not sufficiently effective.
Although the EU has contributed to capacity building, especially in the area of customs, the success of police and justice assistance has been modest.
In Kosovo, the level of organised crime and corruption remains high.
Justice continues to experience political influence, inefficiency and lack of transparency and enforcement.
The limited capacity to protect important witnesses in Kosovo and the difficulty in transferring witnesses abroad are serious shortcomings.
In the words of Gijs de Vries, a member of the Court responsible for the report, the Kosovo authorities do not assume sufficient priority for the rule of law and EU aid should be more effective.
Francisco de Miguel Rodriguez, head of the evaluation team, says that there is no place in the world other than Kosovo, where in such a small area there could be so many international donors for capacity building.
The Court concluded that EU coordination mechanisms, including coordination with the international community, should be improved.
Unlike the other Western Balkan countries, the lack of a common EU position on their independence poses a threat to their possible accession to the EU in the case of Kosovo.
In the field of communication, this analysis has moved towards new ways.
This was most frequently cited in 2012 in the Court's report, in which more than 130 articles were published in printed and electronic media.
In addition, a summary video was published on the Court's website.
It was a premiere for the Court, reflecting its desire to reach a wider audience.
The European Commission and the European External Action Service have accepted the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The report was presented to the European Parliament and to the Council working groups.
In view of the importance of its findings, the UK Upper House has decided to take a comprehensive look at the report.

(No 12/2012) The special report assessed whether the procedures for the production of reliable and reliable statistics were improved by the Commission and Eurostat.
The improvement is directly linked to compliance with the Code of Conduct for European Statistics, which sets standards for the production, production and dissemination of statistics and for the implementation of the European Statistical Programme.

Reliable and reliable statistics are crucial to the achievement of the tasks entrusted to the European Union.
Statistics are necessary in almost all areas for the formulation, application, monitoring and evaluation of the tasks and objectives of the Treaties, and for the collection and allocation of EU funds.
European policy decisions are increasingly based directly on statistics and statistical indicators are increasingly used as a factor in policy decisions or sanctions. on the management of conflicts of interest in selected EU agencies (No 15/2012) This special report assesses whether the selected agencies have properly managed conflicts of interest, whether there are appropriate guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflicts of interest situations and whether the selected agencies have properly implemented guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflicts of interest situations.
The review assessed guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflicts of interest situations for four selected agencies which take decisions affecting consumer safety and health.
The Court found that the selected EU agencies did not adequately manage conflicts of interest.
The report examines the extent to which the recommendations made by the Court in the seven selected special reports from 2003 to 2009 were implemented by the Commission.
Further special reports concerned three budgetary areas: agriculture, energy and external action.
The Court assessed the actions taken by the Commission in response to the Court's recommendations.
The audit showed that the recommendations were taken into account: the Commission fully implemented 29% of the recommendations examined, mostly implemented 49%, partly implemented 20% and 2% did not.

29 OPINION No 1/2012 ON THE COMMISSION'S LEGISLATIVE PROPOSALS ON THE REFORM OF THE COMMON AGRICULTURE POLICY FROM 2014 (Common Agricultural Policy (CAP)) is to be reformed by 2013.
In October 2011, the Commission published a proposal containing the main elements of the CAP legislative framework for 2014-2020.
The new legal framework proposes maintaining the current two-pillar structure of the CAP and thus the two existing European financial instruments under the agricultural policy: the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
The Court recognised the Commission's efforts to simplify the CAP rules (e.g. not applying the different implementation models under the current single payment scheme, the introduction of a simplified scheme for small farmers).
In its conclusions, the Commission made a number of observations by Parliament, the Council and the Court.
However, legislative proposals continue, in principle, to focus on expenditure and control, and therefore, contrary to the stated intentions, they continue to comply with the performance rules.
The Court took note of the Commission's objective of paying CAP aid to active farmers and of seeking to achieve a more balanced distribution of direct payments to beneficiaries.
However, the Court had doubts as to whether the proposed measures could be effectively implemented without imposing an excessive administrative burden on administrative authorities and farmers.
In his view, the solution could consist in the combination of the general principles laid down in the Regulation and the systematic monitoring and monitoring by the Commission of their implementation.
It stated that the so-called "shortening' (shortening the aid beyond a certain ceiling) would have a limited impact on the redistribution of the aid.
This opinion has had a significant impact on the reflection on the future of the CAP.
More than 2000 articles have been published in the media.
The Court has been invited by a number of NGOs, farmers' fair organisers and other industrial forums to present an opinion and the European Parliament invites the Court's representatives to participate in the working groups on the subject.
Most of the European Parliament's recommendations have been incorporated into its own proposals for changes to legislation.
The legislative package will be put to the vote after the adoption of the multiannual financial framework.

34 OUR MANAGEMENT: STRATEGIES FOR 2013-2017 The Court adopted and published its 2013-2017 strategy in 2012.
The Court's objective during this period is to maximise the value of the Court's contribution to the EU's public responsibility.
The main priorities for achieving this objective are: to focus the Court's products on improving the EU's reporting obligation; to cooperate with other actors to increase the Court's contribution to the implementation of the EU's reporting obligation; to further develop as a professional audit body; to make the best use of the existing knowledge, knowledge and expertise fund at the Court; to demonstrate the Court's capacity and accountability.
The Court will use its unique powers and views, expertise, expertise and partnerships, which it has built over 35 years of its existence, to assist, to assist, to assist other parties involved in the EU-level accountability process to identify the risks of EU responsibility and to facilitate the use of audit results, to enhance professionalism by contributing and applying new control standards and best practices, to assist other parties involved in the EU-level accountability process, to enhance reporting and opinion processes, to improve the results and control framework, in accordance with their responsibilities as EU and ORB institutions, to implement budgetary discipline measures in accordance with the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, including the further improvement of reporting and opinion processes, to improve their performance and accountability, in accordance with their responsibilities as EU and ORB institutions, to implement, in accordance with the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, the budgetary framework measures, including to the extent that it applies.
In 2013-2017, the Court will focus on reports, opinions and comments on the following aspects: strengthening public responsibility and control; improving financial management and reporting on the implementation of the EU budget; and improving financial management; improving responsibility for the implementation of EU spending policies and programmes.

1 43 44 SUPPORT FOR THE CONTROL OF STAFF RESOURCES The Court's most important capital is its staff.
At 31 December 2012, the Court's staff was 887 staff (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
573 of them work in examination chambers (including 123 staff in the study of members).
In 2012, given the objective of the best use of resources, the possibility of increasing efficiency through simplification of procedures was re-examined and implemented in all actions.
The posts released as a result of increased efficiency outside the scope of control were, as far as possible, transferred to the control services and the services of the President.
As a result, since 2008, the number of audit posts has increased by 14.4%, while the total number of posts approved by the Court has increased by only 3.5%.
Production increased significantly over the same period (see page 9).

Moreover, the Court, for a limited number of university graduates, establishes a policy of equal opportunities between men and women, as well as other EU institutions, for human resources management and recruitment.
Following a steady increase in women's participation over the years, the Court has achieved the almost balanced participation of women and men among its employees.
At the end of 2012, the Court adopted an action plan on equal opportunities aimed at achieving a more balanced participation of women and men at all levels of the institution.
In 2012, the Court had 78 staff: 50 officials, 11 temporary staff and 17 contract staff.
Since 2011, the number of job vacancies is almost 3% (28 job vacancies on 31 December 2012).

EDUCATION EDUCATION EDUCATION The profession of examiner requires continuous training to keep pace with new changes and acquire new skills.
Moreover, due to the specific nature of the Court's audit environment, auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2012, the Court's staff (researchers and other staff) completed an average of 8 days of vocational training (9.3 days in 2011).
Language courses accounted for 52% of the total number of training days (compared with 54% in 2011).
Translation is a supporting action to support checks that enable the Court to carry out its mission and to achieve its communication objectives.
In 2012, the value of translations reached a maximum of 158 861 pages, i.e. 11% higher than in 2011.
More than 99% of translations were completed on time.
Information technologies play a key role in the efficiency and efficiency of the Court.
2012 was a successful year: a first version of the new control support instrument (ASYST2) of the Court was created in the field of knowledge management and a pilot phase was launched in the control department.
In addition, improvements were made in the content of training in 2012 and new courses were developed in order to adapt to the audit priorities.
Moreover, the creation of a new electronic system and the development of e-learning have made it possible to manage training activities more effectively.
The Translation Directorate did not only provide linguistic support in inspections in the Member States, but also in the subsequent stages of drawing up the audit reports.
It also supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the Court's audit activities. the automation of administrative processes was actively continued by the introduction of the ECAdema supporting the Court's training policy, by decentralising the control of time by which human resources were spared and by fully digitising the personal files.
The new building was also connected with the new telephone system and the data network 47.
48 MANAGEMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE In 2012, the Directorate for Finance and Support Services continued to provide: (a) adequate resources, services and infrastructure for the fulfilment of strategic objectives and objectives, and (b) provide the necessary funding, internal control and accounting mechanisms to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2003, a second extension building was commissioned to ensure a safe, comfortable and ergonomic working environment for the Court's staff and to ensure that all the Court's staff work in one place.
In November 2012, the hostel closed down the building and the first move took place before the end of the year.

54 35 YEARS IN THE YEARS OF THE BETTER EU FUNCTIONS The European Court of Auditors has been an external auditor of the EU for 35 years, which has constantly added value to the Union's financial management and provides public responsibility for the use of taxpayers' money.
The Court was founded at a time when the European Community (the original European Union) developed towards greater democracy and greater responsibility towards its citizens.
Two particularly important steps are to extend the powers of the European Parliament to budgetary control and to fully finance the European Community budget from own resources.
The Community has recognised that it needs an independent external auditor who has helped Parliament and the Council to ensure democratic financial control.
Heinrich Aigner, President of the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, who, since 1973, has strongly supported an external audit body at Community level, has come across an initiative which led to the creation of the European Court of Auditors under the Brussels Treaty on 22 July 1975.
The Court started its activity in October 1977 with its seat in Luxembourg.
The President of the Court Hans Kußer then found the Court to be the financial conscience of the community.
On 1 November 1993, after the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty, the Court obtained the status of a fully-fledged European institution, which guarantees its independence and independence as an equivalent institution.
The Maastricht Treaty has also implemented, which is now the main product of the Court, namely the statement of assurance (DAS) of the EU accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The role of the Court was strengthened with the entry into force of the Amsterdam Treaty on 1 May 1999, in which the Court's independence was strengthened and its control powers extended to other policy areas.
The Nice Treaty of 1 February 2003 confirmed the principle that the Court should belong to one member of each Member State, also stressed the importance of the Court's cooperation with the national audit authorities and enabled the Court to establish the structure of the chambers.
Since its establishment, the Court has consistently supported cooperation with the highest audit authorities of the Member States in the control of EU funds, in particular through the participation of EU-ORKB Chairs in the Contact Committee.
As part of the ORKB role, the Court also sought to prepare the development of public sector control by cooperating with other ORKBs within the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Authorities (INTOSAI) and their regional EUROSAI group to define technical standards and best practices.
The Court took note of the peer review procedure at an early stage as a tool for the development and dissemination of best practices in the Community in the framework of the ORKB.
Over 35 years, the Court has sought to improve the EU's financial management by providing high-quality products reflecting changes in the EU and the changing needs of its addressees.
Over the last 35 years, the EU has adopted new Member States, has acquired new powers and has set up new institutions at EU level, and all of these countries have had to take account of their work.
As a result, the Court's results have increased significantly in comparison with the two opinions drawn up by the Court in the first year of its activities.
The Court's products now include annual reports, special reports, statements of assurance, special annual reports, opinions and position documents.
The number of products has increased to 87 publications in 2012.
For several years, the Court has given a higher priority to monitoring the results of EU policies and to providing guidance to improve cost-effectiveness.
Like the EU, the Court has developed.
On the basis of nine members and 120 employees in 1977, the Court currently has 27 members and almost 900 employees.
Like the Union itself, the success of the Court depends on close cooperation between members and workers from all European countries.
The Court is proud of the fact that since 1977 it has built seconded, professional and experienced staff that is responsible for protecting the financial interests of citizens.
In the coming years, the Court will seek to increase the responsibility towards citizens for the resources to achieve the objectives pursued.
55 Members of the first College of the Court, November 1977

To commemorate our colleague, Henrik Otbo, a member of the Court, who died unexpectedly on 1 February 2015, Henrik Otbo was born in 1949 and was Danish.
From 1995 to 2012 he was the President of the Danish Court of Auditors and from 1 March 2012 he was a member of the European Court of Auditors in the CEAD Chamber (coordination, evaluation, quality assurance and development) with special responsibility for development and evaluation of audit.
His commitment to public financial control throughout his life, in particular his leading role in setting international standards for the highest audit bodies as president of the INTOSAI Committee on Technical Standards, was particularly valuable to the Court, his former colleagues from the Danish Court of Auditors and the whole audit sector.
01 European Court of Auditors 02 The European Court of Auditors' mandate is responsible for the audit of the EU's finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management, contributes to accountability and transparency and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
The leading and dynamic Court of Auditors, which is characterised by fairness and impartiality, is recognised as a professional, quality and impact of its work and provides valuable support to its addressees in improving the EU's financial management.
Values Independence, integrity and impartiality Professionality Value added Excellence and efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its employees.
An impartial audit which takes account of the views of the addressee of the Court but rejects any form of influence through instructions or external pressures.
Maintaining the right level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Active participation in the further development of financial control in many cases at EU and global level.
preparing appropriate and timely high-quality reports based on reliable findings and evidence taking into account the issues on which they are based and taking into account the relevant and direction-oriented findings.
contribute to the effective improvement of EU financial management and contribute to the strengthening of the EU financial management obligation.
Promoting team spirit through effective communication.

The President's foreword 04 Dear Reader, 2014 was a year of profound change for the EU and its finances.
The EU has entrusted the European Central Bank with responsibility for the supervision of large banks in the euro area.
This was the first year of the new multiannual financial framework relevant for the implementation of the EU budget for the period 2014-2020.
The new elections of the European Parliament and the renewal of the highest positions in the Council and the European Commission were also of particular importance and the six new members of the European Court of Auditors (ECA) were welcomed.
In 2014, our body issued 91 reports, opinions and other products, more than ever before.
They are the result of our accounting audits, compliance audits and performance audits, including audits, which are part of our new competences in the field of financial and economic governance.
They contain a number of important proposals, proposals and recommendations for improving EU financial management and accountability for the 2014-2020 programming period.
Some of its main statements are contained in this annual activity report.
We are also trying to provide our addressees with the broadest possible knowledge of the main challenges facing the EU in terms of funding and implementation of policies, based on our experience in the field of control.
To this end, in 2014, we introduced a new product called "Landscape Analysis" in 2014 in order to help this period.
In addition, at the request of the European Parliament, we have published an overview of the results of our accounting and compliance checks in the field of agriculture and cohesion in the period 2009-2013.
The Court also cooperates with its addressees to ensure that the addressees can make the most of the results of their work.
In 2014, the Court appointed, inter alia, the member responsible for institutional relations and the Ombudsman.
It also organised several events to ensure that information can be exchanged with high-level stakeholders from the EU and Member States.
During the conference, a number of those responsible for the management and control of EU funds, including Members of the European Parliament, the European Commission, met the highest control bodies and representatives of the scientific community.
The European Parliament's Vice-President and former EU Commissioner, Commissioner Olli Rehn, gave an introductory speech.
Particular attention should be paid to the visit of the delegation of the members of the Court to Lithuania, where the meetings took place with Members of Parliament, members of the Government and representatives of the national Court of Auditors and with the Lithuanian Central Bank.
Preface by President 05 All year round, our strategy for 2013-2017 was crucial for our work and for our efforts to reform our institution.
In 2014, we shortened the average time needed to prepare our special reports and reduced the number of our employees in line with the requirements of the Interinstitutional Agreement.
We have also put measures in place to improve efficiency and effectiveness in the future by introducing an internal reform project.
The project will coordinate the implementation of the recommendations of the internal working groups and the recommendations of the independent external peer review of our economic evaluation and of the European Parliament report on the future role of the Court.
The Court is based in Luxembourg, but our teams, as part of their work to obtain proof of control, travel where EU funds are spent.
This activity report shall include an overview of the inspection visits and the reports we are preparing.
Particular emphasis will be placed on our assessment of EU support for European airport infrastructure.
This is an example of our performance audits in order to assess the impact and added value of EU funding and shows what efforts the Court needs to make in order to carry out its mission.
Furthermore, this audit demonstrates the commitment and professionalism of the members of the Court, on which the Court and its citizens, in their interest, can always leave.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira

The College of Members - Vítor Caldeira, elected for the third period of three years - once again as President of the Court and appointed Ville Itälä as the member responsible for institutional relations. • The Court's 2013-2017 strategy stimulated changes in the organisation: the Court introduced an internal reform project aimed at improving the control process and ensuring a more flexible organisation of resources. • Further improving administrative efficiency, based on simplification of procedures and the transfer of staff in support services to the control department.

Our activities 07 Audit reports and other products The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: • Annual reports are: • Annual reports of checks and checks on compliance with the European Union budget and the European Development Fund (EDF).
This includes special annual reports on agencies, decentralised agencies and EU Joint Undertakings. • Special reports, which may be published at any time during the year, together with the results of the audits of the agencies, decentralised agencies and EU Joint Undertakings selected by them in specific budgetary areas or management issues.
These are mainly economic audits. • Opinions on new or amended acts affecting financial financing and other products based on an analysis made at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative.
In 2014, the Court developed more products than ever before and presented new products.
Numerous analytical information is still available as part of the annual evaluation as well as extensive information on the results of our annual audits on accounting and compliance audits.
In 2014, more emphasis was placed on cost-efficiency audits, so that EU budgetary authorities received additional information on the quality of EU budget implementation.
In addition to the annual reports, for the first time, we have published a summary of our audit results for agricultural and cohesion expenditure, which are subject to shared management in the period 2009-2013, in order to ensure a multi-annual perspective.
Their important development was a new product called Landscape analysis.
The Landscape analysis will provide information and analysis on key issues based on our audit expertise.
In 2014, we published two Landscape analyses: the first one focuses on the main challenges facing the EU, taking into account public responsibility and control, and the second one focuses on the risks related to EU financial management.

Our activities 08 Audit visits in 2014. While most of the examination work is in our premises in Luxembourg, our auditors also carry out inspection visits to the authorities of the Member States, to other beneficiaries of EU funds (including the headquarters of international organisations such as the World Health Organisation in Switzerland) and to EU agencies and agencies.
The purpose of these visits is to obtain direct proof of control from the bodies involved in the approval, management and payment of EU funds and from the relevant final beneficiaries.
Our teams of controllers usually consist of two to three controllers, and the duration of the verification visit is several days to two weeks, depending on the type of exam and the distance.
In the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in consultation with the highest audit authorities in the Member States visited.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in each Member State and in the beneficiary countries depends on the type of control and the results of the selection of the sample.
The number and duration of inspection visits may therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
In 2014, the Court's auditors spent 4,915 days on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU and obtained evidence that annual reports and selected audit tasks (annual reports).
They also spent a lot of time in the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg and in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU.
In 2014, our auditors used less days on on-the-spot checks than in previous years.
This is due to more effective working procedures and the increasing use of technologies such as video conferencing.
EU inspectors used EU controllers to control maritime transport equipment.

Our actions 10 Annual Implementation Report for the EU budget for the financial year 2013 Most of the audits carried out by the Court in 2014 were devoted to the implementation of the EU budget for 2013.
The 2013 annual report, which was produced as a result of this work, was published on 5 November 2014 and presented to our addressees, including the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU (Council of Ecofin and Financial Financial) and the European Parliament and governments, as well as to the media.
The annual report aims to assist the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in assessing the quality of the EU's financial management through the presentation of findings and conclusions.
The 20th Annual Statement of Assurance (2013) on the reliability of the EU accounts and the regularity of the underlying transactions is the main element of the 2013 Annual Report.
This report contains even more information on the cost-effectiveness of EU spending and on the Commission's report on the results.
Estimated error rate in the EU budget: 4.7% at the time of the 2013 annual report to the President of the European Parliament Martin Schulz.
Our actions 11 Key conclusions in the 2013 Annual Report The EU Court delivered an opinion on the reliability of the European Union accounts for 2013.
The 2013 revenue was generally legal and regular, including with respect to commitments. ο Payments for 2013 were to a large extent burdened with errors.
The Court therefore issued an incomplete opinion on legality and regularity.
This figure is close to the 2012 error rate (4,8%) and is constantly above the materiality threshold of 2%. ο The most defective of these two expenditure areas were: regional policy, transport and energy, with an estimated error rate of 6,9% and rural development, the environment, fisheries and health, with an estimated error rate of 6,7%.
The total estimated level of error in shared management was 5.2%. ο Overall, the level of regularity of payments in the Member States was partly effective with significant divergences between Member States in the analysis of supervisory and control systems.
As in 2012, in the case of a large proportion of the errors in shared management areas, Member States' authorities had sufficient information to detect and correct errors before submitting a proposal to the Commission. ο Recovery and recovery of funds by Member States' authorities and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Without these measures, the estimated overall return on investment would be 6.3%. ο Using EU funds for the 2007-2013 programming period meant absorption (use it or lose it in case of non-use) and compliance and not good results.
This lack of focus on results is a key weakness in the way a large part of the EU budget is built.

Our actions 13 Agriculture and cohesion: the review of EU expenditure in 2007-2013 for the first time, in parallel with the annual reports in the 23 official EU languages, the Court has published a document in order to provide a multi-annual perspective on the expenditure on which the statement of assurance is based in two main areas of expenditure: agriculture and cohesion.
He drew conclusions on the problems with EU financial management and control over the last spending period, summarised the results of the audit and presented the challenges of the new spending period 2014-2020.
In addition, in this context, the European Parliament has expressed its wish for information on shared management in the various countries. ο Main assumptions: ο With the exception of direct aid and market support for farmers in the agricultural sector, the pressure on the use of funds is a key aspect of the risk associated with expenditure under shared management. ο The main risks to the regularity of agricultural expenditure are that the areas, animals or costs on which aid payments are based are not eligible, the beneficiaries of the aid do not fulfil the conditions and are not fully calculated.
Infringements of agri-environment requirements, specific requirements for investment projects and public procurement rules are important factors for increasing the risk of rural development expenditure. ο The greatest risks associated with cohesion expenditure are cases of breaches of EU or national public procurement rules.

Our actions 14 The 2013 Annual Report on the European Development Fund (EDF) is funded by the EU Member States and is managed outside the EU general budget.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of actions financed by the EFF.
Within the framework of the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and with the Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs) under the Cotonou Agreement of 2000.
Expenditure is aimed at reducing poverty and reducing it at the end, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of ACP and OCT countries into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars: development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2013 Annual Report on the EDF was published on 5 November 2014 as an annual report on the EU budget.
It contains the 20th EDF Statement of Assurance.
The Court found that the 2013 annual accounts constitute the appropriate financial and financial situation of the EDF, the results of its operations and cash flows and the change of net assets as a whole.
The Court estimated the error rate for EDF expenditure for the financial year 2013 at 3,4%, an increase of 3,0% compared to 2012.
Specific annual reports for the financial year 2013 In 2014, the Court prepared and published 51 annual reports for the financial year 2013.
The reports concerned 41 decentralised EU institutions, executive agencies and agencies, seven EU Joint Undertakings active in research and the European Central Bank, European Schools and communication infrastructure Sisnet.
The Court also published two reports summing up the results of its annual audits for the financial year 2013, one of the EU agencies and other bodies, the other of the joint undertakings active in the field of research.
These two summaries of analysis and comparisons were submitted to the President of the European Parliament, the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
Together with the specific annual reports, these reports are available on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu).
EU agencies, bodies and joint undertakings are prepared on the basis of EU legislation to carry out specific tasks and are established throughout the European Union.
They operate in many areas such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and travel.
Each of them has one mandate, one board, one director, one staff and one budget.
While financial risks are relatively low for agencies, bodies and joint enterprises, for the entire EU budget, the reputation risk is high in the EU as they are clearly visible in the Member States and have a significant impact on policy-making, decision-making and programme implementation in areas that are crucial for European citizens.

Our actions 17 Smart and Inclusive Growth Smart and Inclusive Growth covers two areas: competitiveness for growth and jobs: research and innovation, education and training, trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, social policy, business development, etc., EU measures for growth and jobs for 2014-2020 amount to EUR 142 billion and 13% of the EU's total budget respectively.
Economic, social and territorial cohesion includes regional policy aimed at helping the least developed EU countries and regions to establish contacts with other regions, with a view to strengthening the competitiveness of all regions and developing cooperation between them.
The EU's cohesion funding for 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 367 billion and 34% of the EU budget at current prices respectively.
In 2014, the Court drew up the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of EU-funded public transport projects (No 1/2014) In this special report, the Court assessed the implementation and effectiveness of public transport projects co-financed by the EU Structural Funds in order to determine whether the projects met the needs of users and achieved their objectives.
The audit showed that two thirds of the projects in the field of transport co-financed by the EU Structural Funds have not been sufficiently used.
This development was mainly due to shortcomings in the project concept and insufficient mobility policy.
However, these insufficient results were generally not monitored by project promoters or by national authorities.
Most projects were based on infrastructure and vehicle structures according to project specifications.
Significant delays and excess costs were found, but almost all the projects audited were in line with the needs of the users.
European cities must increase mobility and reduce congestion, accidents and pollution through local mobility strategies.
As part of the co-financed projects, the city received support in the development of urban transport systems such as metro, trams and buses.
Trams and buses are important means of public transport.
Our actions 18 • Have cohesion policy funds for renewable energy production produced good results?
(6/2014 No) in this special report, the Court examined whether good results were achieved in this period from two main sources of funding to promote renewable energy sources under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (FS) in order to check whether these funds had been adequately prioritised, cost-effective and mature in renewable energy production projects, in order to achieve meaningful objectives, and to what extent these funds had achieved good results in order to achieve the EU 2020 renewable energy target.
The audit concluded that improvements were needed to ensure that EU funding could contribute as much as possible to this objective.
The projects audited provided results according to the plan and most of the projects were well-developed and ready to be implemented at the time of selection.
No significant cost overruns or delays were observed and the production capacity of renewable energy was installed as planned and launched as planned.
However, energy production results have not always been achieved or have not been properly measured.
The total effectiveness of the use of funds was limited as cost-effectiveness in project planning and implementation was not a guiding principle and expenditure had limited added value in the EU.
The EU Council has set a binding EU target of 20% of the share of renewable energy in gross final energy consumption by 2020.

(No (In this special report, the Court examined whether the funders co-financed by the ERDF successfully supported start-ups with high growth potential.
The audit concluded that the EU made a significant financial contribution to the creation of incubator centres infrastructure, in particular in Member States where such support to businesses is relatively rare.
However, the results of the founders' centres examined were not sufficient.
In view of the financial constraints and the limited scope of the business start-up activities, the provision of business-related services was rather limited.
This situation was mainly due to the lack of expertise in seed support procedures and the shortcomings in management systems.
Founding centres aim to support new businesses in their creation and further development.
Support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has become an increasingly political priority over time.
