Our actions 19 • Is the ERDF effective in financing projects aimed at the direct promotion of biodiversity in the framework of the EU Biodiversity Strategy 2020?
(No 12/2014) In this special report, the Court examined whether the ERDF funds available for direct support for biodiversity were used by the Member States.
The audit showed that Member States are lagging behind using ERDF resources to finance projects compared to other areas of ERDF expenditure.
In order for the ERDF to continue to be a useful tool for the implementation of the EU Strategy to reduce biodiversity loss by 2020, the Commission should further support Member States in the implementation of specific conservation and management plans for habitats and natural species.
Projects co-financed were broadly in line with biodiversity priorities at national and EU level.
However, the assessment of the effectiveness of these projects has been undermined by the fact that most Member States have not added performance indicators or monitoring systems to assess the development of natural habitats and species.
The protection of biodiversity is one of the EU's key priorities.
After the 2010 target of reducing the loss of biodiversity in Europe had not been reached, the Council approved a new strategy by 2020, in which direct support for biodiversity and nature conservation for the 2007-2013 programming period was earmarked for ERDF support of EUR 2.8 billion. • Has the ERDF support for SMEs in the e-commerce sector been effective?
(No 20/2014) In this special report, the Court assesses whether operational programmes provide a good basis for effective support for e-commerce activities for SMEs, whether the managing authorities have correctly selected and monitored e-commerce projects, and whether projects co-financed by the ERDF have been successfully implemented and provide tangible benefits.
The Court found that ERDF support for SMEs in the e-commerce sector supported the purchase and sale of goods via the Internet in order to increase the availability of services to businesses on the Internet.
However, due to the lack of monitoring, it was impossible to assess the extent to which ERDF support contributed to the achievement of the IT objectives of the Member States and the EU.
Insufficient procedures for the selection of Member States lead to an apparent error in the cost/benefit ratio for many projects.
The programme managers focused more on the use of resources (outputs) than on the achievement of results.

Our actions 20 Approaching economic control: EU-funded airport infrastructure: no cost/benefit ratio (No 21/2014) Closed part of the oversized terminal at Fuerteventura airport.
While EU aviation policy aims to address capacity problems in the EU to build additional infrastructure, to make better use of existing structures, to optimise airport services and to better connect with other modes of transport in Europe, it will not be able to meet much of this demand due to the lack of airport and ground infrastructure.
There are more than 500 airports in Europe, with more than one million employees directly or indirectly employed, and more than EUR 140 billion, together with airlines, contribute to Europe's economic performance.
Airport infrastructure projects are an important area of expenditure in the EU budget: in the period 2000-2013, around €4.5 billion was allocated to EU projects of this type, of which over €2.8 billion was allocated to cohesion policy funds.
As part of the economic control of this support, the Court examined whether the investments were properly needed, whether the time and cost framework were respected in the framework of the construction projects and whether the newly built or upgraded infrastructure was fully used.
The Court assessed whether the investments led to an increase in the number of passengers and improved after-sales services and whether the supported airports were financially stable.
The auditors carried out their work between May 2013 and October 2014, in particular in respect of 20 airports in Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and Spain financed by EU funds.
In total, over EUR 600 million of the EU was allocated to these airports between 2000 and 2013.
The team reviewed the relevant legislation, air traffic planning in five Member States and the publication of the main interbranch organisations.
In particular, the auditors visited 20 airports to assess the results, use, results and effects, as well as the economic situation of airports, as well as to obtain direct evidence that they come from EU funds.
The Court found that the cost-benefit ratio for EU-funded investments at airports was not consistent.
Too many airports, often close to each other, have received financial support for similar infrastructures, and in many cases, the infrastructure has become too extensive.
Only half of the airports audited managed to increase the number of passengers.
No measurement of the improvement in customer service or regional socio-economic benefits such as the creation of additional jobs has been made or no evidence has been provided.
The Commission therefore concludes that the Commission concludes that, since the airport in Lubeca is located at the same airport in Lubeca, the airport in Lubeca is not located at the same airport in the same area as the airport in Lubeca, in which the airport in Lubeca is located in the area where the airport in Lubeca is located in the area where the airport in Lubeca is located in the area where the airport in Lubeca is located in the area where the airport in Lubeca is not located in the same area as the airport in Lubece is located in the area in which the airport in Lubece is located.
For most airports, the audit team noted significant delays in the construction and construction of the infrastructure.
For almost half of airports, costs were exceeded, which means that Member States had to pay almost EUR 100 million more of their national budgets than originally planned.
Our actions 21 Funding was not well coordinated by the Member States: in most countries there was no strategic long-term airport development plan.
The Commission also did not fully monitor the financing which is not known at all to airports which receive or are concerned by the financing.
In this way, it will not have a full picture of all EU investments in airports and will have limited opportunities to ensure monitoring and to ensure that the strategy is properly developed and implemented.
On the basis of these findings, the Court recommended to the Commission that, from the 2014-2020 programming period, Member States should apply EU measures only to airport infrastructure that is financially viable and the investment needs of which have been adequately assessed and demonstrated.
Another recommendation was that Member States should have coherent airport development plans at regional, national and transnational level, in order to avoid excessive capacity, duplication and uncoordinated investments in airport infrastructure.
In its reply, the Commission ensured that lessons were learned from these experiences.
The Commission has therefore ensured that a different approach will be applied substantially in the relevant provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period.
The report was presented to the European Parliament, which fully supports the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The publication of the report was of great interest to the media.
The media response was greatest in Spain, but it also included headlines in major international newspapers, television broadcasts and social media.

Our actions 22 Sustainable growth: EU natural resources are politically responsible for agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2014-2020 is EUR 420 billion and 39% of the EU budget at current prices.
Three quarters of the expenditure concerns direct payments to farmers and support the agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF) through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF) through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EGF) through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EGF) the strongest pillar of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
The next fifth part of the expenditure concerns EU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second pillar of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development shall be managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2014, the Court drew up the following special reports in this area: • Inclusion of EU water policy objectives in the CAP: partial achievement (No 4/2014) in this special report The Court assessed whether the objectives of EU water policy were successfully integrated into the common agricultural policy (CAP).
The audit showed that the EU can only partially achieve the objectives of water policy within the CAP.
Two instruments for integrating water-related issues (respect for cross-compliance and rural development) are insufficient and the implementation of the Water Framework Directive is characterised by fluctuations and weaknesses.
The CAP instruments have so far had a positive impact on supporting policy objectives to improve water quantity and quality.
However, these instruments are limited compared to the ambitious objectives of the CAP.
For example, none of these two instruments allows the "polluter pays" principle to be fully applied to CAP spending.
Moreover, at the level of the EU institutions and Member States, there is insufficient knowledge of and the development of the burden of water resources arising from agricultural activities.
The EU attaches great importance to the protection of European water resources.
Agriculture, one of the largest consumers and polluting water resources, plays a key role in sustainable water management.
The CAP allocates almost 40% of the EU budget (over EUR 50 billion for 2014) and the EU CAP seeks to influence agricultural procedures affecting water resources.
Our actions 23 • Did the Commission effectively manage the integration of coupled support into the single payment scheme?
(No (8/2014)) In this special report, the Court assessed how well the Commission, following the 2008 CAP Health Check, incorporated EU production-related support (e.g. for the areas for which it was managed or for which it was for animals) into the single payment scheme into the single payment scheme.
The audit showed that the Commission did not adequately monitor over the period 2010-2012 how Member States calculated the payment entitlements of farmers under EU farm support under the single payment scheme.
Although most Member States have correctly used the reference data of farmers, there have been serious shortcomings in the correct application of the rules and calculation rules.
The Commission has not used its mandate to ensure that the criteria for the allocation of available support are always in line with EU rules, are in line with the principle of sound financial management and do not have a potential impact on market conditions.
Within the framework established by the Commission, it was not clear enough what checks should be carried out by the Member States and the Member States' control systems varied in quality, and the main objective of the single payment scheme was to shift the orientation of the CAP from market support to support non-productive income for farmers: farmers' owners should be able to adapt their production to market demand and their income should be balanced.
The single payment scheme introduced so far in 18 Member States accounts for 54% of the total EU budget for agriculture and rural development. • Is EU support for investment and promotion in the wine sector well managed and is there evidence that EU wine is competitive?
(9/2014 No) ) In its special report, the Court assessed whether investment and promotion activities had been adequately developed and examined the available monitoring and evaluation data to determine whether the Commission and the Member States had achieved the desired results effectively.
The audit concluded that the management of support for investment and promotion in the wine sector was affected by design and implementation defects and that the impact on the competitiveness of EU wines could not always be demonstrated.
Investment activities specifically targeted at the wine sector are not justified as support is already provided under the EU's rural development policy.
EU support for the promotion of wines has often served to consolidate existing markets rather than to create new or to recover old markets.
The impact of the investment action cannot be easily separated from the investment for rural development.
The EU is the world's largest wine producer.
EU support is aimed at increasing competitiveness and ensuring a better balance between supply and demand.
Between 2009 and 2013, Member States spent EUR 522 million on promotion and EUR 518 million on investment activities.
Between 2014 and 2018, the measures granted to the Member States under this measure increased significantly.
Our actions 24 • Effectiveness of aquaculture support (No 10/2014) from the European Fisheries Fund (EFF) of this special report The Court assessed whether aquaculture support actions were well designed and implemented at both EU and Member State level and whether the EFF achieved an appropriate cost-benefit ratio and whether sustainable development of aquaculture was supported.
The audit showed that by 2013 aquaculture support measures were not well developed and implemented at EU and Member State level, that the EFF did not provide an adequate cost/benefit ratio and did not provide effective support for the sustainable development of aquaculture.
The current framework was not adequate to achieve the EU's objectives for the sustainable development of aquaculture and the results were insufficient.
Actions to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Member States have not been well designed and implemented.
The Member States' national strategic plans and operational programmes were not clear enough and Member States did not have a coherent strategy for this sector.
In many cases, EDF funds were not adequately targeted for aquaculture projects, and the audit showed that these projects were not generally either the expected results or the good results in terms of costs and benefits.
Every year aquaculture produces 1.3 million tonnes of fish in the EU, with a turnover of EUR 4 billion.
One of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) for the period up to 2013 was to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture.
By May 2013, more than €400 million were earmarked under the EFF to finance productive investment and environmental and health measures in aquaculture. • Economic economy: the EFF maintained control of the cost of EU funding for rural development projects (No 22/2014) in this Special Report, the Court examined whether the approach taken by the Commission and the Member States was the most effective in controlling the costs of rural development aid.
The audit showed that EU Member States could achieve significant savings in aid for rural development projects while at the same time achieving a more efficient use of resources.
Auditors have identified feasible and cost-effective approaches that could be applied more widely to Member States' control of the costs of rural development aid.
The Member States' control systems were intended to control the prices of the goods or works referred to in the aid applications without having to pay equal attention to whether the same goods were measured.
Some price controls were time-consuming or did not provide sufficient assurance that the approved costs were appropriate.
At the beginning of the programming period, the Commission did not provide sufficient guidance or ensure the dissemination of inadequate procedures.
It did not ensure the effectiveness of Member States' systems before the aid was granted on a large scale.
About half of the EU's rural development expenditure of EUR 100 billion for the period 2007-2013 was implemented in the form of grants for investment projects and other projects implemented by farmers, agricultural enterprises, associations and local authorities.
Our actions 25 • Errors in rural development expenditure: What are the causes and actions for removing them?
(No 23/2014) In this special report, the Court examined the compliance with existing legislation and other legislation on the implementation of rural development and identified the main reasons for the high level of error in this area.
The audit showed that most of the errors in rural development policy are due to a breach of the conditions laid down at Member State level.
Member States' control authorities could and should have detected and corrected most of the errors in rural development investment activities.
Member States' control systems are insufficient as controls are not exhaustive and are based on insufficient information.
The average error rate in rural development expenditure over the last three years was 8.2%.
The errors in the investment activities represented two thirds of the error rate and the area aid represented one third of the error rate.
Only 16 percent of errors were due to non-compliance directly with EU regulations, while most were due to non-compliance with the conditions set at Member State level.
During the 2007-2013 programming period, the EU and the Member States have allocated more than EUR 150 billion to rural development policy, which has been used in almost equal parts for investment and area aid.
• Is EU aid to prevent and mitigate forest damage due to natural disasters and natural disasters well managed?
(No 24/2014) In this special report, the Court assessed whether the support measures of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) for forest recovery and the introduction of prevention measures (measure 226) had been well managed and whether the Commission and the Member States could demonstrate that the objectives of the aid had been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
The audit showed that EU funding to prevent forest fires and rebuild forests affected by natural disasters and fires has not been properly managed.
The Commission and the Member States are not fully aware that the intended funding results have been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
Over the past 30 years, fires in the EU have destroyed on average 480,000 hectares of forest in the last 30 years.
Preventive actions accounted for more than 80% of EU funds of €1.5 million for the period 2007-2013.
Our actions 26 Security and citizenship This policy area has been established to ensure the free movement of persons and to ensure a high level of protection for citizens.
It covers from the management of the EU's external borders to judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters, as well as asylum and immigration policy, police cooperation and the fight against crime.
Expenditure in this area is expected to reach EUR 18 million in 2014-2020 or less than 2% of the total budget.
In 2014, the Court drew up the following special reports in this area: • Conclusions from the development by the European Commission (No 3/2014) of the SIS II Information System (SIS II) In this special report, the Court examined why the Commission, more than six years later than planned, provided SIS II with eight times the costs initially foreseen.
It was examined whether there was a stable business principle throughout the duration of the project in SIS II which took into account significant changes in costs and expected benefits.
The audit concluded that delays and excessive costs were caused by shortcomings in the Commission's management.
The original deadline was unrealistic and the Commission was not able to effectively manage the main development order before 2009.
The actual level of investment needed was clearly underestimated in the initial cost estimates.
The total cost of SIS II amounted to EUR 189 million, which initially corresponds to the estimated amount of EUR 23 million.
The Commission has not fully demonstrated that SIS II provides its best cost/cost ratio.
However, the Commission has learned lessons from the first stage of the project and has already used them for other major IT projects.
The Schengen Information System is used by border, police, customs, visa and judicial authorities throughout the Schengen area.
It shall contain information (s) concerning persons potentially involved in a serious crime or persons who do not have the right to enter or stay in the EU.
• The External Borders Fund has contributed to increasing financial solidarity, but the evaluation of results needs to be improved and added value for the EU (No 15/2014) • In this special report, the Court assessed the effectiveness and added value of the EU for the External Borders Fund and assessed to what extent the objectives of the co-financed projects and programmes have been achieved.
The audit showed that the External Borders Fund contributed to the management of the EU's external borders and to increased financial solidarity between Member States.
However, its added value for the EU was limited and the results could not be measured due to shortcomings in monitoring by the competent authorities and serious shortcomings in the evaluations at the level of the Commission and at the level of the Member States.
Member States' programmes were not integrated into national border control strategies and visas and did not contain SMART objectives or measurable indicators.
The project selection procedures have not ensured that the real needs of the Member States are met.
Unsatisfactory procurement procedures in the Member States pose a risk to the cost-effectiveness of household management.
There are four shortcomings in the management of the Fund in the Member States concerned (Greece, Spain, Italy and Malta, as well as in the first years of financing).
As the EU's main financial instrument to support the protection of external borders, the External Borders Fund for the period 2007-2013 was provided with EUR 1.9 billion.
Its overarching objective was to support the current and future Schengen countries in ensuring uniform, effective and effective controls at their common external borders.
Our actions 27 Europe in the world The EU's external relations actions aim to: to expand, to ensure stability, security and prosperity in the neighbourhood, to actively promote sustainable development at international level, to promote global political governance and to ensure strategic and civil security.
In the period 2014-2020, the EU allocated EUR 66 billion and 6 percent of the planned expenditure respectively.
The Commission shall manage expenditure, mainly directly through its central services or delegations.
In 2014, the Court drew up the following special reports in this area: • the establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) (EEAS) (No 11/2014) in this special report, the Court examined whether the establishment of the EEAS had been properly prepared, whether its resources had been effectively prioritised, organised and allocated, and whether it had effectively cooperated with the Commission and the Member States.
The audit concluded that the EEAS should increase its efficiency and efforts for the EU and its citizens.
The establishment of the EEAS was premature and was not well prepared.
The lack of priorities, organisation and allocation of resources has led to a weakening of its effectiveness.
Coordination between the EEAS and the Commission was only partially effective, mainly due to the lack of effective coordination mechanisms and the rigid financial and administrative framework at the level of the Delegate.
Coordination with Member States may continue to be strengthened to exploit synergies in the exchange of information or shared accommodation and to improve consular services, including the protection of EU citizens.
The EEAS has its headquarters in Brussels and has a network of 140 delegations worldwide.
In 2014, the EEAS had a budget of EUR 519 million, divided between headquarters (41%) and delegations (59%). • EU aid for rehabilitation after the earthquake in Haiti (No 13/2014) In this special report, the Court examined whether EU aid for rehabilitation, EU aid for rehabilitation in Haiti was well designed and implemented, and whether the Commission ensured a proper link between emergency aid and rehabilitation and development.
The audit concluded that EU aid for rehabilitation after the 2010 Haiti earthquake was well designed and targeted at the country's priorities, but that the programmes were not sufficiently implemented and that emergency aid, rehabilitation and development were not sufficiently linked.
Most of the programmes audited have delivered the products according to the timetable or have been delayed in almost all programmes.
Although the Commission was aware of the difficult situation, it was not sufficiently aware of some of the significant risks that threaten the achievement and achievement of the objectives of the programme.
The programmes have been monitored but the Commission and the EEAS have not taken timely action to increase the resources of the EU Delegation to Haiti.
In March 2010, 55 donors granted USD 5.4 billion for the period 2010-2012 for rehabilitation and development and another USD 3.0 billion for 2013 and subsequent years.
The EU was one of the most important donors, one of which was EUR 1.2 billion.
Our actions 28 • The effectiveness of combining financial instruments from regional investment instruments with loans from financial institutions (mixed financing) supporting EU foreign policy (No 16/2014) • In this special report, the Court has dealt with the creation and management of investment instruments and wondered whether the combined financing has benefited from the intended benefits.
As part of the audit, although the mixed financing judgment, i.e. the combination of financial assistance from regional investment instruments with loans from financial institutions to support the EU's external policy, was positive in terms of structure and overall effectiveness, the Court also draws attention to a number of key issues that need to be addressed urgently.
Although these instruments were well developed, the potential benefits of the combined funding were not fully absorbed due to shortcomings in the Commission's management of these instruments.
Almost half of the projects examined did not have sufficient evidence that the grants were justified.
In some cases, investments would probably be made without an EU contribution.
The Commission should ensure that the allocation is based on an accurate and documented distribution of added value in relation to the achievement of the EU's development, neighbourhood and enlargement policy objectives.
Since 2007, the Commission has created eight regional investment instruments.
They combine EFF and EU general budget grants with loans mainly from European financial institutions for development.
• Can the EU's initiative on centres of excellence effectively contribute to reducing chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) threats from outside the EU?
(No 1) No ) In this special report, the Court assessed whether the initiative was based on a sound analysis of the situation prior to 2010, whether the organisational structure of the initiative was appropriate to address the identified challenges and whether there was an appropriate governance system and whether it was applied.
In the context of the audit, the Court generally welcomed the contribution of centres of excellence to the reduction of the risk associated with CBRN.
This initiative is in line with the priorities set out in the European Security Strategy and the EU Strategy against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
It envisages the involvement of all stakeholders in partner countries in order to improve the sustainability of the actions undertaken.
The organisational structure is generally appropriate, but its complexity has contributed to the delay in starting the business.
The Centres of Excellence initiative aims to create regional platforms in different regions of the world to address the risks of CBRNs.
This is the largest single measure under the long-term component of the Instrument for Stability and a budget of EUR 100 million is made available for the period 2010-2013.
Our actions 29 • Within EuropeAid • Results oriented Monitoring (Rome) systems (No 11/2014) In this special report, the Court examined whether these systems are reliable, whether their structure and resources are adequate and whether they ensure adequate and reasonable arrangements, and whether they are most favourable from the findings.
In the framework of the audit, the Court made a critical assessment of the reliability of these systems.
The bodies responsible for evaluation and performance-based monitoring are well organised, but more attention should be paid to the efficient use of resources.
These systems do not provide sufficient information on the results obtained and do not ensure the greatest possible use of the findings.
The evaluations of projects and programmes organised by Commission delegations and carried out in partner countries are not satisfactorily managed: overall monitoring is inadequate, is unclear on the extent of the resources used and does not have access to the results.
The two main elements of the European Commission's European Commission's European Commission's Commission's Commission's European Development and Cooperation DG (EuropeAid) accounting framework are their performance-based evaluation and monitoring systems.
The total annual cost of the schemes is estimated at EUR 34-38 million.
The annual development expenditure covered by these schemes is estimated at around EUR 8 billion. • EU pre-accession assistance to Serbia (No 19/2014) The Court examined in this special report whether the Commission managed pre-accession assistance to Serbia effectively in the period 2007-2013.
Together with other forms of support, the measures of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) have contributed to Serbia's social and economic reforms and to improving public finance management.
On the basis of the experience gained with other IPA beneficiary countries, the Commission is increasingly focusing on management issues with regard to the planning of financial and non-financial assistance to Serbia.
The Commission has effectively managed non-financial assistance to Serbia in the management and fight against corruption.
With regard to Serbia's preparations for managing EU funds, the Commission has also provided effective support, but only to a limited extent, for IPA management structures.
One quarter of IPA funding for Serbia has been allocated to governance, which, according to the Commission, is the biggest challenge for the country.
The EU complements IPA funding through a number of non-financial measures to help Serbia prepare for EU membership.
Our activities 30 Management Administrative expenditure of EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (personal and pension) and on buildings, equipment, energy, communication and information technologies.
The planned budget for 2014-2020 is for current prices of EUR 70 million, or 6% of the total EU budget.
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report: • How to calculate, reduce and compensate for greenhouse gas emissions by EU institutions and bodies?
(No 14/2014) In this special report, the Court assessed whether EU institutions and bodies had strategies to reduce the environmental impact of their administrative activities and whether these strategies had been effectively implemented.
In the report, the Court called on the EU institutions and institutions to develop a common policy approach to reducing greenhouse gas emissions (CO2 fingerprints).
The introduction of the environmental management and audit system is slow and the information available on the actual emissions is insufficient.
Few institutions and bodies systematically use environmental contracts.
While EU institutions and bodies have managed to reverse the upward trend in energy-related greenhouse gas emissions in their buildings, the available data do not indicate that other sources of emissions, such as business trips, have a clear tendency to reduce emissions.
More than half of the EU institutions and bodies audited have not set any quantitative targets for reducing emissions.
EU environmental policy aims to achieve a high level of protection.
The Treaty (TFEU) requires that environmental requirements be taken into account in the definition and implementation of Union policies and actions in order to promote sustainable development.
Our actions 31 Revenue/own resources are EU revenue to finance expenditure.
There are three types of own resources: traditional own resources (customs collected outside the EU and sugar production levies), VAT-based own resources and GNI-based own resources (the largest revenue source in the EU budget).
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report: • Are preferential trade schemes managed in a proportionate manner?
(No 2/2014) in the report, the Court assessed whether the Commission had properly assessed the economic effects of the preferential trade arrangements and whether the checks effectively ensured that imports could not be subject to the wrong preferential tariff rates as a result of the loss of EU revenue.
The audit showed that although the Commission has improved the quality of the impact assessments over time, it has still not sufficiently analysed the economic impact of the preferential trade systems.
The EU is losing revenue due to shortcomings in customs controls in the Member States: these controls do not prevent the introduction of unfair and preferential import duties in certain cases.
The EU grants preference under unilateral preferential agreements to ensure that developing countries have duty-free access to the EU market, thereby contributing to the eradication of poverty and the promotion of sustainable development.
In 2011, the value of products imported into the EU under preferential trade arrangements exceeded EUR 242 billion, representing 14% of imports into the EU.
Our actions 32 Financial and economic governance The economic governance framework of the European Union is designed to prevent or detect and correct problematic economic developments, such as excessive deficits or debt, which may hamper economic growth and put the sustainability of public finances at risk.
In 2014, the Court adopted the first special report in this field: • the European Central Bank (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB) (ECB)
The audit showed that the Commission's regulatory reform of the banking sector and the creation of EBA were the first important responses to the financial crisis.
EBA has laid the foundations for a new system of regulation and supervision for the banking sector.
The identified shortcomings concerned cross-border banking supervision, assessment of the resilience of EU banks and the promotion of consumer protection.
In view of the stress tests carried out in 2011, which were carried out at EU level without definitive funding, EBA had a limited legal mandate and limited human resources.
Although the stress test led to the recapitalisation of many banks in 2011, it proved that such stress tests are limited if they are not linked to the assessment of the quality of the total assets.
Questions remain concerning the future role of EBA in banking supervision and the role and responsibilities of EBA and the ECB.
As a result of the financial crisis, the Commission has taken steps to stabilise the banking sector to strengthen the regulatory framework and banking supervision, in particular in the case of banks operating across borders.
EBA was established in 2011 in the framework of the detailed proposals for regulatory changes.
EBA plays a role in the supervision of European banking rules and in the protection of consumers.

Our actions 35 Lukes, overlap and challenges: an analysis of the EU's public responsibility and control system The aim of this analysis is to realise and encourage control of the EU's democratic legitimacy of the institutional system.
It describes the basic features of the accountability framework, the role of public financial control, the key elements of a robust chain of responsibility and financial control, and the six important areas in which accountability and financial control challenges are at EU level, as well as the principles of accountability and financial control in relation to the various new EU and intergovernmental instruments developed in response to the financial crisis.
Optimum use of EU funds: risk analysis for EU financial management At a time when governments and taxpayers of the Member States want the funds they provide to provide greater benefits, the analysis summarises the Court's observations on all aspects of EU financial management.
Based on the Court's 35-year experience in the control of EU revenue and expenditure, the analysis presents an overview of the EU's financial management and a summary of the issues to be addressed in order to ensure a better cost-benefit ratio to the EU budget.
This analysis will be complemented by detailed data on the main characteristics and themes of the various areas of revenue and expenditure and proposals for improvement.
Our actions 36 The analysis identifies a number of key issues that deserve particular attention: ο overly complex eligibility schemes and other EU support conditions that hinder their understanding, management and control and lead to different interpretations; ο public procurement rules and procedures that are not always respected; they are not always respected; they therefore lead to higher costs or delays in financing EU projects; ο insufficient capacity of national authorities to manage and pay EU funds, which increases the risk of errors and the risk of poor quality of expenditure; ο insufficient coordination of the EU budget and national budgets, lack of funds to co-finance Member States and greater emphasis on compliance with the principles that result; ο high levels of commitments from the previous expenditure period that still require financing from the EU budget.

The strategy for international cooperation The Court's cooperation strategy aims to contribute as fully as possible to the EU's public responsibility, in particular by strengthening bilateral and multilateral cooperation with relevant partners, such as national supreme audit bodies and international audit organisations, in line with the Court's overall strategy for 2013-2017.
Given that the Court's audit responsibilities include areas that have pan-European (e.g. financial management) and global (e.g. climate change), our international cooperation activities are even more important than in the past.
As part of its cooperation strategy, the Court has the following priorities: ο Cooperation at EU level within the Contact Committee and individual cooperation with the EU Member States' CoRs will continue to be the main priorities.

High-level conference on improving accountability in the EU From left to right: Jacques Sciberras, Head of Cabinet, Kevin Cardiff, Member of the Court, Vítor Caldeira and Vice-President Olli Rehn.
In October 2014, the Court organised a high-level conference, to which many persons were invited to ensure that the European Union fulfils its public responsibility to achieve its objectives.
The conference focused on gaps, overruns and challenges at EU and Member State level, which were identified in the Court's analysis on EU legislation on public responsibility and control (see page 35).
The Conference has enabled discussion between participants, including members or representatives of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court, the European Central Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Stability Mechanism, national clearing and learning tribunals, in order to discuss how these principles should be developed in response to the development of economic, budgetary and monetary integration.
The EU has focused on accountability, particularly with regard to central banks and supervisors, crisis and post-crisis structures, increasing leverage with regard to EU assistance through participation of third parties and focusing on EU performance.
The participants agreed that there was a need for closer cooperation between government bodies, parliaments and auditors at EU and Member State level, with a view to a better understanding of what EU policies and programmes are provided by society.
Our actions 43 Strengthening the partnership with the national authorities in Lithuania The high-level delegation of the Court visited Lithuania in September 2014 in order to strengthen the partnership with the parliament, the government, the central bank and the central bank in Lithuania and to support the best use and control of EU spending in the country.

Our management of the 44th College of the Court of Justice belongs to one member of each Member State.
Under the agreement, the term of office of the members of the Court shall be six years, renewable.
Members shall be assigned to one of the five chambers.
The Boards shall adopt audit reports and opinions and adopt decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member shall be responsible for his or her own tasks, which are primarily audit tasks.
The Court's auditors shall carry out the basic audit work and shall be coordinated by the relevant member, assisted by his office.
The member shall then accept the presentation of the report on the adoption by the Chamber and/or the entire College of the Court and the presentation by the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties, including the media.
In line with Member States' proposals and after consulting the European Parliament in 2014, the Council of the European Union appointed six new members of the European Court of Auditors.

Our management strategy 46 of the Court for 2013-2017: Progress was made in 2014 in the second year of the Court's implementation of the 2013-2017 strategy.
During this period, the Court's contribution to EU public responsibility should be maximised.
To achieve this objective, the Court has the following priorities: ο focus the Court's products on improving the accountability of the EU; ο work with other stakeholders to increase the Court's contribution to the accountability of the EU; ο develop the Court as a professional audit body; ο make the best use of the knowledge available by the Court as well as the expertise and expertise available to it; ο demonstrate that the Court is able to realise the Court's responsibility.
In 2014, the strategy initiated a major change in the Court's organisational structure.
Two internal working groups dealing with this strategy (including the improvement of the audit process with better definition of tasks and responsibilities) have presented their results.
Together with the European Parliament report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors and on the results of the peer review carried out by the Court.
The various recommendations were summarised in a comprehensive reform project which started at the end of 2014 and which will run until mid-2016.
In the case of special reports, this means that they are to be drawn up in a shorter period of time and, in the case of annual reports, they are intended to increase the concentration and saving of resources.
Secondly, the Court should be transformed into a task-based organisation.
This will enable it to make greater use of resources in order to focus more on controls and analyses that make the most of the added value for EU citizens.
Our management 47 The Court's performance measurement Since 2008 the Court has used central performance indicators (ZLIs) to inform the management of the progress of its objectives, to support the decision-making process and to inform the addressees of the results.
The CLIs reflect the Court's priorities and define its effectiveness and audit responsibilities as a professional audit body.
These indicators are used to measure the basic parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, with particular regard to the views of the main addressees and the effectiveness and effectiveness of its use of resources.
The ZLIs were updated for the period covered by the strategy for 2013-2017.

Another criterion of the evaluation shall be the actions taken in response to recommendations on the improvement of the EU's financial management.
Moreover, the Court measures its presence in the media.
The Court asked the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Committee on Budgets of the Council, the main bodies controlled by the Commission and the EU Agencies, as well as the EU-ORKB Presidents, to assess the usefulness and impact of its reports published in 2014, on a five-step scale from... very high to... very low.

Support for control activities Human resources Allocation of human resources In view of the difficult situation of public finances in Europe, the Court continued the reduction of human resources by 1% per year over the five-year period (2013-2017), in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of December 2013 on budgetary discipline and financial management.
Therefore, in 2014, from 891 to 882 temporary officials and temporary staff (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees) staff decreased.
A total of 561 posts are assigned to examination posts (including 113 staff in the members' office).
In 2014, in view of the objective of making the best use of resources, all actions re-identified and transposed the capacity to increase efficiency by simplifying procedures.
The relocation of staff from support staff to control services continued in 2014.
However, this compensated for the transfer of some support services from the members' offices to the administrative pool and the transfer of the Communication and Institutional Relations Department to the President's Departments.
51 Recruitment The Court's staff has a broad academic and professional context and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's findings.
The Court's recruitment policy is consistent with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions, and the EU institutions involve both officials and officials, as well as officials and temporary staff.
The internal selection procedure for grade AST 1 and the selection procedure for the employment of the Ombudsman were carried out in 2014.
In addition, the Court made 77 traineeships available for university graduates for a period of between three and five months per year.
In 2014, the Court had 78 staff: 31 officials, 29 temporary staff, 13 contract staff and five seconded national experts.
The number of job vacancies since 2011 is almost 3% (27 job vacancies on 31 December 2014).

Support for control activities 55 Vocational training support services In order to further develop the Court as a professional audit body and to make optimal use of the knowledge available to it and of the expertise and expertise available to it, continuous training of staff is necessary in order to keep up with professional development and to acquire new skills.
In 2014, the Court's staff (researchers and other staff) completed an average of eight days of vocational training.
The participation of language courses in vocational training continues to decrease.
In 2014, they accounted for 43% of the total number of training days (compared with 46% in 2013).
In order to make the best use of existing resources and technologies, the Court offers its staff, from 2014, tailored to the needs, e-learning courses and training in the form of integrated learning, in which participants participate in online training before the event.
In addition, presentations by internal and external experts on audit developments and other relevant areas have been further organised in order to exchange existing internal knowledge and transfer knowledge in order to provide the Court's auditors with the most modern knowledge on the development of public sector audits.
Translation is a work supporting controls, enabling the Court to carry out its mission and to achieve its communication objectives, which are to deliver results in the languages of EU citizens.
In 2014, total translation volume was 4 % higher than in 2013.
More than 98% of translations have been completed according to deadlines.
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate continued to participate directly in the Court's activities: translators provided linguistic support on 40 audit visits across the EU and in the preparation of audit reports.
In 2014, the Translation Directorate focused mainly on quality assurance.
To this end, the first quality assurance manual for translations was adopted and a system for quality translations for customers was developed.
In order to improve service efficiency, a review and optimisation of the translation process has been carried out and, in cooperation with the Directorate for Information Technology, the translation process has been automated.
Support for control activities 56 All processes related to the development and availability of tools have been carried out with safety and continuity: for example, in 2014 a comprehensive test to restart the new K3 building was carried out after the collapse of the IT systems (disaster recovery) and central IT components (e.g. the launch of the Court's e-mail system) have been upgraded.
The management and infrastructure of the Directorate for Finance and Support Services shall be designed to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and pursue its strategic objectives, and to ensure that the necessary control, internal control and audit mechanisms are available to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2014, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and more economical.
An environmental management system is currently being developed for the Court, which is in line with the principles of the Community environmental management and audit system (EMAS), to be approved by the end of 2016.
In 2014, a number of actions were successfully implemented which produced concrete results and showed the Court's commitment to environmental protection, including: • adoption of environmental policy; • carrying out environmental analysis and analysis of compliance with environmental legislation; • increasing the number of environmental awareness campaigns from four in 2013 to eight in 2014; • obtaining a BREEAM environmental certificate (the most important method for designing and evaluating sustainable buildings in the world) for building K3 and maintaining the mark of compliance with best practices in waste management; • promoting sustainable transport for workers by providing a new bicycle space with showers and changing rooms for cyclists, installing an electric car charger and booking parking spaces for bicycle groups.
Support for control activities 57 Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union.
The Court's budget accounts for approximately 0.093 per cent of the total EU expenditure and 1.58% of the total administrative expenditure.
In 2014, the total budget available was 98.8%, compared with 92% in 2013.
The higher execution rate is mainly due to better estimate and planning of expenditure under Title 1 in which the average execution rate was 98.8%.
For Title 2, the average performance rate was 98,4 %.

Support for control activities 59 Auditing and clearing The Court's internal audit The internal auditor shall advise the Court on matters relating to risk control by issuing opinions on the quality of management and control systems and recommendations to improve the conditions for the management of operations and the promotion of sound financial management.
The internal auditor shall also support the work of the external auditor responsible for certifying the Court's annual accounts.
The internal auditor informed the Court of the results of the audits carried out in 2014, the findings, recommendations and the follow-up to these recommendations.
The Court shall report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work.
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit was approved in accordance with the definition of internal audit, code of conduct and standards developed by the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA).
This certification was the result of a comprehensive assessment of the quality of the Court's internal audit, carried out at the request of the internal auditor and the Internal Audit Committee by an external expert, Deloitte SRL, and was in line with international standards in the field of internal audit practice in IIA.
The Court's external audit The Court's annual accounts shall be audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability that apply to the bodies that it has carried out.
The Auditor's Report: Pricewaterhouse - Coopers SRL: The Court of Auditors' Annual Report for the financial year 2013 was published on 18 September 2014.
The Court of Auditors' opinions in 2013 on the annual accounts: in our view, the annual accounts provide a true and fair view of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2013, of its results and cash flows at the end of that period, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Eura-Tom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and Commission Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules for the application of the Financial Regulation. on the use of resources and control procedures: in the work described in this report, we have not referred to the situation from which we have to conclude that, in all relevant matters and taking into account the above evaluation criteria, the resources allocated to the Court have not been used for this purpose and • in the control procedures established to ensure that the financial measures have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations.
Declaration by the 60th authorising officer by delegation, the undersigned Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors hereby declares that he is the authorising officer by delegation, • • - that the information contained in this report is correct and accurate and confirms with reasonable assurance that the appropriations made available for the activities described in this report have been used for the purposes of this report and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management and that the control procedures in place provide reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and to the proper management of fraud or fraud, costs and benefits of control.
This security shall be based on an assessment of the signed and available information, such as the reports and declarations of the authorising officers by sub-delegated, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's opinions on the previous financial years.

European Court of Auditors, President of EU Financing
The European Court of Auditors 02 Court of Auditors is an independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It has 28 members from each EU Member State and employs about 900 employees from all EU Member States in the field of audit and administration.
Since its establishment in 1977, the Court has advocated the improvement of EU financial management and the improvement of accounting.
The Court's tasks are to verify that EU funds have been correctly booked, that they have been used and used in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations and that they have been used optimally.
It warns against threats, provides security and guidance to policy makers in the EU, how to improve public finance management and ensure that European citizens know how their funds are used.
Through its control activities and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and stability of the European Union.

President's preamble 04 Dear Reader, in 2015, to which this activity report relates, the European Union has again faced the serious challenges faced in the management, policy and financial management of the EU, including the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the introduction of a single resolution mechanism for banks in the euro area.
These and other events have led to the creation of new audit tasks of the Court.
In 2015, we also examined the activities of EU institutions and other bodies and all EU funds paid to Member States, non-EU countries, international organisations and other beneficiaries.
In accordance with our obligations under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have prepared annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund and special annual reports on the annual accounts of more than 50 EU agencies and other bodies.
In addition, we have prepared 25 special reports on a number of topics, the results of which are summarised in this activity report.
We would like to draw your attention to two specific reports: the report on the Emissions Trading Scheme, which shows that our work goes beyond purely financial issues, as well as the report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which forms part of a series of new special reports on financial and economic governance.
In addition, last year we issued eight opinions on new or revised EU legislation with a significant financial impact, including an opinion on the EFSI Regulation.
In order for our work to be effective, we need to provide the information we have received to stakeholders both at EU level and at national level.
During the year, we have deepened our cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union During the year, we have deepened our cooperation with our key partners in ensuring the European Union's reporting obligations.
The results of our studies have been presented by an increasing number of specialised committees of these institutions, and their concerns have been taken into account during the planning of future studies.
Members of the Court also made high-level visits to the Member States to strengthen their partnership with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies.
In 2015, we organised two important conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and the other in Luxembourg on the future of assistance in the context of the new UN Sustainable Development Goals.
We have also prepared a comprehensive internal reform to better respond to ongoing changes in the European Union.
This report presents some important changes that we have made with regard to our relations with stakeholders, our audits and our resources.
In addition, you receive important information on the management of human resources, finance and services and the results of our internal and external audits last year, as well as on the latest annual discharge procedure.
I hope that this report will provide you with a useful and interesting overview of the Court's activities in 2015, in which we intend to achieve our task of improving the financial management of the EU, increasing accountability and transparency and protecting the financial interests of EU citizens.
2015 summary 05 Our management • Annual reports on the general budget of the EU • and the European Development Fund for the financial year 2014, containing the statement of assurance and the results of the audit. • 52 annual reports containing the Court's opinions on the audit reports of the various EU agencies and agencies and two summary reports. • Internal reform has been carried out to improve our control and reporting procedures and to ensure greater flexibility in the management of our resources. • 25 specific reports on specific management topics and budgetary areas, including the emissions trading system, youth employment programmes and assistance during the financial crisis. • Eight opinions on new or revised EU legal acts and other decisions affecting the financial management, from the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the revised regulation on the Single Resolution Mechanism. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our addressees, including two high-level conferences on EU commitments on energy and development assistance.
In terms of recruitment and management of human resources, we continued our policy of equal opportunities. • In terms of integration of IT systems, audit management and audit documentation, we made significant progress, and we made available information related to audit on mobile devices, as well as the buildings of the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg.
Our activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's liability chain because they are used to hold the EU's financial management entities accountable in particular under the annual discharge procedure.
They are primarily the European Commission, but also other EU institutions and bodies.
In shared management areas, Member States also play an important role, for example, in agricultural and cohesion spending.
Our three main products are: • Annual reports containing mainly the results of accounting checks and compliance checks in relation to the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund (EDF), taking into account aspects of financial management and results.
These reports are accompanied by specific annual reports published separately for EU agencies, decentralised bodies and joint undertakings. • Special reports presenting the results of selected performance and compliance audits for specific expenditure or policies or budgetary or management issues. • Opinions on new or amended legal acts which affect financial management as well as other products based on analyses carried out at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative.
We are trying to manage our resources in a way that ensures a proper balance between our different actions, while at the same time taking full account of the different areas of the EU budget, and achieving robust results.
In 2015, we used a large part of our resources to produce annual statements of assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports.
The work underlying the Statement of Assurance covers two aspects for which, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we must issue an annual audit opinion: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
Furthermore, we take into account, as far as possible, the performance of other auditors (see the section on the review of the EU Agencies on page 14) and management declarations in the form of annual reports on the activities of the Directors-General of the Commission.
In addition to statutory controls, we choose, at our discretion, specific expenditure or policy areas, on the basis of criteria such as the risk of irregularities or insufficient results, the potential for improvement and the public interest.
We choose these issues in a completely independent way, but we take into account the views of our address circle.
In 2015, we prepared 25 special reports, which are in particular the result of our performance controls.
A summary of the special reports is presented in this activity report (pages 15-33).
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or revised provisions and regulations (p. 34).
In particular, we pay attention to our opinion on EFSI to highlight both the subject and the impact of our opinions.
All audit reports and opinions are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 Audit visits in 2015. While most of the audit work at the Court of Justice in Luxembourg took place in Luxembourg, the auditors also carried out audit visits to the authorities of the Member States, to other beneficiaries of EU funds in and outside the European Union (including the organisations involved in the allocation of EU funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and to other EU institutions, agencies and bodies.
As a result of these visits, we received direct proof of control from the authorities responsible for the approval, management, collection and payment of EU funds, as well as from the relevant final beneficiaries.
Our teams of controllers usually consist of two to three controllers, and the duration of the verification visit may be several days, but also several weeks.
The frequency and intensity of control activities in individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of control and, where appropriate, on the selection of the sample.
The number of inspection visits may therefore vary from country to year.
In the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the highest audit authorities in the Member States visited.
In 2015, the Court's auditors spent 4 310 days on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU and obtained evidence of checks in respect of annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports).
In addition, they devoted a lot of time to the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as to decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU.
On-the-spot checks took less days than in 2014.
This is due to more effective working procedures and the increasing use of technologies such as secure data and documents exchange and video conferencing.
Detecting fraud Although our controls are not specifically designed to detect fraud, sometimes during our audit work, we encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent actions.
The Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to combat fraud from the EU budget.
Any suspicion of fraud, corruption or other illegal activities that may affect the EU's financial interests that arise during our audit work, we shall forward it to OLAF.
These cases shall then be monitored by OLAF, which shall decide on a possible investigation and, where appropriate, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2015, we handed over 27 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16).

Our activities 10 Annual Reports for the financial year 2014 Most of our accounting audits and compliance audits have been dedicated in 2015 to the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2014.
The 2014 Annual Report was published on 10 November 2015 and presented to our addressee, including the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Ecofin and Financial Councils), the national parliaments and governments, as well as the media.
Our main objective of the annual report is to help the European Parliament, the Council and citizens assess the quality of EU financial management by submitting proposals and proposals.
In our 2014 Annual Report, we have ensured that EU funds will be used during the financial year under consideration, highlighting the areas where the risk that EU funds have not been fully used is the greatest.
In addition, we analyse the reasons for errors and make useful and cost-effective recommendations for possible improvements.
We have revised the structure of our annual report for the financial year 2014 to make this report clearer.
The titles of the chapters correspond to the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
The key element of the report is still the statement of assurance in which we deliver an opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts and on compliance with the rules on revenue and expenditure.
In addition, we have made a specific assessment of all the main areas of EU activity and have provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management.
The report also provides information on the results of the EU budget and the Commission's reporting, in particular on progress towards the Europe 2020 objectives.
President Vítor Caldeira presented the European Parliament with the annual report of the European Court of Auditors for 2014 of EUR 142.5 billion in 2014 = almost EUR 300 per citizen.

The estimated error rate for reimbursement schemes (5.5%) for which the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible actions based on the cost statements drawn up by the beneficiaries is twice as high as the estimated error rate for payment entitlements schemes (2.7%) for which no costs are reimbursed but payments are subject to certain conditions. for corrective actions taken by the authorities in the Member States and the Commission, there has been a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Without these measures, the estimated total error rate would be 5,5 %.
The Commission needs further improvements in the assessment of risks and the impact of corrective actions in so far as the Commission, the Member States' authorities and independent auditors use all the information available to them could prevent, detect and correct a significant proportion of errors prior to their appearance. The Commission must take steps to address this persistent problem.

In view of these two aspects, the Commission can only partially monitor the results and the contribution of the EU budget to the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. In view of the upcoming mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, it is crucial for the management of EU expenditure.
It is important that the Commission examines as soon as possible the areas where the high level of error is maintained, assess the potential for reducing these error rates, focusing more on expenditure results.

Our activities 14 Special Annual Reports 2014 Total in 2014 around €4 billion has been allocated to all EU agencies, bodies and joint enterprises.
EU agencies, other bodies and joint undertakings perform specific tasks on behalf of the EU and are established in different EU Member States.
They operate in many areas such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and transport, and in any case have their own mandate, management, director, staff and budget.
In 2015 we prepared 52 special annual reports for the financial year 2014.
They concerned 41 decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, eight European Joint Research Undertakings, European Schools, the Galileo Joint Undertaking in the decommissioning and communication infrastructure of Sisnet.
In addition, we have published two summaries of the results of our audits in this area (one summary of EU agencies and other agencies, and the other summary of joint enterprises).
These reports have been submitted to the President of the European Parliament and to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, the Council for General Affairs and the Committee on Budgets of the Council.
In 2014, each financial statement of 33 decentralised EU agencies and other bodies was first verified independently of a private audit firm.
In drawing up our opinions on these financial statements, we have taken into account this audit work and the actions taken by the evaluation bodies on the basis of the audit findings.
The financial statements of other agencies and joint ventures have been fully audited by us.
In 2014, we considered the accounts of all agencies, other bodies and joint enterprises to be reliable.
The processes were legal and correct, except for Artemis (built-in systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and ECSEL (electronic components and systems).
Overall, the agencies have improved their procedures by taking corrective action on the basis of our comments from previous years.
Our special annual reports and two summaries of the audit results of the agencies, other bodies and joint enterprises for 2014 are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
52 specific annual reports on EU agencies, other bodies and joint enterprises based across Europe, based in Europol, The Hague, the Netherlands.
Our activities 15 Special Reports developed in 2015. In addition to our annual reports and special annual reports, we publish special reports throughout the year containing the results of the performance and compliance checks that we carry out in the specific budgetary areas or management areas that we choose.
When selecting and designing these control tasks, we try to achieve the maximum effect and thus make the best use of our resources.
Our economic controls often cover several financial years, and their subject matter is complex, so their completion may last longer than a year.
In 2015, the special reports focused in particular on the following issues: the EU's overall objective of creating added value and growth, and the EU's response to global challenges such as the sustainability of public finances, the environment and climate change.
The relevant headings corresponding to the headings of the multiannual financial framework are summarised in a summary of the 25 special reports prepared in 2015.
