Our actions 16 100 80 60 40 20 0 Competitiveness for growth and jobs EUR 143 billion 13 % Smart and inclusive growth Within the Smart and Inclusive Growth Unit, the EU budget is the majority of the expenditure.
This area covers two sub-headings of competitiveness for growth and jobs for economic, social and territorial cohesion for growth and jobs for economic and social cohesion for territorial cohesion for growth and jobs for growth and growth.
The Competitiveness sub-heading for growth and jobs 2014-2020 covers the financing of trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, business development, research and innovation, education and training, social policy, etc. The planned expenditure for 2014-2020 represents 13% of the total EU budget for the programming period, i.e. EUR 143 billion.
For 2015, EUR 15.7 billion were allocated. • Inland navigation in Europe: no significant improvement in the share of transport and navigation conditions since 2001 (No. 1/2015) the special report examines whether the projects co-financed by the EU budget have effectively contributed to increasing the share of maritime transport in inland waterway transport and improving the capacity of inland waterway transport and whether EU inland waterway strategies have been consistent and based on appropriate and comprehensive analyses.
Projects co-financed by the EU have not been successfully implemented as an alternative to road transport, as they have not been successfully implemented as an alternative to inland waterway transport, nor have they been able to improve the transport capacity.
Although the Commission has identified inland navigation as a priority, Member States have given little attention to inland navigation.
There is no coherent overall strategy for Member States combined with the main shipping corridors, and the EU strategies do not take sufficient account of the maintenance of the river, as well as of political and environmental considerations.
Member States should prioritise inland waterway transport projects which bring the greatest and most direct benefits and the Commission should focus its resources on projects where advanced bottlenecks are available.
Between 2007 and 2013, the TEN-T programme, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund allocated €1.3 billion to inland waterway projects in the EU.
Our actions 17 • Are the needs of micro-enterprises adequately met by EU financial support?
(No 8/2015) This Special Report examines whether the needs of micro-entities are met by the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Progress Microfinance Facility (ESF).
The auditors found that programming and planning of financial support granted by the ESF was weak and that the implementation of the results was not adequately and reliably monitored.
Neither the Commission nor the Member States had comparative information on Member States' administrative costs and funding mechanisms.
These circumstances may have a negative impact on the effectiveness of EU financial support to micro-enterprises.
Member States should assess needs when developing financial instruments and when developing operational programmes, including financial support for micro-entities by the EU.
The Commission should make the use of ESF financial instruments by Member States conditional on the existence of sound risk management systems.
In the case of microfinance, loans of less than EUR 25 000 are usually granted and often less than EUR 10 000.
The total demand for funding in EU Member States is estimated to be over EUR 12 billion.
Examples of this report are: providing €5,000 for urban kiosk development and €9500 for the development of the playground and clothing store. • Improving security of energy supply through the development of the internal energy market: in the Special Report on energy security (No 16/2015) on energy security (No 16/2015) on whether the implementation of internal energy market policy and energy infrastructure expenditure in the EU have effectively contributed to the security of energy supply benefits.
The audit showed that energy infrastructure in Europe in general is not yet fully integrated and therefore currently does not provide effective security of energy supply.
Therefore, the Commission should define the energy infrastructure in the EU, which is not actively used, and cooperate with the Member States in order to overcome obstacles to its use for the purposes of the internal energy market.
The Commission should also consider new ways of making energy available to customers from another Member State from one Member State.
The internal energy market aims to enable the free movement and trade of natural gas and electricity across the EU.
Within the EU budget, €3.7 billion has been earmarked for the financing of energy infrastructure for the period 2007-2013, with a further € 7.4 billion for the period 2014-2020.
However, the report stresses that the EU's objective of completing the internal energy market by 2014 has not been achieved.
Our actions 18 Economic, social and territorial cohesion Intelligent and inclusive growth Sub-heading "Economic, social and territorial cohesion its objective is to support the EU's least-developed countries and regions to join the rest of the regions to strengthen competitiveness and cooperation between them.
Cohesion expenditure 2014-2020 accounts for 34% of the EU budget for the entire programming period, i.e. EUR 367 billion.
100 80 60 40 20 0 367 billion EUR 34% • Efforts should be stepped up to address the public procurement problems of EU cohesion expenditure (No 10/2015) in a special report on the assessment of whether the Commission and the Member States are taking appropriate and effective action to address the problems of public procurement errors in cohesion policy.
The audit showed that there are still widespread public procurement problems across the EU.
Although the Commission and the Member States have started to address this issue, much remains to be done.
Serious errors have led to a lack of fair competition and a lack of award to the best tenderers.
The systematic analysis is very limited and lacks sufficiently accurate, reliable and consistent data on the nature and scale of errors.
If the situation does not improve by the end of 2016, it is recommended to suspend payments to the Member States concerned for the period 2014-2020.
For the period 2007-2013, € 349 billion was allocated to regional policy expenditure to be paid under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Social Fund.
A large proportion of these funds are spent through public procurement.
In the case of approximately 40% of the projects which the Court examined for its annual accounts for the financial years 2009 to 2013 for public procurement, errors were found.
Our actions 19 • EU funding of urban waste water treatment plants in the Danube basin: Member States need further support in the implementation of EU waste water treatment policy objectives (No 2/2015) in this special report assess the effectiveness of support to Member States in the Danube basin from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund in the implementation of EU waste water treatment policy objectives.
The audit showed that although EU spending programmes have contributed significantly to the progress made in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, there have been delays in compliance and the use of available EU funds in all countries.
Although sewage in installations in these countries were usually properly absorbed, the treatment of sewage sludge and rainwater leaks in some cases was insufficient.
One third of the installations were overdeveloped and potentially unsustainable in the long run.
These countries have slowly benefited from the available EU funds, which have threatened the loss of EU funds or the loss of additional funds from national budgets.
The Commission should strengthen reporting requirements and Member States should lay down rules to ensure fast connection to public sewerage.
The Commission and the Member States should establish criteria for all types of use of sewage sludge and ensure reliable monitoring of pollution.
The Danube basin area is the largest area in Europe.
The EU contribution to waste water treatment projects in the four Member States audited • for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods amounted to EUR 7.9 billion. The water quality in the Danube basin: progress in implementing the Water Framework Directive, but the need for further action (No 23/2015) is further examined in the special report as to whether the implementation of the Water Framework Directive by the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia has led to improved surface water quality in the Danube basin.
The audit showed that only a few improvements have been made since 2004.
The main reason for the limited progress was that the Member States' plans were not ambitious enough.
Targeted actions were missing for water bodies of insufficient quality.
In addition, shortcomings in the monitoring systems have led to the lack of data on both the type of pollution and the sources of pollution that led to the negative assessment of the state of aquatic organisms.
In addition, Member States have abandoned a significant number of water bodies without sufficient justification for significant deadlines.
Between 2007 and 2013, Member States in the Danube basin received €6.35 billion from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund for waste water treatment.
During the same period, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development received EUR 6.39 billion to cover the expenditure to farmers related to agri-environmental measures.
Our actions 20 • EU Youth Guarantee: The start is possible, but the risk of implementation is predictable (No 3/2015) is analysed in the special report, whether the Commission has adequately supported the Member States in creating the Youth Guarantee and whether the risk of implementation is possible.
The audit identified three risks that could hinder the effective implementation of the Youth Guarantee: the adequacy of the overall budget, the definition of high quality jobs, and the way the Commission monitors the Youth Guarantee and presents results.
The auditors concluded that the Commission had helped the Member States to implement the Youth Guarantee in a timely and appropriate manner.
However, the Commission has not carried out an impact assessment indicating the expected costs and benefits, although this is a standard procedure.
Although the Commission asked the Member States to provide estimates of the costs when submitting plans for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, some of them did not provide the necessary information, none of the Member States indicated the estimated costs of the necessary structural reforms.
The Youth Guarantee was established in June 2013 in response to the deterioration of the situation of unemployed young people, which aggravated the economic and financial crisis.
In the period 2014-2020, the Youth Guarantee The European Social Fund and the special initiative for youth employment The EU budget co-financed a total of EUR 12.7 billion. • Support for youth teams by the Commission: The transfer of resources from the ESF successfully but not sufficiently focused on results (No 17/2015) This special report examines whether the Youth Action Teams presented proposals in 2012 on how to achieve results more quickly and more effectively by young unemployed people, and whether these proposals contributed to the transfer of resources from the ESF.
The auditors concluded that, although the Youth Action Teams set up by the Commission have managed to regroup funds for projects to support young people, these proposals have only been presented to a limited extent.
The Commission provided Member States with advisory assistance but was limited in the scope and quality of the information available.
While the initiative has led to the reprogramming and reprogramming of the European Social Fund, the Commission has focused mainly on its budgetary impact in its assessment of the changes in the operational programmes.
Where there are discrepancies between the promises and the real objectives achieved by the Commission, there should not be too high expectations for such initiatives.
As part of the Youth Opportunities initiative, the Commission set up youth teams in 2012.
The teams included experts from eight Member States with the highest number of unemployed among young people and experts from the Commission.
This initiative covered almost EUR 10 billion of the European Social Fund, which were still available in the Member States concerned.

100 80 60 40 20 0 39 % • Technical assistance: What contribution has it made to agriculture and rural development?
(No 4/2015) This special report examines the use of financial resources for technical assistance in agriculture and rural development for the 2007-2013 programming period.
The audit focused on the regularity, effectiveness and effectiveness of funding at the level of the Commission and the Member States.
The audit showed that neither the European Commission nor the Member States were able to demonstrate how the use of technical assistance in the field of agriculture and rural development contributed to the use of budgetary resources and to the achievement of the objectives of the common agricultural policy.
Rural networks to support cooperation, knowledge exchange and innovation in the agricultural sector are very good beneficiaries of technical assistance.
However, in most cases, capacity-building funds were used to support general administrative budgets.
The Commission should clarify the scope and use of technical assistance in the Member States in the field of rural development and closely monitor its implementation.
For the period 2007-2013, Member States have planned to allocate €1.5 billion to technical assistance under the EU budget under the ceiling of 4 % of the national financial framework available for rural development.
In the period 2014-2020, this amount increased to around €1.9 billion.
Our actions 22 • Are financial instruments in the field of rural development an effective and promising instrument?
(No 5/2015) This special report concerns whether the financial instruments (credits and guarantee funds) introduced under rural development policy have been well developed and managed during the 2007-2013 programming period.
The audit showed that the financial instruments were not yet effective.
This is mainly due to overcapitalisation of financial instruments and their lack of potential with regard to the desired leverage effect and the renewable effect.
There was no clear argument for the introduction of financial instruments for the 2007-2013 programming period.
In addition, reliable quantitative information was not available to justify the nature of the financial instruments established, to identify the demand for financial instruments in the agricultural sector and to demonstrate that the amount allocated to the fund was appropriate.
Incentives for Member States to create financial instruments for rural development and to increase the demand for farmers or other beneficiaries should be stepped up and appropriate standards and targets for leverage and renewables for 2014-2020 should be set.
By the end of 2013, the EU and its Member States invested around €700 million in guarantee and credit funds for rural development.
The Commission wants Member States to commit to at least doubling the use of these instruments for the period 2014-2020.
Approximation of economic control: the integrity and implementation of the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (No 6/2015) The EU Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) differs in a way from other policies and programmes that we are investigating because it does not receive significant funding from the EU budget.
However, it has a huge impact on the implementation of EU policies and on the quality of life of citizens.
The EU ETS was introduced in 2005 and is often referred to as the reference model for the development of emission trading strategies and schemes elsewhere in the world.
Therefore, an appropriate regulatory and supervisory framework for the market, legal certainty and management systems for relevant information are expected.
The basic structures of the implementation systems should also be sufficiently robust.
At the end of 2013, our auditors examined the framework for the protection of the integrity of the EU ETS and the systems for the effective implementation of the programme by the Commission and the Member States by Phase II (end 2012).
The evaluation was carried out because of the risks associated with the creation of a functioning market with a view to implementing EU climate policy and because of the difficulties of controlling untraceable activities (how is hot air measured? how).
Our auditors have examined whether the EU ETS was properly managed.
To this end, they not only checked the file and interviewed the officials involved in the management of the EU ETS in the European Commission in Brussels, but also visited the competent authorities in five Member States (Germany, France, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom).
In addition, in two other countries (Greece and Spain), the documents were reviewed and the experts were consulted.
More evidence was obtained from auditors who checked the 150 installations selected in these seven Member States as well as data from the EU transaction protocol.
Our actions 23 are being analysed and the inspectors could not control the equipment on the ground because they are not financed by EU funds under the Emissions Trading Scheme and the Court therefore does not have the access rights required for the control.
The evidence obtained by our auditors indicated that the emissions market was not being monitored and that there was insufficient cooperation between regulators.
For example, our auditors concluded that the legal definition of allowances should be clarified and that the procedures for the opening of ETS accounts in the Union Registry and the monitoring of transactions were not adequate in order to ensure adequate checks on fraud.
However, the initial situation was difficult: Member States could not effectively monitor cross-border transactions because they had no direct access to the central database and the Commission was not able to monitor the transactions because there was no legal basis for this.
Our auditors also found that the emission monitoring and reporting systems were not harmonised and that the controls were weak and insufficient support from the Commission and from the Commission and the Member States.
In their findings, the auditors concluded that the framework for protecting the integrity of the market is not sufficiently robust and that, at the last stage, there have been significant shortcomings in the implementation, which in some cases require further action at this stage.
However, our report also shows that this innovative system has been continuously improved.
At the time of publication of the report, the debate on possible reforms of the EU ETS, which focused on the effectiveness of the system and the management of the surplus of powers, was not yet completed.
However, in our report, we note that attention should also be paid to the fundamental issues of market integrity and implementation, so that the EU can be sure that this fundamental instrument is sufficient to meet the expectations of reducing emissions and low-carbon technologies.
We have made some practical recommendations to the Commission and the Member States' authorities to improve market integrity and to implement the system so that the EU ETS becomes a more effective tool to achieve the climate targets by 2020 and beyond.
The Commission agreed with the recommendation in the report that, in order to improve market integrity, significant remaining problems in the regulation and supervision of the market should be addressed where appropriate, and that a number of improvements have already been made in phase III (2013-2020) in order to improve market integrity, in particular with regard to our comments.
This report aroused great media interest and was presented to accredited EU journalists at a press conference in Brussels.
In the EU and around the world, the press reported that the EU ETS should be more supervised to improve the carbon market and that the system should be more protected from market abuse, including the still high risk of VAT fraud.
As usual for all special reports, the Member responsible for the report, in this case Kevin Cardiff, reports to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, as well as to the Committee on the European Parliament and the Environment Council, in order to forward to them the conclusions of the Court, which may form the basis for future decisions on the relevant provisions and regulations.
Parliament and the Council welcomed our comments and recommendations and will take into account future proposals to improve the integrity and implementation of the system.
Control team (left to right): Stefan Den Engelsen, Emese Fésűs, Kevin Cardiff and Colm Friel.
Our actions 24 • Are fisheries partnership agreements well managed by the Commission?
(No 11/2015) ) This Special Report examines whether contracts are well managed.
The auditors assessed the negotiations and implementation of the agreements, the monitoring of catches by the Commission and the selection and control of the actions financed.
The audit showed that although contracts were generally well managed, the quantities negotiated were often higher than the quantities declared during the previous periods.
This leads regularly to incomplete use of resources.
As the EU makes full payments regardless of the actual catches made, the actual costs were often higher than the negotiated price.
Furthermore, reliable, uniform and complete data on actual catches of the EU fleet were missing.
In negotiating the new rules, the Commission should take into account earlier utilisation rates, which make payments more dependent on actual catches and ensure that the new fishing database is fully used by the flag Member States and contains reliable catch data that can be monitored and updated.
The aim of the agreements is to ensure the sustainability of the fisheries concerned by allowing EU vessels to fish exclusively for surplus resources of the partner countries.
However, auditors doubt whether the so-called surplus can be reliably calculated due to the lack of reliable information. • The EU priority to support the knowledge-based economy in rural areas has been breached as a result of insufficient management of knowledge transfer and advice (No 12/2015) on the basis of this Special Report, in particular to examine whether management and control systems exist to effectively implement knowledge transfer and advice in the field of rural development.
The audit has shown that the implementation of EU funded VET and VET programmes in rural areas is too expensive, often leads to duplication of existing programmes and is beneficial for existing providers of training services.
Auditors have identified shortcomings in administrative procedures in the Member States and insufficient supervision by the European Commission.
Member States relied too much on instructors' proposals and considered all kinds of training to be good and eligible for public support.
The lack of fair and transparent choice has led to the fact that the selection of existing and existing suppliers has been repeatable for a long time and most of them have received support.
Member States should select training projects that meet the skills needs of the periodic analysis and avoid the establishment of selection procedures by suppliers.
The EU supports rural training and advisory projects from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.
€1.3 billion has been allocated to these projects for the period 2007-2013.
Together with Member States' co-financing, the total amount of public support amounted to EUR 2.2 billion.
This amount may amount to over EUR 4 billion over the period 2014-2020.
Our actions 25 • The cost-effectiveness of EU rural development assistance for non-productive investments in agriculture (No 20/2015) in particular determines whether non-productive investments in agriculture (NPI) are cost-effective and contribute to the achievement of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the sustainable management of agricultural land in the 2007-2013 programming period.
The auditors concluded that although aid to the NPI contributed to the achievement of the objectives, it was not profitable, as the costs of 75% of the projects audited were disproportionate.
Many of these projects were fully funded by public funds, although they obviously benefited, and the auditors visited four Member States, which in total spent 80% of the total EU budget on NIP: Portugal, Denmark, the United Kingdom (England) and Italy (Apulia).
Only five of the 28 projects audited proved cost-effective.
The report warns that the lack of cost efficiency may not be limited to the sample as the problems identified are due to shortcomings in the management and control systems of the Member States.
Non-productive investments are investments that do not lead to significant revenue or revenue or to a significant increase in the value of the beneficiary's activities but have a positive impact on the environment. • Infrastructure support in EU rural areas: these measures could be used in a much more efficient way (No 25/2015) in this special report, which examines whether the European Commission and the Member States have achieved a good cost-benefit ratio through the financing of roads, water supply systems, schools and other institutions in the framework of rural development programmes.
The audit showed that although some infrastructure projects have made a positive contribution in rural areas, Member States and the Commission have achieved insufficient cost-benefit ratio in shared management.
Member States have not always made it clear that the EU needs to finance rural development.
The risk of supporting projects without EU funding has not been effectively controlled.
The report concludes that the Commission has adopted a more active and coordinated approach since 2012.
Appropriate implementation should lead to improved financial management for the period 2014-2020.
Between 2007 and 2013, the rural development programmes allocated EUR 13 billion to rural infrastructure.
Our actions 26 100 80 60 40 20 0 Foreign policy EUR 65 billion 6% Europe in the world Europe in the world covers the external relations of the EU (the world's foreign policy), including enlargement issues, as well as EU development and humanitarian aid.
During the 2014-2020 programming period, the EU has allocated 6% of the planned total expenditure, i.e. EUR 65 billion.
In 2015, the budget amounted to EUR 7.5 billion.
Additional appropriations will be made available through the European Development Fund, which is not part of the EU budget and is therefore not covered by the multiannual financial framework. • EU police mission in Afghanistan: Mixed results (No 7/2015) in the Special Report assess whether the EU police mission (EUPOL) was well planned and coordinated, whether it received appropriate operational support and appropriate guidance, whether it contributed to progress in the field of the national Afghan police and whether it was prepared in the appropriate form.
The audit has shown that EUPOL has partially fulfilled the objective of contributing to the establishment of a permanent and effective civilian police force under Afghan responsibility.
In an environment characterised by the lack of trained, fully functioning Afghan police forces, high illiteracy and widespread corruption in Afghan police and judicial systems, EUPOL has managed to contribute to the reform of the Ministry of the Interior and the professionalisation of the national police.
However, given the persistent shortcomings in the police and judicial system in Afghanistan, there is a risk that the results of EUPOL and, in general, the Afghan police will not survive by the end of 2016.
The total cost of EUPOL between May 2007 and December 2014 amounted to almost EUR 400 million, with almost one third of the security costs.
At the end of 2014, the EU sent a total of 32 missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy, 16 of which were completed and completed and 16 were still ongoing.
Our actions 27 • EU support for the fight against torture and the abolition of the death penalty (No 9/2015) for the fight against torture and for the abolition of the death penalty (No 9/2015) for the fight against torture and rehabilitation of torture victims and for the abolition of the death penalty under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.
The audit showed that although EU-funded projects are producing results, projects are often not sufficiently targeted and have limited scope, as funds are distributed in accordance with the casting principle.
The allocation of funds was usually appropriate, but the Commission has not sufficiently taken into account the priorities of the individual countries in the field of human rights.
Projects have often not been well coordinated with other EU actions such as development aid and political dialogue.
They are usually implemented by involved and competent organisations.
The recommendations of the auditors concerned the targeting of financial resources, better coordination with other EU actions, the selection and improvement of project proposals, the measurement of results and the sustainability of beneficiary organisations.
The European Union acts by diplomatic means and grants grants to non-governmental organisations through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.
• EU support to timber-producing countries under the FLEGT Action Plan (No 13/2015).The special report examines whether the Commission has managed well the support under the EU FLEGT Action Plan to combat illegal logging.
The auditors said that although the Action Plan is a positive initiative, the results are generally thinner.
The aid was not granted to timber-producing countries on the basis of clear criteria and its impact was weakened due to the large number of countries competing for aid.
These countries have made significant differences in progress.
Inappropriate progress is particularly due to the lack of appropriate planning by the Commission and the lack of clear priorities for the allocation of resources to wood producing countries.
The auditors recommended that the Commission set clear objectives and ways of achieving them.
Four Member States still need to fully implement the EU Wood Regulation, which was introduced to prevent illegal timber from being imported into the EU market.
Between 2003 and 2013, 35 countries received EUR 300 million under the Action Plan.
Two of these countries, Indonesia and Ghana, have made progress towards a full timber authorisation system.
Overall, little progress has been made, and many countries have encountered difficulties in overcoming obstacles to responsible policies.
Within 12 years of the Commission's implementation of the action plan, no partner country has been able to implement a fully recognised authorisation scheme.
Our actions 28 • ACP Investment Facility: does it offer added value?
(No 14/2015) This Special Report assesses whether the Investment Facility was an added value for EU development cooperation with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries.
The audit has shown that the Investment Facility has indeed added value to EU development cooperation with ACP countries and that it fully fits EU policy objectives.
At the end of 2014, the credit lines represented 28% of the instrument's portfolio compared with 14% at the end of 2010.
This increase reflects the continuing importance of the long-term financing offered under the instrument.
The instrument also acted as a catalyst in a positive sense by mobilising additional measures.
However, auditors found that the contractual obligation to inform the final beneficiaries of the financing by the European Investment Bank (EIB) or the Investment Facility is not always fulfilled, and technical assistance is not always targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises.
They have made recommendations to address these problems.
The ACP Investment Facility established in 2003 receives its capital from the European Development Fund and is managed by the EIB.
The instrument has approved development projects worth €5.7 billion over the last ten years.
The instrument provides medium- and long-term financing and aims to achieve sustainable economic, social and environmental benefits. • The promotion of renewable energy in Eastern Africa under the ACP-EU Energy Facility (No 15/2015) in this special report, in order to examine whether the Commission has successfully used the energy instrument in order to improve access to renewable energy of poor social groups in Eastern Africa.
The audit has shown that some significant successes have been achieved, but even better monitoring of the instrument is needed.
The Commission has made a good choice among the proposed projects but has not made sufficient close monitoring of the progress made in the implementation of the projects.
The reports of the project managers differed in quality and the Commission did not take any action to ensure compliance with the reporting requirements.
For projects known to have had serious problems, Commission staff have carried out insufficient on-the-spot visits and monitoring checks to supplement the information provided by the administrators.
The report sets out recommendations for more rigorous selection, better monitoring and more sustainable future projects.
By mid-2014 a total of EUR 268 million had been allocated, of which EUR 106 million had been allocated to projects in eastern Africa which had been allocated the lowest access to electricity in Africa.
Our actions 29 • Analysis of the risk of a performance-based approach to EU development and cooperation activities (No 21/2015) due to the increased interest that has recently been to shift the development and cooperation priorities of EU development and cooperation policy to results.
The auditors identified nine main threats: inconsistent terminology related to performance or inconsistent chain of actions, products, impacts and impacts; increased complexity related to the integration of cross-cutting issues into EU programmes; lack of harmonisation of aid instruments, performance frameworks and accountability structures of partners for development; shortcomings in the evaluation and evaluation of results; lack of consolidated reports or the compilation of results obtained from EU aid; lack of adequate, adequate, reliable and up-to-date data; focus on budgetary results as a target; change of the context of actions.
The audit showed that these risk areas were correctly identified by the Commission in a number of different documents.
Nevertheless, further action is needed to exploit the full potential of the Commission's initiatives and to improve the EU's development and cooperation performance.
A number of recommendations have therefore been drawn up which the Commission should take into account.
Our actions 30 100 80 60 40 20 0 Financial and economic governance The objective of the EU economic governance framework is to address problematic financial and economic trends, such as excessive public deficits and public debt, which can hamper economic growth and threaten the sustainability of public finances.
Under this framework, an EU banking union is established.
According to the 2014 European Banking Authority report, this special report was the second we published on the subject.
In 2008, Europe faced a financial crisis that has become a sovereign debt crisis.
The sovereign debt crisis was the consequence of various factors, such as weak banking supervision, insufficient fiscal policy and difficulties faced by large financial institutions (and the resulting costs of rescuing these institutions from society).
The crisis hit the EU Member States in two waves: in 2008-2009, it met countries outside the euro area and then spread to the euro area itself.
Our auditors examined how the European Commission managed the financial assistance provided under the Balance of Payments Instrument and the European Financial Stability Mechanism during the crisis, under which the Commission absorbed financial resources in the capital markets, with the EU budget as a guarantee.
The audit concerned financial assistance granted to Hungary, Latvia, Romania, Ireland and Portugal, with particular emphasis on the Commission's role in these programmes.
In addition, our auditors analysed the Commission's cooperation with its partners from the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt and with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Washington.
Evidence of verification was obtained through detailed review and analysis of documents and through discussions with Commission officials, national authorities, the ECB and the IMF.
The partners and decisions taken at EU political level were not subject to scrutiny.
The audit showed that the European Commission was not prepared for the first requests for financial assistance during the financial crisis in 2008, because no warning signals were included, which, to a large extent, explains the first significant shortcomings in its administrative processes.
The auditors identified four main areas of crisis management of the Commission: different approaches, limited quality control, insufficient monitoring and shortcomings in the documentation.
In some programmes, the conditions for granting aid were less stringent and easier to meet.
Furthermore, it was found that the Commission's teams had not carried out sufficient verification of the relevant documents, had not been verified by anyone outside the team, had not been thoroughly verified by the experts or had not been sufficiently documented by the verification procedures.
Our actions 31 In the view of the auditors, despite the lack of experience, the Commission has managed to carry out its new administrative tasks and to launch financial assistance programmes relevant to the reform process, which, given the pressure of time, must be considered to be a success.
In addition, the auditors found that, during the crisis, the Commission increasingly developed internal knowledge and cooperated with a number of stakeholders in the countries concerned, and that improved macro-economic surveillance was introduced during subsequent reforms.
For example, the objectives of the programmes have been achieved, the adjusted deficit targets have been achieved to a large extent, structural deficits have improved, and the Member States have fulfilled most of the conditions of their programmes, albeit with some delays.
In most cases, the countries continued the reforms under the programme, and in four out of five countries the current account adjustment was faster than expected.
Our auditors have noted that there are still a number of weaknesses and that the Commission needs to improve its financial aid management procedures.
We have made a number of recommendations to the European Commission to ensure that financial assistance is better managed in the future when Member States in difficulty ask for assistance.
This report was widely echoed, especially in European media, but also in the United States and Australia.
Like our other special reports, it is presented to the addressees in the European Parliament and the Council by our fellow Member, Mr Baudilio, in the São Tomé and Príncipe.
Control team (left to right): Didier Lebrun, Ignacio García de Parada, Kristian Sniter, Josef Jindra, Giuseppe Diana, Baudilio Island Muguruza, Adrian Savin, Daniela Hristova, Zacharias Kolias, Marco Fians and Daniel Costa de Magalhães.
Our actions 32 • The supervision of EU credit rating agencies is based on solid grounds, but is not yet fully effective (No 22/2015) The special report examines whether the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) (ESMA) is effective in the supervision of credit rating agencies in the EU.
The financial crisis in 2008 increased the focus on credit rating agencies and their impact on financial markets.
At that time, credit rating agencies in Europe were, to a small extent, regulated.
The audit has shown that although ESMA has developed good grounds, its rules and guidelines are not complete and that there are still serious risks.
The auditors concluded that ESMA could reduce the average duration of the registration procedure but the procedure remains complex.
While rating methods should be rigorous, systematic, durable and validated, ESMA's activities focus primarily on whether these methods are rigorous.
The current Eurosystem credit assessment framework does not guarantee the same functioning of all credit rating agencies registered with ESMA, which creates a two-stage market structure which puts small credit rating agencies at a disadvantage.
The auditors made certain recommendations to ESMA on the registration procedure, the traceability of the risk detection procedure, supervisory procedures and information systems. • Technical assistance to Greece: Better making available requires a greater focus on results (No 19/2015) on the basis of this Special Report, to assess whether the Greece Task Force has fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance to Greece has effectively contributed to the reform process.
The Task Force was set up by the Commission in 2011 to support the economic adjustment of Greece by means of a number of technical assistance measures.
The auditors checked whether the task force had fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance had effectively contributed to the reform.
They obtained evidence from the Commission, service providers, Greek ministries and other interested parties.
The audit showed that the Greek authorities received technical assistance in accordance with the mandate, but that they did not always go well enough with the reforms.
Due to the urgency of the situation, the Task Force was set up in a short time and without a full analysis of other options or of its own budget.
The Task Force did not have a complex, comprehensive strategic document to provide technical assistance or to set priorities.
The aid was appropriate and largely in line with the requirements of the programme and the Task Force developed a flexible and diversified implementation system, but there were shortcomings at project level.
Greek parliament, Athens, Greece.
Our actions 33 Other 8.2 % 100 80 60 40 20 0 VAT 12.8 % TEM 13.3% % GNI 65.7 % revenue The EU budget is financed mainly from revenue from three types of own resources.
These include own resources based on gross national income (GNI) and VAT and traditional own resources (tem), in particular customs duties on products and sugar levies imported into the EU.
In addition, the EU receives taxes on the salaries of EU workers, contributions from third countries to certain EU programmes and fines from companies that violate EU rules and regulations.
EU expenditure must be fully covered by revenue.
In 2015, revenue amounted to EUR 141.3 billion. • Combating intra-Community VAT fraud: further action is needed (No 24/2015) The special report examines whether the EU is effectively combating intra-Community VAT fraud.
Because of organised crime, the European Union loses between EUR 40 billion and EUR 60 billion of VAT revenue each year.
Since exports of goods and services from one EU Member State to another are exempt from VAT, criminals in both countries may fraudulently delay taxes.
In this way, both the countries concerned and the EU lose their income.
During the audit, serious deficiencies were identified, indicating the insufficient effectiveness of the current system.
In order to combat intra-Community VAT fraud, the EU has a number of instruments, but some of these instruments need to be improved or more harmonised.
In most Member States that have visited, there are no effective cross-checks between customs and tax data; Member States' tax authorities exchange information on VAT, but there are problems regarding the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the data; there is no cooperation and between administrative, judicial and judicial authorities.
In order to improve the system, action is needed by the Member States, the European Parliament and the European Commission.
Our actions 34 opinions in 2015. Our opinions on proposals for new or revised legislation with financial implications also contribute to improving EU financial management.
These opinions shall be issued at the request of the other EU institutions and shall be used by the legislative bodies at the request of the Parliament and the Council and shall be used by the Parliament and the Council.

In 2015, we issued eight opinions on a number of important areas: • Opinion No 1/2015 on the proposal for a revision of the Financial Regulation on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union; • Opinion No 2/2015 on the proposal for a revision of the Financial Regulation of the Community Plant Variety Office; • Opinion No 3/2015 on the proposal for a Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Committee; • Opinion No 4/2015 on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) (for further details in the framework); • Opinion No 5/2015 on the proposal for a revision of the Regulation of the Budget Committee of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market; • Opinion No 63/2015 on the proposal for a revision of the Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Committee; • Opinion No 71/2015 on the proposal for a revision of the Regulation on traditional own resources based on VAT and GNI and the resources to make available the necessary financial resources; • Opinion No 84/2015 on the Proposal for a revision of the Financial Regulation on the European Development Fund.
In response to the fall in investment since 2007, the Commission launched an investment offensive for Europe in November 2014.
The Investment Plan is based on the logic of intervention on which there is a high demand for investment in Europe and on a number of economically viable projects for which sources of funding are sought.
The challenge is to make effective use of savings and liquidity to promote sustainable employment and growth in Europe.
The Investment Plan is to be implemented without burdening national budgets and new debt.
From this investment plan to its full implementation, the Commission promises to create between 1 million and 1.3 million new jobs and to mobilise additional (mainly long-term) investment funds of at least EUR 315 billion between 2015 and 2017.
To contribute to the success of this initiative, in our opinion, we have drawn attention to the issues of governance and the legal framework, the rules on accountability and external audit, as well as financial commitments for public budgets.
We also stressed that in the case of instruments in which the EU cooperates with the private sector, an adequate level of transparency and accountability should be ensured with regard to public funds.
In addition, the results of these instruments should be measured in order to achieve the objectives of the actions financed.
We have noted that the proposal does not explicitly describe the agreements between the Commission and the European Investment Bank.
Our opinion has been taken into account by regulatory authorities in Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 on EFSI.

Our actions 36 The Court's Conference on the Future of Development Assistance On 20-21 October 2015 in Luxembourg, we organised an international conference on European Development Assistance beyond 2015 on the occasion of the European Year for Development, the adoption of the new UN Sustainable Development Goals and the Luxembourg Presidency.
At the beginning of the two-day conference chaired by our Danièle Lamarque, the President of Vítor Caldeira, followed by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Aid in Luxembourg, Romain Schneider, on behalf of the EU Presidency, the President of the European Parliament Development Committee, Linda McAvan, EU Commissioner for Development Neven Mimica and UN Undersecretary-General Grete Faremo, spoke.
The conclusions of the conference were summarised by Marc Angel, President of the Committee on Foreign and European Affairs, and by the Luxembourg Chamber of Deputies.
The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and cooperates with many public and private partners, including international organisations, foundations, NGOs and countries.
It is becoming increasingly important to ensure that aid is effective, which can be achieved through careful compliance with the criteria for the allocation and evaluation of aid.
In this context, the Court plays a huge role.
The new UN Sustainable Development Goals 2015-2030 are more ambitious than the previous Millennium Development Goals and encourage the addressees to think and act differently.
Participants agreed that development aid must be adapted to environmental, energy and migration policies and to other policies and that new stakeholders should be involved.
Moreover, development agencies need to adapt to the increasing diversification of funding and financial instruments: innovative financial instruments contribute to increasing leverage and to increasing convergence with market conditions, but at the same time make it difficult to make financial decisions and to identify the added value of the aid.
The European Commission has given a lecture on how a result-oriented budget should look like, in which it has clearly defined how EU spending and results should be spent.
The Court also participates in a joint interinstitutional working group set up for this purpose.

Our management 41 The College of the Court of Justice of the Court belongs to one member from each Member State.
The members shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament for a period of six years, in accordance with the proposals of each Member State.
In accordance with the Treaty, the members shall carry out their tasks in the full independence and in the general interest of the European Union.
The chairman shall be elected from among their members for a period of three years.
The term of office of the President and of the Members may be renewable.
The majority of the members shall be assigned to one of the five chambers, with the chambers adopting audit reports, opinions and position papers and taking decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member shall be responsible for his or her own tasks mainly in the field of audit.
The member, assisted by his office, shall coordinate the relevant teams of auditors.
It shall then adopt the presentation of reports, opinions or documents of positions to be adopted by the Chamber and/or the entire College of the Court, and then by Parliament, the Council and other relevant addressees, including the media.
In selected cases and at the initiative of the members, the report may also be submitted to the authorities of the Member States concerned.
One of the members of Ville Itälä W y is responsible for institutional relations.

Our governance 43 The Court's 2013-2017 strategy: Continuous progress Our five-year strategy aims to maximise the value of our contribution to the EU's social responsibility.
Our main priority for achieving this goal is the following graph: many initiatives launched under the strategy have already been implemented.
We have expanded the product range, strengthened and expanded our relationship with our addressees, accelerated our research and improved the way we measure our own results.
In 2015, the Court decided to reform its organisational structure.
In this way, we will take into account the European Parliament's recommendations on the future role of the Court and the results of the international peer review procedure carried out in 2014 in relation to our performance controls.
The Court's strategic priorities for 2013-2017: RECOGNIZING THE COURT'S PRODUCTS TO IMPROVE THE EU'S REFERENCE TO COOPERATION WITH US PARTNERS IN THE COURT'S PARTNERS IN THE COURT'S PARTNERSHIP AND COOPERATION WITH PARTICIPANTS IN THE PARTICIPATION AND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE EU'S REPRESENTATION IN THE COURT'S PARTICIPATION AND PARTICIPATION WITH THE PARTICIPATION IN THE PARTICIPATION OF THE PARTICIPATION AND IN THE PARTICIPANTS IN THE PARTICIPATION AND OF THE NEWS TO THE NEWS AND NEWS OF THE INSURANCES OF THE COURT'S INFLUENCE IN THE INFLUENCE OF INFLUENCES AT THE START OF THE PARTICIPATION AND IN THE NEWS OF THE INFLUTION TO THE NEWS AND NEWS OF THE INFLUSIONS TO THE INFLUSIONS IN THE INFLUSIONS TO THE INFLUENCE OF THE 01 05 02

Our management 45 Flexible response in a rapidly changing environment We have developed a new process of planning work that will allow us to plan our work based on our priorities and comprehensive risk assessment, based on the whole Court.
At present, we systematically take the views of the addressees into account when planning our work, in order to ensure that our reports are as important as possible.
With the help of our Member of the European Parliament responsible for institutional relations, our President and Members shall cooperate with EU citizens, including the European Parliament's committees.
Flexible provision of resources for priority control tasks We have organised our staff in flexible teams around specific tasks, not in departments, in order to facilitate the allocation of priority tasks.
This means that now we can use the right person to work fully using its skills and potential.
The reform also led to improved management of the Court: the heads of departments have become management managers who, under the direction of the Director, share management tasks and share quality and supervisory expertise.
We also strengthen our research expertise and introduce knowledge transfer tools to further improve our knowledge management processes.
Product delivery speed We have simplified our control procedures and simplified our task management so that we can deliver our products in good time.
In recent years, we have constantly reduced the average time needed to prepare our special reports and the reform will allow for further shortening.
This is particularly important in the context of the entry into force of the new Financial Regulation.
Better communication on our role and our work We revised our annual report to refer to the headings of the multiannual financial framework and thus to be easier to use and clearer.
In the annual report, we are now presenting a few years' report on the main expenditure areas and the results.
In addition, we have strengthened the communication and relations functions with the addressees, and we have hired one spokesperson.
Our management 46 Performance measurements Since 2008 we have been using key performance indicators (ZLIs) to inform management about progress in achieving our goals, to support decision-making and to inform our addressees about results.
They reflect our priorities and define our achievements and accountability as a professional examination body.
These indicators measure the basic parameters of the quality and impact of our work, with particular emphasis on the views of the main recipients and the effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources.
The ZLIs were updated for the period covered by the strategy for 2013-2017.
Quality and impact of our work We assess the quality and impact of our reports based on the assessments carried out by the addressees and assessments carried out by experts.
In addition, we measure our presence in the media.
We called on our main addressees to call on the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Committee on Budgets of the Council, the main bodies that have been audited in the Commission and in the EU agencies, and the EU-ORKB Presidents to assess the usefulness and impact of our reports published in 2015, on a scale from very low to very high on a scale of five steps from........
The answers show that 90% of our main addressees assess the value of our reports as suitable for their work (compared with 94% in 2014). 92% believe that our work is producing results (91% in 2014).
Rating of recipients 10% 21% 45% 24% 2% 0 % very low 20% average 40 % very high Properties of reports Probably impact of reports 60 % 80 % 100% 6% 23% 45% 24%
Our management 47 reviews carried out by experts Every year independent external experts review the content and present a sample of our reports for quality assessment. In 2015, the auditors assessed the four special reports and the annual reports for the financial year 2014.
They assessed the quality of the various aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale to a large extent affected in (1) the most valuable value on (4).
The assessment of experts in 2015 was higher in comparison with the previous four years, compared with a total average of 3,3 for both types of reports.
Follow-up to the recommendations We contribute primarily to improving the EU's financial management by making recommendations to the Commission and other bodies audited in our reports.
Some recommendations can be quickly implemented while others require more time due to their complexity.
We regularly check to what extent our recommendations have been implemented by the evaluation bodies.
By the end of 2015, 73% of the more than 600 recommendations we have made in 2012-2015 have been implemented.
This represents an increase compared to 69 % of the 2014 implementation rate in relation to the recommendations issued in 2011-2014.
Reviews of the Court's 2012 reports by experts 3.0 3.0 3.1 3.3 Quality assessment 01234 Implementation of the Court's recommendations after 2014 100 % 80 % 60 % 40 % 20% 0% 91 % 80 % 50 % 2012 2014 2015
It concerns the strategic objective of raising the Court's awareness of its products, its findings of the audit and the conclusions of the audit.
In 2015, we identified about 3400 online articles on our special reports, annual reports and the Court in general.
54% of them concerned our audit reports and the other articles referred to the Court and to its work in general.
In 2015, almost twice as many of our annual reports were reported in the media as in 2014.
However, the number of media reports on our special reports has decreased since 2014, mainly because of the interest in the report in question this year (airport infrastructure financed by the EU (No 21/2014) on which more than 800 articles have been published).
Resource efficiency and efficiency We assess the efficiency and effectiveness of resource use, depending on the extent to which we are able to implement our work programme, carry out audits in good time and ensure the competence of our employees.
Implementation of the work programme We plan our audit tasks and others based on the annual work programme and monitor the progress of the year.
In 2015, we launched our work programme at 88%.
While the work on the annual reports and the special annual reports was carried out as planned, in the case of special reports, compared to our very ambitious planning, this was 69%.
The completion of the remaining special reports, which were delayed due to the lack of evidence from the audit or unexpected complexity, was carried over at the beginning of 2016.
Special reports concern mainly new or innovative audits which may take longer to complete due to their nature.
The Court's draft reform, assessed for other tasks, was in line with the plan.

Our management 49 Preparation of special reports In order for our special reports to be effective, they must be submitted in good time.
In recent years, we have managed to reduce the time needed to carry out the audit, mainly on the basis of initiatives resulting from the 2013-2017 strategy.
In 2015, we prepared 25 special reports over an average period of 17 months (19 months in 2014), for the first time in less than 18 months.
We will continue our efforts to reduce the time needed to prepare our special reports, in particular in response to the new rule introduced by the amended Financial Regulation.
Vocational training In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we try to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of vocational training (except language courses).
The objective of vocational training of controllers has been again exceeded, which shows how important we attach to the development of human resources.
In 2015, taking into account language courses, one examiner represented an average of 9.4 days of training.

Support for 50 control actions Human resources Allocation of human resources In 2015 we continued to reduce human resources by 1% per year by five years (2013-2017), in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of December 2013 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management.
As a result, 872 workers (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees) were employed in 2015 out of 882 temporary staff in 2015 (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
The controller's staff consisted of 562 staff, including 113 staff in the members' office.
The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's results.
Our recruitment policy is in line with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and includes both officials and temporary staff.
In 2015, we employed 63 people: 30 officials, 17 temporary staff, 11 contract staff, four seconded national experts and one consultant.
In addition, we provided 74 graduates with traineeships for a period of between three and five months.
On 31 December 2015, the Court had only 15 vacancies (1.7% of the total number of jobs).

Support for controls 51 Balance between men and women Like other EU institutions, we are pursuing a policy of equal opportunities for human resources management and recruitment.
For several years now, we have been able to maintain the balanced participation of men and women among our employees.
The chart shows men and women at the level of responsibility at 31 December 2015 which have changed slightly in recent years.
Our action plan on equal opportunities aims to achieve a balanced participation of women and men at all levels.
According to the latest recruitment waves, 50% of AD 5 to AD staff are 8 women (an increase of 48% in 2014).
In the future, the participation of women in management positions is expected to increase as a result of the renewal at higher and medium management levels and the increasing participation of women in the AD functional group.

Support for control activities 53 Age profile Age group 20-24 25-29 30-34 35-39 40-44 45-49 50-54 55-59 60-64 65+ 0 % 0,3% 3.0% 8.0% 13.7% 20.3% 20.9% 19.9% 20% 25% 4.1 % 0.6% 5 % 10% 15 % Age profile of active-duty employees on 31 December 2015 indicates that 52% of our employees are 44 years of age or younger.

Support services Vocational training The profession of controller requires continuous training to keep up with professional development and acquire new skills.
In 2015, our employees completed an average of 7.3 days of vocational training.
The participation of language courses in the total number of training days is still falling.
Language courses accounted for 35% of the total number of training days in 2015 (compared with 43% in 2014).
Our main vocational training activities concern the modernisation of our training programmes and closer cooperation with learning opportunities both within and outside the EU institutions.
We have requested cooperation with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France) to offer post-graduate studies, public and political studies, public and master's studies and master's studies in the management of public organisations.
Cooperation with the European Commission has continued, which offers language courses for our staff and with the European Administration School, which has helped us organise training courses on personal skills in the field of training on personal skills in ECA and ECA day training.
In addition, we have increased our offer of courses through individual e-learning courses and training in the form of integrated learning (blended learning).
We have also continued our successful series of presentations organised by internal and external experts on the development of audit and other issues related to the work of our auditors.
Finally, we have introduced a framework for awards for workers who do not work in managerial positions in order to provide special training outside the Court.
Support for control activities 54 Translation Translation is a control support activity that allows us to do our job and achieve our communication objectives.
In 2015, total volume of translations was as high as ever: almost 200,000 pages and an increase of almost 3% compared to 2014.
About 99% of translations were completed according to deadlines.
In addition to normal translation work, during 26 EU-wide audit visits, our translators provided language support and interpretation during internal events and meetings.
In addition, they supported the preparation of preliminary comments and special reports and, in this way, they were more involved in the key audit processes of the Court.
In 2015, the Translation Directorate (DG Translation) optimised its structures by introducing a pool of assistants.
The large project of the GroupShare Directorate will lead to significant improvements by further improving the work of the assistant teams in order to create space to increase efficiency and automation and to harmonise the procedures of all language teams.
Information Technologies In 2015, the Directorate for Information Technologies focused its efforts on adapting our administrative information systems to support the successful implementation of the Court's reform and on preparing for the development of knowledge management to support the Court's new organisational structure.
In addition, all functions of the full Assist2 audit documentation system have been put in place for the work related to the assurance, performance audit and related reports, which means the completion of this major project.
Our new audit management system (AMS) has been launched: more than 300 plans have been created in the system and 180 audit tasks have been identified and monitored by the tool.
Based on the technical basis of mobility introduced in recent years (the provision of Wi-Fi in all areas of the Court, the equipment of all laptop employees), the Directorate is currently focusing on global mobility, i.e. access to all content anywhere, at any time and on all devices.
The project to develop a solution to ensure that employees have access to our information on all devices will help to maintain the functioning of the Court and to increase its effectiveness and effectiveness.
The maintenance of operations during the development and delivery of IT solutions was ensured and the critical systems were 99.82% available.
Support for control activities 55 Management and infrastructure The task of the Directorate for Finance and Support Services is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its tasks and fulfil its strategic objectives.
The Directorate shall also ensure that the necessary internal control, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all the Court's activities.
In 2015, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities more efficient and efficient.
Due to the exceptional situation following the terrorist attacks in Paris in November and following the crisis in Belgium, we have tightened our security measures and acquired the necessary security support in public procurement.
Information on public procurement is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
The Farm House currently has three buildings (including K1w, K2w and K3w) and leases small areas to the IT center for data recovery and to the conference room.
In addition, the European Parliament rents three offices in Brussels and one office in Strasbourg.
To ensure the cost-effectiveness of our building policy, we take into account three factors: purchasing or renting, purchasing costs and interinstitutional cooperation.
In developing and implementing our building policy, as in all areas of our business, we aim to establish and meet the highest standards of transparency and accountability.
The Community Environmental Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) The Community Environmental Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) is an instrument for business management and other organisations developed by the European Commission to assess, report and improve their environmental performance.
In 2014, we started developing an environmental management system2 which complies with the principles set out in the European EMAS standard set out in the 2009 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council.3.
Our goal is to certify EMAS by the end of 2016.
In 2015, the EMAS project made the planned progress.
2 The EMAS project in the Court started in July 2013.
Regulation (EC) No 1221/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the voluntary participation of organisations in the Community eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS).
Support for control activities 56 Financial information The Court shall be financed by the general budget of the European Union.
Our budget accounts for about 0.087% of total EU expenditure and 1.51% of total administrative expenditure.
In 2015, the total budget was 98,68 %.

Supporting control measures 58 The Court, like the other EU institutions, is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2015, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2013, which means that our 2013 annual accounts have been definitively approved.
We have carefully analysed the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our responsibility for control and management, and we have taken appropriate action in the framework of our reform.
We have notified the European Parliament of our follow-up.
Internal audit and external audit The internal audit department shall provide advice to the Court on risk control by issuing opinions on the quality of internal management and control systems and recommendations to improve the management of our operations and to promote sound financial management.
In addition, the services support the work of an external auditor, the task of which is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
Finally, the Internal Audit Department provides information on the significant risks and issues of corporate governance.

The Committee shall regularly monitor progress in the implementation of the various tasks set out in the work programme of the Internal Audit Unit.
The Committee shall also ensure the independence of the internal audit department.
In 2015, the Internal Audit Service prepared specific reports on strategic issues such as the changes in our annual report, the mid-term review of the implementation of our 2013-2017 strategy and the monitoring of the implementation of the recommendations under the peer review procedure and the European Parliament.
Taking into account the recommendations of the 2014 Internal Audit Agency that the internal control cycle should be strengthened, we have updated our IT security system and formalised the existing risk management framework and existing guidelines.
The Internal Audit Department monitored the implementation of the new guidelines and ensured that their recommendations were taken into account.
Every year we report to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit of the Court Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability that apply to the authorities that it has carried out.

01 Images will best revive the last 40 years.
These pictures show the daily work of many hundreds of workers who have worked outside in the last decades.
The selection of these photos was published in 2017 on our website (eca.europa.eu) and on social media (@EUAuditors).
The European Court of Auditors 02 Court of Auditors The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is an external auditor of the EU and one of the seven institutions of the Union.
The College of the Court has 28 members, one of each EU Member State.
The Court employs around 900 employees from all EU countries, which consist of auditors and administrative staff.
It was built in 1977 and is based in Luxembourg.
The Court's tasks are to verify that the EU ensures correct accounting, correct compliance with financial rules and that EU policies and programmes are used optimally.
Through its audit work, the Court contributes to improving the EU's financial management and to improving accountability and transparency.
It warns against threats, ensures security of control, points to shortcomings and successes, and gives guidance to policy makers and EU legislators.
The Court makes its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, the national parliaments and the general public.
Building of the European Court of Auditors at the Placeau Kirchberga in Luxembourg, 2017
