Preface of the President 04 Dear Reader, Reader!
In 1977, the European Court of Auditors started operations 40 years later, when we successfully contributed a lot of resources to the EU's public responsibility and financial management.
In October 2017, an official ceremony took place on the occasion of the anniversary of the Hof Jubilee with the participation of Her Majesty the Grand Duke and the Grand Duke of Luxembourg, President of the Republic of Estonia Kersti Kaljulaid, President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani and President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker.
Their participation in the event is to a large extent evidence of the importance of the Court as a financial institution of the European Union.
But within a year, we looked to the future.
In this way, we discussed and agreed on a strategy for the remaining three years of the current multiannual financial framework by the end of 2020.
Our citizens need access to clear and reliable information so as not to lose confidence in the EU and its bodies.
People need to see that the EU works honestly, respects the rule of law, uses public funds wisely, has clear political goals and achieves the goals it has promised.
As an external EU controller, we are well prepared to examine these aspects and to report on these aspects.
We have issued special reports throughout the year on a wide range of EU policies and programmes and based on an analysis of publications such as land analysis and rapid analysis.
In addition, we have prepared several opinions on legislative proposals and on our annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund, as well as on EU agencies and many other bodies of the European Union, as was the case every year.
This activity report provides a comprehensive overview of our activities in 2017 and provides important information on the Court, its budget and its staff.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President
2017 look 05 Our actions Our management • 28 special reports analysing effectiveness and • the added value of EU policies and programmes in areas such as youth unemployment, the environment, migration and banking union; • the analysis of EU action on energy and climate change and the rapid analysis of employment reductions in EU institutions; • five opinions on new or revised EU legislation, including the opinion on the Financial Regulation on the EU budget and the opinion on the financing of European political parties; • the annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and actions under the European Development Fund, together with the 2016 EU Review Report on the Financial Regulation; • 55 special annual reports on the annual accounts of individual EU agencies, bodies and joint undertakings, including two summary reports; • meetings, seminars and conferences with our institutional addressees and with our counterparts, including meetings of the Climate Change Contact Committee, Climate Change and Conferences on Climate Change.
We welcomed two new members: Juhan Parts (Estonia) on 1 January 2017 and Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary) on 1 September 2017 • We issued a new multi-annual strategy that serves as a guide to our work and management in 2018-2020. We also revised our work plan to ensure a more strategic, coherent and applied approach to the whole Court to the planning of our control priorities. We also examined our risk management policy and strengthened our financial procedures. • We continued to remove the positions agreed among the EU institutions while implementing a policy of equal opportunities for the recruitment and management of human resources.
Our activities 06 Audits We carry out various types of controls in various areas of the EU budget: • Performance audits take into account the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes.
The checks on the optimal use of funds focus on specific management issues or budgetary issues that we choose on the basis of criteria such as public interest, potential for improvement, risk of insufficient results or irregularities; • accounting audits and compliance audits that take into account the reliability of the financial statements, the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions (in particular as regards the Statement of Assurance) and the assessment that systems or transactions in specific budgetary areas comply with the relevant rules and regulations.
Based on the evidence gathered during our audit work, our reports have made clear conclusions on the achievement of the EU policy objectives and on the situation of the Union's budgetary and financial management.
This information will help us to formulate appropriate cost-efficiency recommendations.
A check-up visit in 2017 Most of the audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg.
At the same time, in 2017, our auditors also carried out numerous visits to other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and EU delegations, to national, regional and local bodies in the Member States and to international organisations such as the United Nations, involved in the allocation of EU funds.
In addition, we carry out on-the-spot checks on beneficiaries of EU funds within and outside the European Union.
These controls provide direct evidence of controls from stakeholders involved in the management of EU policies and programmes and in the collection and payment of EU funds as well as from the relevant beneficiaries.
The audit is our main task The frequency and intensity of our audit work in individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of controls we carry out.
In 2017, our auditors spent 3,670 days on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU (2016: 4 246 days).
In the EU, on-the-spot checks are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities of the Member States visited.
In addition, in 2017 in the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations and the OECD, as well as audit firms, our auditors spent 2 300 days (2016: 2 510 days).
In order to obtain and approve examination evidence, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies (such as secure data and documents exchange).

Our actions 08 Detecting fraud In the fight against fraud from the EU budget, we work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
It shall then take a decision on a possible investigation and, where appropriate, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2017, we gave OLAF 13 alleged cases of fraud under our control, although our controls are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we sometimes fall into cases where we suspect irregularities or frauds during our audit work.
In 2017, we handed over 13 such cases to OLAF (2016: 11 cases) where fraud was suspected. We suspected fraud as part of our audit activity on assurance of financial years 2016 and 2017 as well as other audit tasks.
Publications Our publications: Special reports, annual reports, opinions and publications based on analysis Our audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's liability chain, as they are used to be held responsible by the bodies responsible for the management of the EU budget, in particular as part of the annual discharge procedure.
In shared management areas, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States play an important role, as in the case of agricultural and cohesion expenditure, and in this way around 80% of the EU budget is implemented.
Our range of publications includes: • specific reports showing the results of selected audits on specific policy areas or expenditure or budgetary or management-related issues; • annual reports containing mainly the results of accounting audits and audits of compliance with the rules on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund, but also on financial management and performance-related aspects; • specific annual reports on the agencies, decentralised bodies and joint undertakings of the EU; • opinions on new or amended legal acts with a significant impact on financial management, drawn up at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative;
Our activities 09 • Publications based on analysis: • Landscape analyses are descriptive and analytical documents on complex and broad policy areas or management issues, in which we often present from a cross-cutting perspective our experiences and knowledge on the selected subject; • Thematic analyses are similar to Landscape analyses, as they are also descriptive and analytical documents on policy or management, but their topics are more limited; • Rapid Case Reviews generate and present facts related to very clearly defined topics or problems.
All publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
In addition, all special reports, opinions and publications based on the 2017 analysis at the end of this report are listed.

Our actions 14 Annual report on the European Development Funds Financial support is provided to the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and overseas countries and territories.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and managed by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB) for certain assistance outside the EU budget.
Around one third of the total number of errors in the EFF is due to non-compliance with public procurement rules.
Other material types of errors relate, inter alia, to expenditure which has not actually been incurred or is not eligible.
Our annual report on the EDF will be published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Special reports In 2017, we published 28 special reports.
In these reports, we have examined in particular whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically and whether the EU funds have added value.
We have also made recommendations on improving financial savings, improving working methods, preventing waste or more cost-effective achievement of the policy objectives.
Special reports examine in particular the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes Our special reports focus on issues relevant to the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, the creation of growth and the promotion of social inclusion, the challenges of migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, and ensuring the accountability and cost-effectiveness of the European Union.
Here we will discuss two of the 28 special reports: the special report on food waste, in which we discussed whether EU policies were able to solve this problem throughout the food supply chain, and the special report on the Greek financial crisis, which looked at how the EU reacted in its economic adjustment programmes to the financial and debt crisis in one of its Member States.

Our actions 17 Special Report: Combating food waste: The EU's opportunity to increase resource efficiency in the food supply chain is the problem of food waste worldwide, which has become the centre of public and political debate in recent years, in particular in view of the need to feed the growing world population.
Current estimates indicate that around one third of food produced for human consumption worldwide is wasted or lost, resulting in high economic and environmental costs.
EU auditors have examined the role that the EU can play in combating food waste The Court's auditors have examined in particular the actions and the way in which the various EU policy instruments have been taken so far in order to reduce food waste.
The main objective was to prevent food waste and to facilitate food donation, as these two aspects are given priority in the fight against food waste.
Our auditors consulted the Commission officials responsible for the policy, carried out documentary checks and carried out checks in five Member States: Italy (Lazio), the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania and Finland.
They visited the appropriate ministries and visited the site.
In addition, they consulted relevant stakeholders in the field of food production, retail trade, research and charitable organisations. in the EU they can and should do more to effectively combat food waste. in., w.s.s.s.s.s.s.s.s., w.s.s.s.s.s., they have stated that although food waste can be combated through a number of EU policies, they do not exploit this potential.
The approach so far remains fragmented and inconsistent and coordination at Commission level is inadequate.
Our report identifies a number of unused opportunities and potential improvements that would not require new legislation or additional public resources, and the auditors have proposed that existing policies should be adapted more closely and that a clear policy objective should be set to reduce food waste.
The report was submitted to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU and many national parliaments across the EU.
Both the European Parliament and the Council welcomed and adopted the conclusions contained therein.
This report also met with a great deal of publicity in the media, in particular in social media.
Our actions 18 Special Report: The role of the Commission in the Greek financial crisis in Greece needed support to ensure financial stability After the financial crisis in 2008 there was an economic crisis and a debt crisis in Europe, which revealed the weaknesses of the Greek economy.
Greece was no longer able to finance itself in the financial markets in April 2010, and therefore requested financial assistance from the euro area Member States and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
Since then, Greece has participated in three economic adjustment programmes managed by the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the IMF in the so-called Troika.
The third programme also involved the European Stability Mechanism (EMS).
The total amount of aid of EUR 368.6 billion was subject to the political conditions laid down jointly by the Greek authorities and creditors.
These programmes aimed at stabilising Greece's economic situation by meeting the financial needs of the Greek economy, which was intended to prevent the crisis being transferred to the rest of the euro area.
In return, Greece committed itself to carrying out extensive structural reforms.
EU auditors have examined whether the Commission has properly managed the economic adjustment programmes, which is part of a series of performance checks carried out by the Court in recent years, which have concerned measures and reforms taken in response to the financial crisis in 2008.
Our auditors assessed how the Commission applied the first two programmes for Greece and how it developed the third programme.
They examined documents relating to EU financial assistance programmes, examined the terms of the programmes and consulted the Commission staff, the staff of the national authorities (such as specialised ministries), the Bank of Greece, economic operators and economic operators, as well as the staff of the IMF, the European Stability Mechanism and the OECD.................adaptative economic programmes of Greece: despite shortcomings, progress in the reform process.................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................
However, in Greece, these programmes have only brought limited improvements.
Furthermore, the auditors found that the Commission had no experience in managing such a process, that the conditions of the programmes were not sufficiently high priority, were not included in a broader strategy for Greece, and that the macroeconomic assumptions of the programmes were not sufficiently clear.
This special report has been submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and to the institutional stakeholders in Greece.
This report was the subject of a wide media coverage and was the biggest media echo of all the special reports we published in 2017.

Our management 26 College of Members of the Court The term of office of Members of the Court lasts six years and is renewable.
Members shall carry out their tasks in the full independence in the general interest of the EU.
They swear on the position of the Court of Justice of the European Union.
The College shall have 28 members, one from each Member State.
Each member shall be appointed by the Council of the EU after consulting the European Parliament in accordance with the proposals of the national government concerned.
In 2017, the Council appointed two new members: • Juhan Parts (Estonia), who began his position on 1 January 2017; • Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary), who began his position on 1 September 2017.
The Chairperson shall elect a Chairperson from among themselves for a period of three years, which may be re-elected.
The role of the chairman is first-rate between Pares (first-rate of the same...)
In addition to other duties, the President shall monitor the performance of the Court's tasks and represent him outside.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany) was elected President.
The Audit Chambers and Committees The members belong to one of the five Audit Chambers of the Court and adopt audit reports, opinions and other analytical publications.
Chambers shall be governed by the Management Board of Doyen chosen by the members of them.
Each member shall be responsible for his or her specific audit tasks.
Members shall be assisted by their office.
In December 2017, five examination chambers were managed by the following Doyens: Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom), Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria), Karel Pinxten (Belgium), Baudilio Baumuruz (Spain) and Lazaros S. Lazarou (Cyprus).
Danièle Lamarque (France) chaired the Quality Control Committee in the field of audit.
Rimantas Šadžius (Lithuania) was responsible for coordinating the interinstitutional relations of the Court.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, the Chair of which shall be the Chair.
In 2017, the members of the Court of Auditors met at 21 college meetings.
Photo: College meeting on 7 September 2017.

Our governance 28 Strategy The next three years will be a very important time for the European Union to make key decisions.
We are aware that EU citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that the EU can tackle the challenges effectively.
Citizens must see that the EU is acting honestly, that the rule of law is respected, that it is using taxpayers' money carefully, that it has clear objectives and that it achieves the objectives it has promised.
We can help this as an EU external controller.
Our strategy for 2018-2020: increasing confidence through external financial control In July 2017 we published our strategy for 2018-2020, which sets out four strategic objectives: • we provide clearly defined information to addressees; • we focus more on the aspects of the effectiveness of the EU's activities; • we increase the added value of the statement of assurance; • we focus on our products across the organisation.
Ultimately, the EU is not about numbers, but about people As part of external financial control, the Court can point out what is working and what is not working and what is not working, and can help EU citizens to answer the question of whether the EU institutions deliver results to them and thus contribute to increasing confidence in the EU.
In this context, the Court's audits must also take into account the concerns of European citizens, their main addressees at the last instance.
The 2018-2020 strategy sets out five priority areas for the Court's work in the coming years.
Sustainable management of natural resources and combating climate change Investments for cohesion, growth and integration The challenges of migration, security and sustainable development in the world The functioning internal market and the stable monetary union Financing and management of the Union while respecting accountability and cost-effectiveness
Our governance 29 During the development of our strategy, we have placed great emphasis on internal and external consultations.
We discussed strategies with our employees and asked Members of the European Parliament, representatives of the EU Member States, the European Commission, other supreme audit bodies and other non-institutional stakeholders, such as scientists, tankers, NGOs (NROs) and private sector controllers.
The Court's 2018-2020 strategy is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Planning Work In January 2017, we decided to introduce new procedures for planning work, which we first applied to our annual work programme for 2018, which was published in October last year.
Main changes to our work plan: • to draw up a list of audit tasks for the whole Court; • a centralised procedure for the selection of audit ideas, possible audit tasks and final audit conclusions; • a more flexible allocation of resources for and allocation of resources between each audit authority, taking into account the workload; • to extend the scope of products to audit tasks, the result of which is an analysis-based publication; • to identify audit tasks with a high priority to which shorter deadlines apply.
In addition, we agreed with the Conference of the Chairs of the European Parliament's committee on a procedure whereby all Parliament's permanent committees can propose to the Court any subject of scrutiny.
The Court's 2018 work programme is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Measurement of results In 2013-2017 we used seven key performance indicators (KPIs) to inform management of progress in achieving our goals, to support decision-making and to inform our addressees of our achievements.
These indicators were intended to measure the basic parameters of quality and impact of our work, paying particular attention to the view of the main recipients and the effectiveness and effectiveness of the use of resources.
A revised set of performance indicators will be introduced in 2018 and will be valid for the period 2018-2020.
Quality and impact of our work We have assessed the quality and impact of our reports on the basis of the assessments of the addressees and assessments carried out by experts and on the basis of our recommendations on improving the EU's financial management.
Our management 30 Evaluation of the addressees We have asked the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Committee on Budgets of the Council, the main bodies audited by the Commission and the European Agencies, as well as the EU-ORKB Presidents and EU-ORKB Presidents to evaluate our reports.
As in previous years, the vast majority of respondents have assessed that our reports in 2017 are accurate and that our reports are very accurate.
Expert reviews Every year independent external experts review the content and presentation of the sample of our reports in order to assess their quality.
In 2017, the auditors assessed six special reports* and the 2016 annual reports.

Our management 31 Monitoring recommendations During the year we systematically checked the extent to which our recommendations were implemented by the evaluation bodies.
By the end of 2017, this was the case in 92% of the 2014 recommendations.
100% 80% 60% 60% 40% 20% 0% Implementation of the Court's recommendations after the year in which the tax was charged 92% 80% 59% 53% 2014 2015 2016 2017 Court in the media mirror 31% 4% 65% Annual Court reports in general in the media In addition, we follow how the media reports on our work and our institution are being reported.
In 2017, 65% of the references to special reports in the online media concerning our work and our institution.
Overall, the number of media reports from our special reports increased by 11% compared to 2016.
The Court's reports, which received the largest media echo in 2017, are the special reports on the Greek financial crisis, on the registration centres of migrants, on fisheries control, on greening and on networks in 2000.
Our management 32 140 120 100 80 60 40 20 Special reports of the Court e the lower number of articles on-line in the Special Report 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 The increase in the media in our special reports in 2017 corresponds to the trend that has been observed for several years.
While less than 1500 articles were published online in 2013, the figure increased to almost 7000 in 2017, the average number of articles in the special report increased from less than 30 in 2013 to almost 130 in 2017.
The biggest media echo has reached our special report on the Greek financial crisis, where more than 2000 online articles and contributions on social media use resources on social media As part of our performance measurements, we also assess our resources, in particular our ability to carry out audits on time, to implement our work programme and to provide the expertise of our employees.
The audit period In 2017, an average of 14.6 months passed from the beginning of the audit task to the adoption of the special report.
This is the shortest processing time since the beginning of the period 2013-2017.
Eight reports (29%) published during the year took less than 13 months.
It took an average of 16 months to publish the reports and about two months less than in 2016.
This positive trend shows that the efforts to achieve the 13-month objective set out in the Financial Regulation are effective.

Our management 33 Publication of reports In 2017, 65 percent of our special reports were published according to the original plan.
The other reports were postponed and published in 2018.
In addition, our annual reports and all special annual reports have been published as planned.
Vocational training As recommended by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) we try to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of vocational training per year.
In 2017, we again exceeded this goal, reaching 6.7 days of training for one controller.
If the language courses necessary for the effective work of our auditors in all EU Member States are also taken into account, the controller represented an average of 8.3 days of training in 2017.
For other employees, we have set the goal of providing an average of 16 hours (two days) of vocational training (without language courses).
In 2017, this target was reached on an average of 2.3 days of training.

Our staff 34 Personnel allocations In 2017, we completed a staff reduction of 5 percent over a five-year period (2013-2017), in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of December 2013 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management.
At the end of 2017, 853 officials and temporary staff worked at the Court. 548 of them worked at the control chambers, including 118 staff in the members' office.
The employment of the Court's staff has a broad academic and professional background.
Our employment policy is consistent with the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and promotes equal opportunities at all levels.
The staff shall include both officials and temporary staff.
General selection procedures are usually organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
In 2017, the Court employed 72 persons: 29 officials, 13 temporary staff, 24 contract staff (of which seven left the Court by the end of the year) and six seconded national experts.
In addition, we have provided 71 graduates with traineeships for a period of between three and five months.
Allocation of human resources of the Court 137 138 123 124 49 43 Control services 2017 Translation of the Service Administration of the President Total: 853 553 548
Our employees 35 Age profile Age profile of active workers on 31 December 2017 indicates that almost half of our employees are 44 years old or younger.
31 of the 68 directors and directors of the Court (46%) are 55 years of age or older.
As a result, in the next five to ten years, when these workers retire, a renewal will take place in higher management positions.
Balance between men and women The Court pursues a policy of equal opportunities which refers to all stages of the career of its employees.
Overall, we have achieved a balanced participation of men and women among our employees; 43% of our auditors and boards are women.
In recent years, we have managed to increase the participation of women in management positions in our examination chambers from 7% in 2015 to almost 20% in 2017.
We continue to advocate a balance between men and women at all levels of governance.
Our policy of equal opportunities for the years 2018-2020 also addresses issues related to age and disability.
For more information on the citizenship and gender of the executives, see the table below.

In 2017, we continued to develop our training offer, including increasing the number of courses in the field of e-learning and integrated learning (Blended Learning).
We continued our successful series of presentations organised by internal or external experts on changes in the audit and other issues related to the work of our auditors.
We also organised a series of trainings and events, during which experts from other supreme control bodies presented knowledge and best practices in the field of economic control and accounting control.
A good example of this is the Annual Training Day (Training Days), which we organized in November 2017 in cooperation with the University of Luxembourg and in which more than 300 employees participated.
We work closely with the European Commission, the European Institute for Public Administration (EIPA) and the European School of Administration (EUA) to offer our employees a wide range of training courses, including specific training in the field of audit and training in the field of personal skills development, as well as language courses related to work.
In addition, we have helped our employees to acquire or maintain professional qualifications and professional qualifications in areas related to the role and work of the Court.
In particular, we continued to work with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France), which offers postgraduate studies in the framework of the Master Management of Public Organisations (Master Management of Public Organisations), postgraduate studies in the framework of the Master Management of Public Organisations (Nancy, France), postgraduate studies in the framework of the Master Management of Public Organisations (Master Management of Public Organisations) and postgraduate studies in the framework of the Master Management of Public Organisations (Nancy, France).
We also signed a cooperation agreement with the European Institute of Higher Education in Florence, Italy.
In 2017, we established a partnership with the University of Pisa (Italy) and the Accounting Association (ACCA) to organise a summer course in financial control and public responsibility.
Last year we rewarded the best contribution awarded by the Court for 2016 for the research work in the field of public sector audit.
37 We continued our Performance Recognition Awards (Performance Recognition Awards) (Performance Recognition Awards).
The translation by the Directorate for Translation, Language Services and Publications of the Court has translated and translated over 211 000 pages.
We continued our efforts to improve translations and reduce the costs associated with them.
For example, all our translation teams are currently using a common work platform to increase productivity.
We are trying to increasingly involve our translators in our basic activities and create more synergies with our auditors.
In particular, in 2017, translators increasingly supported auditors in drawing up special reports and annual reports.
In addition, they provided linguistic support to our inspectors during 38 inspection visits.
Information Technologies Our IT Directorate plays a key role in our control processes by optimising information flow through modern and secure technologies.
In the field of document management, we have made further progress and have fully digitised the processes of production, reception and publication.
We have introduced a simplified tool to facilitate remote access to mobile devices.
In addition, we have updated the system (the installation of Windows 10 and SharePoint 2013).
In order to make even better use of interinstitutional synergies, we have introduced new systems for managing audits, missions and training, which are currently being used by other EU institutions.
Support for control activities 38 Buildings The Court currently has three buildings (including K1w, K2w and K3w) and leases office buildings for its data recovery centre in Luxembourg.
K1 The K1 building opened in 1988 has offices for up to 310 staff and conference rooms.
In the bullets there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses, library and main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical installations.
Building K1 was modernised in 2008 in order to adapt it to national health, safety and environmental requirements.
Where possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adapted to achieve compatibility with the K2 and K3 buildings.
In this way, three buildings form one integrated technical unit.
K2 K2 building was opened in 2003.
The bullets include parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses and a fitness centre.
The entire top floor is used for technical installations.
Other missiles are used in offices for up to 241 staff in which there are conference rooms, conference room with translation cabins, video conference room, café and kitchen base.
The Court commissioned a study to assess the feasibility of establishing areas of work related to the operation and the modernisation of the technical installations K2.
The study concluded that the structure of the work areas could be improved and that certain technical installations should be modernised.
A detailed analysis of this project will be carried out in 2018 and work will begin in 2019.
As the Council and the European Parliament approved in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining funds in the framework of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago in order to finance this modernisation.

In the bullets there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses, warehouses, warehouses, waste storage facilities, printers, kitchens and archives.

Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method (BREEAM) building K3 was assessed very well on the basis of the assessment on the basis of a very good basis on the basis of the assessment on the basis of the Environmental Assessment Method (BREEAM).
The project for safety at work In 2017, the project for the improvement of the safety of the Court and its staff was continued as planned.
The new security control centre, external accreditation centre and access control centre for employees and visitors will be launched in 2018.
Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, we consider it our duty to respect the principle of sound environmental management in all activities, and we are constantly trying to reduce the Court's environmental impact.
In 2017, we received a certificate of the environmental management and audit system.
Currently, we successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements set out in ISO 14001:2015.
Our goal is to systematically reduce CO2 emissions.
In 2017, in the third year in a row, we analysed greenhouse gas emissions (i.e. our CO2 footprint).
The results of this study are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Liability 40 of the Court Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union and its budget falls within the scope of administrative expenditure.
In 2017, the Court's budget was around 141 million euro.
This represents less than 0,1% of the total EU expenditure or around 1.5% of the total EU administrative expenditure.
The budget share for 2017 was 98%.

Court's liability 42 Risk management During the year, in accordance with the requirements of the Financial Regulation, we have checked the risk assessments prepared for each Directorate.
The results of these checks shall be taken into account in the annual declaration of the authorising officer by delegation in the annual activity report and shall be taken into account in the risk assessments of the following year.
If necessary, we have prepared action plans for ex ante and ex post controls.
In September 2017, following these inspections, we strengthened internal controls and financial procedures regarding travel and management costs of service vehicles.
Internal audit and external audit Internal audit department shall advise the Court on issues relating to risk management.
The Commission shall deliver opinions on the quality of internal management and control systems and shall report to the Internal Audit Committee of three members of the Court and to the external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor the progress made in the various tasks identified in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Unit and shall ensure its independence.
In 2017, the services examined the implementation of the Court's 2013-2017 strategy, the operational structure of the Directorate-General for Services, as well as the management of licences and software products.
The Commission has also examined the implementation by the Court of the risk management policy and monitored the implementation of its recommendations to ensure that action plans are being shaped.
The internal auditor considers that the existing procedures for the management, risk management and internal control in 2017 provide in general sufficient assurance that the Court's objectives will be achieved.
Every year we report to Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability to the authorities it has carried out.
The auditor's report on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2016 was published on 31 October 2017.
The discharge, like the other EU institutions, is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2017, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2015.
This means that our annual accounts were finally approved for 2015.
As every year, we have carefully analysed the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our responsibility for audit and management, we have taken appropriate action, and we have informed the European Parliament of our follow-up.
The Court issued 43 opinions on the Court's annual accounts on the Court's annual accounts on the Court's annual accounts on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors on 31 December 2016 and on the Court of Auditors' financial situation and financial situation, financial flows and changes in net assets in the year ending on that date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (OJ L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1).
Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities (OJ L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1) and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 148/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules for the application of the Financial Regulation.
The statement by the 44th authorising officer, the undersigned Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declares that, as authorising officer by delegation, • • that the information contained in this report is correct and accurate and that it is sufficient to confirm that the appropriations made available for the actions described in this report have been used for the intended purposes and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, that the control procedures put in place give reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and the sound handling of the allegations of fraud or fraud are proportionate to the costs and benefits of the control.
This security shall be based on an assessment of the signed and available information, such as the reports and statements of the authorising officers of the sub-delegated, internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's opinions on the previous financial years.
Done at Luxembourg, 8 March 2018.

The European Court of Auditors 4 Court of Auditors The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the external auditor of the European Union.
It was established in 1977 and is one of the seven EU institutions.
The Court is based in Luxembourg and employs around 900 employees from all EU countries, which consist of auditors and employees in horizontal and administrative services.
The College of the Court shall be composed of one member of each EU Member State.
The Court's tasks are to verify that the EU ensures that its financial rules are properly applied, that its policies and programmes are in line with the objectives and that they ensure that financial resources are used optimally.
Through its audit activities, the Court contributes to improving the EU's financial management and to improving accountability and transparency.
The Court makes its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, national governments and national parliaments and the general public.
Preface of the President 5 Dear Reader, Dear Reader!
We are now focusing more on assessing the results of the EU's actions, on the clearer message of our statements to the Court's addressees, and on increasing the value of our work for our stakeholders.
In this activity report we present a review of our work in 2018, in which we have published the highest number of special reports, analyses and opinions so far.
In addition, you can find information about our employees, management and our finances.
Our reports ensure an impartial evaluation of the Union's policies and programmes and the quality of EU financial management in the European Union and beyond.
We are checking whether EU expenditure is in line with the rules and whether EU policies and programmes ensure the optimal use of resources.
We will be happy to work with the newly elected European Parliament and the new European Commission to further improve the EU's financial management and ensure that the EU achieves its results.
In this report, we express our determination to continue to adapt the organisation of the Court to "prepare us for the future" and to continue to prepare for the development of control in the public sector.

Our 2018 strategy is the first year of our current strategy, which covers the period up to and including 2020.
Our strategic objectives for this three-year period are to increase the added value of the statement of assurance for the current EU financial management, to focus more on the aspects of the effectiveness of EU action, to increase transparency among our addressees.
We also agreed that our entire organisation would focus even more on our products.
To achieve our strategy, we agreed on an action plan on these objectives to continue to be a leader in the development of the public sector.
All these measures were in progress at the end of 2018.
At the same time, we have already commissioned an independent peer review procedure to implement our strategy. Technical evaluation is due to be completed at the end of 2019. For more information, see the section on the Court's liability.
Progress towards achieving our strategic objectives 7
In the spotlight Among our products, the communication activities in sending clear statements to our addressees Communication is crucial to achieve our strategic goal of sending clear statements to our addressees, including to the political bodies of the EU and the Member States responsible for the control and management of Union policies and programmes, to the other highest control bodies, to businesses and industrial organisations, to researchers and, in particular, to the general public, to our key stakeholders.
In 2018, we saw how much the media are interested in our work.
In particular, our special reports have received great media interest and have increasingly been discussed in national and EU media channels.For more information, see the section on media presence.
In 2018, we published 12 audit forecasts (formerly called "basic documents") which are intended to serve as a source of information for those who are interested in specific policy areas or programmes for which controls are carried out.
The information provided therein shall be based on preparatory work prior to the commencement of the ongoing examination task.
The audit projections contributed to the stable and sustainable results of the Court's publication throughout the year: 2018 was the first year in which there was not a single month without the publication of the European Court of Auditors.
We will continue to publish this type of communication products in 2019. 8
Journal While our findings and recommendations on improving the EU's financial management are presented in our audit reports, in the Court's journal we pay particular attention to our working methods and our staff, who report in various areas.
Now every number is devoted to a different number of topics.
In 2018, the Court's report raised a number of issues such as EU assistance, Parliament's funding and control, and the EU's financial and economic governance, as well as our special reports, the work programme, international cooperation and our work for the future, aimed at "arming the Court for the future."

Audits More focus on results We carry out different types of controls in different areas of the EU budget: on Performance Audits in this area take into account the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes, focusing on specific issues of governance or budget.
When selecting and organising these audit tasks, the Court shall take into account the risks related to cost-effectiveness or compliance, the level of revenue or expenditure, as well as the political and public interest; the audits and audits of compliance, as well as the reliability of the annual accounts, the legality and regularity of the basic financial operations, in particular in relation to the statement of assurance of expenditure, and the assessment of whether the systems in each budgetary area are in compliance with the rules.
Our random random procedure guarantees the same probability of checking for each euro issued.
Our audits focus on issues that reflect important issues for the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, economic growth and social inclusion, the challenges of migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, as well as ensuring the accountability and cost-effectiveness of the European Union.
On the basis of the evidence gathered during our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which EU policy objectives have been achieved, as well as the state of budgetary and financial management of the Union.
Our research is in line with the international rules of public sector control.

Planning of work Audit priorities are based on key EU issues Our work programme is adopted annually by the members of the Court.
In January 2018, President Lehne presented the 2018 work programme of the Conference of Commission Chairs of the European Parliament and asked all Parliament committees to propose potential topics for monitoring the 2019 work programme in the framework of the annual stakeholder consultation.
12 In October 2018, we published the first work programme prepared in line with the new strategy. In this 2019 work programme we presented our audit priorities and 36 analytical reports and products to be published this year.
These tasks included at least 29 out of 69 requests submitted by Parliament (42%) (2017: 32%).
In our assessments, we will continue to address key issues such as the sustainable use of natural resources, economic growth and social inclusion, migration, security and global development, the internal market and the accountability and cost-effectiveness of the EU to determine whether the EU is achieving what it has promised.
On-the-spot checks 3 761 days of audit work within and outside the EU Most of our examination work is carried out on the premises of the Court of Justice in Luxembourg.
At the same time, our auditors carry out numerous visits to the European Commission to the main body controlled by the Court, including the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and EU delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States and international organisations to which EU funds are coming in.
In addition, we carry out on-the-spot checks on beneficiaries of EU funds both within and outside the European Union.
With these checks, we can understand the audit trail and obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of the Union's policies and programmes, as well as the collection or payment of EU funds, as well as from the relevant beneficiaries13.
The frequency and intensity of our control activities in the individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of controls we have carried out.
In 2018, our auditors spent 3,761 days (2017: 3,670 days) on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU.
In the EU, our on-the-spot checks are often carried out in conjunction with the highest control authorities in the Member States visited.
In addition, our auditors spent 2,723 days (2017: 2,300 days) in the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations, OECD and audit firms.
In order to obtain and approve control evidence, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as secure data exchange and documents 14.

Combating fraud from the EU budget Nine alleged frauds In the fight against fraud from the EU budget, we work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
OLAF shall then decide on a possible investigation and shall cooperate with the authorities of the Member States if necessary.
Although our controls are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we sometimes encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraud.
In 2018, we handed over nine such cases to OLAF (2017: 13 cases) where fraud was suspected.
Further information on the nature of the suspected fraud provided to OLAF and the related recovery of funds, as recommended by OLAF, is provided in our annual reports on the EU general budget 16.
Publications New Record: the highest number of publications in 2018 Our audit reports, analyses and opinions are an important part of the EU's liability chain.
They help the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to monitor and verify that the EU achieves its political objectives and that the bodies responsible for EU financial management, in particular in the framework of the annual discharge procedure, are responsible.
This is primarily about the European Commission, but also about the other EU institutions and bodies.
National, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role in the areas of shared management, in which most of the EU budget is spent, including in the areas of agriculture and cohesion.

As regards our publications: Special and annual reports on specific reports presenting the results of selected audits on specific policy areas or expenditure or budgetary or management issues; annual reports containing mainly the results of accounting audits and audits of compliance with the rules on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund, but also on financial management and performance aspects; on the specific annual reports on EU agencies, decentralised bodies and joint undertakings.
Opinions and publications based on an analysis of opinions on new or revised legal acts having a significant impact on financial management which are mandatory under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) or are drawn up at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative; the thematic documents are descriptive and analytical policy or management documents which focus on specific topics; the Landscape analysis is similar to thematic documents; however, they focus on complex, broad policy areas or management issues, often from a cross-cutting perspective; the Rapid Case Reviews, which bring together facts relating to very clearly defined topics or problems; where necessary, they include an assessment to better understand these facts.
Finally, we provide basic information on future or ongoing control tasks in the form of control forecasts in the chapter on communication activity around our products.
All the Court's publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu) and at the end of this report.

Special reports Evaluation of the results of EU action in our Special Reports In line with the 2018-2020 strategy, we are increasingly focusing on assessing the results of EU action in order to ensure the optimal use of EU funds by EU citizens.
In 2018, we published 35 special reports (2017: 28 special reports) on the various areas of EU spending in which we discussed the challenges facing the EU, such as air pollution, the high-speed rail network, the refugee instrument in Turkey, banking supervision and funding of non-governmental organisations (NROs).
In the Special Reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically, and whether added value has been created within EU funds, i.e. whether more has been achieved than just through action at national level.
In addition, we make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, prevention of waste or more cost-effective achievement of the policy objectives.
Here we will discuss two of our 2018 special reports: a special report on high-speed railways in the EU and a special report on the refugee instrument in Turkey.
In accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, we are trying to prepare our special reports within 13 months 20.

Special report on the European high-speed rail network: not reality, but the ineffective high-speed rail carpet brings many benefits to passengers.
It is a convenient, safe, flexible and ecological means of transport.
By improving the links between the EU regions, they become more competitive and contribute to European integration by bringing people closer together.
In this way we analyzed various connections, driving times and prices for business and private travellers.
We also examined whether co-financed investments in high-speed lines were cost-effective, effective, well-thought-out and planned.
The Court found that the European high-speed rail network is only an inefficient, inefficient combination of national lines that are not interlinked.
There is no realistic long-term plan to connect different parts of the existing EU network; fast connections that cross national borders do not belong to the priorities of the individual Member States and the European Commission does not have the power to force the Member States to do so.
In these circumstances, EU co-financing for high-speed railways brings little added value.
However, there is also good news: the number of high-speed passengers in Europe is increasing steadily, and in 1990 the number increased from around 15 billion passengers to more than 124 billion in 2016.
Both institutions welcomed the report and agreed with our proposals.
We also presented it to numerous national authorities and national supervisory authorities, researchers, industry stakeholders and media.
The EU-wide media, in particular EU-oriented media and financial media, have fully addressed this report, in particular in Spain and Germany.

Special Report Special Report The Instrument for Refugees in Turkey: although helpful, the optimal use of the funds can only be achieved through improvement, Turkey, in which almost 4 million people are coming, has adopted as many refugees as no other country in the world.
About 3.5 million of these refugees are Syrians, most of whom live outside refugee camps.
The support provided by the EU and its Member States under the Refugee Instrument in Turkey for a total amount of EUR 6 billion covers humanitarian actions and not humanitarian actions in favour of refugees and host communities.
Under the political agreement, Turkey was obliged to stop irregular migration from Turkey to the EU.
Humanitarian projects have helped to meet the basic needs of refugees, but in some cases the expected optimal use of the funds and the objective of the instrument of effective coordination of this support has not been achieved.
The humanitarian projects audited provided assistance to refugees.
For example, the emergency social security network helped 1.3 million refugees by cash aid.
However, for half of the projects, the expected impacts are still positive, which can be maintained without further financial support, and nine out of ten projects had to be extended.
Early implementation of projects managed by NGOs was mainly hindered by difficult working conditions.
This was the result of the Turkish authorities refusing to grant the data to eligible beneficiaries of two cash aid projects in our sample of a total of EUR 1.1 billion of EUR 1.1 billion.
We presented our report at a joint meeting attended by the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, and then the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.
It was also presented to the Enlargement Group and the acceding countries and the press.
In particular, in Germany, this report has met with great media interest, but also in Denmark, Austria, the Benelux countries and the Mediterranean countries, as well as in the EU-oriented media.

Annual Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2017 Annual Financial Report for the financial year 2017 Annual Financial Report for the financial year 2017, full opinion on revenue control, limited opinion on expenditure control Every year we check the revenue and expenditure from the EU budget and check that the annual accounts are reliable and that the revenue and expenditure transactions comply with the financial rules of the EU and the Member States.
In addition, we assess all the main areas of the EU budget in a specific way, based on the headings of the MFF 2014-2020, based on information on budgetary and financial management and results.
We also analyse why errors have occurred, make recommendations for possible improvements and assess whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been implemented.
As part of our last annual report on the EU budget for the financial year 2017, our auditors have examined a sample of around 700 payments worth a total of EUR 100 billion to beneficiaries in various areas of EU budget expenditure.
This means that we have analysed about 700 different cases where EU funds have been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in EU Member States, or to support non-EU beneficiaries.

The downward trend in the estimated error rate remains in the scope of this broad work, which is the basis for our statement of assurance, which we must present to the European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with our mandate set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
The Court delivered an opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts and revenues, as in previous years.
In addition, in the second year in a row, we were able to deliver an opinion on EU expenditure to a limited (and not disappointed) extent.
A significant proportion of the expenditure audited in 2017 did not show a significant error rate.
In addition, the estimated error rate in payments in 2017 was 2,4% after the error rate in 2016 was 3,1 % and 3,8% in 2015.
The launch of the discharge procedure by Parliament The publication of our annual report takes place at the beginning of the discharge procedure by the European Parliament, in which, on the recommendation of the Council, the legislative authority and the EU budgetary authority in the EU, decides whether the management of the EU budget by the Commission and other bodies takes place satisfactorily.
On 4 October, we presented our annual report to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, at the same time as its publication, and then to the plenary assemblies of the European Parliament and the Economic and Financial Affairs Council, as well as to the national Parliaments and bodies of the 14 Member States.
Mr Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors and Mr Lazarou, President of the Court of Auditors, during the presentation of our annual report at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg in November 2018 28
As regards cohesion expenditure, we have assessed the control and reliability framework for 2014-2020 and the reliability of the information submitted by the Commission in order to demonstrate regularity.
This was the first step towards the possible development of a statement of assurance as a test-based test.
With the revised approach and the transition to a test-based audit, we generally intend to take more account of the different internal controls in the European Commission and in the authorities of the Member States responsible for managing EU expenditure.
It is therefore more clear where shortcomings persist both within the European Commission and in the Member States, which allows us to increase accountability and further improve the EU's financial management.
This approach shall apply only if the relevant conditions laid down in the international audit rules are met. 29
Annual report on the European Development Funds Audit Report on payments under the European Development Fund (EDF) The European Union shall support development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States and with overseas countries and territories.
The EDF shall be financed by the Member States of the Union and managed by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank outside the EU budget.

Special Annual Reports Agencies and other bodies The unlimited audit opinion for all EU agencies, with the exception of one EU agency, is based across Europe and employs around 11 000 employees.
The budget of all agencies for 2017, with the exception of the Single Committee for Restructuring and Structured Restructuring, amounted to EUR 3.5 billion, representing around 2.7% of the total EU budget.
The 2017 SRB budget financed by the contributions of credit institutions amounted to EUR 6.6 billion.
European Medicines Agency (EMA) in London, which is moving to Amsterdam New approach: one report on all 41 EU agencies In 2018, we decided to present the results of our audit in EU agencies in a more user-friendly format.
While we continued to present individual statements of assurance for each agency, we published one annual report on all agencies, including a summary document entitled "Consumer information on the audit of EU agencies."
As every year, we also publish our annual reports on European Schools and conditional commitments to the SRB, the Commission and the Council 31.

Joint Undertakings Unlimited evaluation of all European Joint Research Undertakings other than the Joint Undertaking is an EU public-private partnership with industry, research groups and Member States, which play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy.
The European Commission is a member of the public sector joint venture and represents the EU.
Private members include various partners in the industrial and research sectors.
One of the main objectives of the Joint Undertaking is to collect contributions from private sector members and research, which is their added value.

About We issued unreserved opinions on the reliability of the accounts for all agencies; on opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenues of all agencies; on opinions on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies; on opinions on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of all agencies, except for the failed opinion on the European Asylum Support Office, which identified a number of problems.
The main requests for confirmation and confirmation of the accounts of all EU Joint Undertakings for the financial year 2017. on the Seven Joint Undertakings received full audit opinions on their income and payment transactions; the Joint Undertaking on electronic components and systems for the leading role of Europe received a limited opinion on the audit, as the auditors identified problems which, in some cases, affected effective internal control.
Opinions also contribute to improving the EU's financial management by publishing opinions on the Commission's proposals for new or revised legislation.
In the case of acts having a significant financial impact, the Court's opinions are required under EU law.
They are primarily used by the legislative body of the European Parliament and of the Council.
Opinions may also be initiated at the request of other institutions or at the Court's own initiative.
In 2018, we issued ten opinions in various areas of governance in the EU.
Firstly, they concerned mainly the Commission's legislative proposals for the new multiannual financial framework, such as the reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP), the effectiveness of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and its cooperation with the future European Public Prosecutor's Office (the European Public Prosecutor's Office) and the link between EU funding and compliance with the rule of law and the protection of marginalised persons.
The CAP reform opinion calls for a greener and more coherent CAP that takes more account of accountability When the European Commission published a legislative proposal for a new CAP after 2020, it stressed that environmental and climate objectives would be given priority.
However, in our opinion on CAP reform, we have pointed out that many proposed policy options differ slightly from the current CAP system.
In particular, most of the budget will continue to be direct payments to farmers based on the number of hectares used or used.
We have also noted that this instrument is not the most cost-effective way of supporting adequate income and is therefore not taking many environmental aspects into account.
Furthermore, the Commission's assessment of the CAP's contribution to the EU's climate change objectives seems unrealistic, and the Court therefore recommends greener and more coherent, results-based plans for the next CAP, which should focus more on accountability. 34
In accordance with the procedure that we are applying in our reports, this opinion has been presented to the committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council, environmental and agricultural stakeholders and the press 35.
Analysis-based publications: Landscape analysis, Rapid Case Reviews A comprehensive analysis of publicly available information and own work of the Court of Landscape Landscape Analysis In 2018, we prepared two Landscape analyses.
In the first instance, the Court examined the application of Union law in practice and concluded that the Commission's supervisory activities in the application of Union law by the Member States should be strengthened.
In the second analysis of the Landscape programme, we have dealt with mobility and transport, and we have recognised them as the basis for European integration.
However, we have been concerned about the delays in investment, as the reduction in investment in transport infrastructure slows down the modernisation of the transport network in the EU.
Thematic documents A total of six thematic documents were published in 2018: five on the Commission proposals on the future MFF and one on the integration of migrants in the EU.
The Court's observations on the multiannual financial framework focused in particular on the proposed procedure for setting priorities for EU expenditure, the flexibility of the EU budget, the focus on the results and simplification of governance, as well as on the principles of accountability and control.
We welcomed the Commission's efforts to modernise the EU budget for the period after 2020, but at the same time showed a number of potential threats, identified a number of shortcomings and proposed concrete improvements.
We stressed the need for effective parliamentary control, fair accountability, and that the Court should, in principle, be designated as an external auditor for all bodies set up by the EU.
Rapid Case Reviews As part of the only rapid analysis submitted in 2018 on cohesion, we have discovered that the VAT refund is wrong and is not always the optimal use of EU funds.
We felt that the return of VAT to public authorities should no longer be possible in the case of expenditure co-financed by the EU in the post-2020 period 36.
Conference on Financial Instruments In January 2018, in cooperation with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Lithuania, we organised a joint high-level conference on EU financial instruments in Vilnius.
This event enabled high-level experts from EU institutions and Lithuanian institutions, experts and other public and private stakeholders to exchange views and ideas.
Symposium on public funding for parliaments In March 2018, the Court organised a two-day international symposium on public funding for European Parliaments, the aim of which was to discuss their autonomy and to analyse the budgetary systems of the EU Member States.
Global Audit Leadership Forum Leadership In April 2018, we hosted the 5th Global Audit Leadership Forum, where presidents and representatives of about twenty of the highest control bodies from around the world met.
This process mainly discussed the practice and limitations of performance control in the political context, as well as the challenges and opportunities for the transmission of control reports in the digital age37.
38 The fifth meeting of the Global Audit Forum of the Leadership Forum in April 2018, during which we took part in the European Court of Auditors in May 2018, in which we took part in the European Day events in Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg.
At the information stations, our auditors could get information about our role and work and firsthand how the controls were carried out.
We will continue to organise open days at the European Court of Auditors and participate in public events in order to make contact with citizens.
Symposium on Good Public Administration In September 2018, we took part in a symposium on UN sustainability and public governance entitled "Good Public Administration and Benefits for Citizens" on "The Role of Parliamentary Control Bodies" organised by the Austrian Court of Auditors, the Secretariat of INTOSAI and the Austrian Public Prosecutor.
The conference on the application of Union law In September 2018, we organised a conference on the application of Union law, during which the need for accountability, transparency and audit was discussed, and then as part of our analysis on the application of Union law in practice.
This event took place at the Committee of the Regions building in Brussels.
Conference on e-commerce and related taxation In October 2018, we organised a conference on e-commerce and tax challenges in the digital age.
Speakers and panel participants discussed the risks associated with the current VAT model in e-commerce and proposed alternative tax models to use modern technologies such as Blockchain.
European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority Conference (EIOPA) In November 2018, we took part in the eighth annual EIOPA conference in Frankfurt.
Over 400 people from the financial services, science, consumer organisations, media, international organisations, EU institutions and national authorities met during the conference.
The Court presented its audit work on supervision and financial stability in the European insurance sector in 2018 on the specific report on EIOPA in 2018.

Cooperation with the EU Member States' Supreme Audit Authorities (ORKB) As part of the active cooperation with the EU ORKB: Joint call to address shortcomings in EU banking oversight liability and control legislation Our cooperation with EU Member States' Supreme Audit Authorities takes place primarily within the EU-ORKB Contact Committee.
In October 2018, we actively participated in the annual meeting of the Contact Committee hosted by ORKB Croatia, the president of which was the president.
Discussions focused on interaction with EU citizens and on making public opinion available to the public.
The President of the Court of Justice, Klaus-Hein Lehne, spoke to the President of the EU-ORKB at the annual meeting of the Contact Committee in Dubrovnik, Croatia in October 2018, together with the Presidents of the highest control bodies of the 28 Member States, called on the governments and national parliaments, as well as on the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission to address a number of shortcomings in the rules on accountability and control of EU banking supervision.
In addition, the Court has participated and participated in the activities of several working bodies of the Contact Committee, including the Value Added Tax Working Party, the Financial Policy Assessment Network, the Europe 2020 Assessment Network and the European Banking Union Task Force, as well as other activities in the field of financial reporting in the public sector and the evaluation of public procurement.

INTOSAI/EUROSAI In 2018 we continued active participation and participation in the activities of the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Authorities (INTOSAI), in particular in our role as Vice-President of the Technical Standards Committee (since December 2016) and member of the Audit and Accounting Sub-Committee, the Sub-Committee for the Verification of Compliance with Legal Standards and the Sub-Committee for Economic Audit.
We have also actively participated in the activities of other INTOSAI bodies, including the work of the evaluation subcommittee, the environmental evaluation working group, the working group on financial modernisation and regulatory reform, and the task force on the professionalisation of auditors.

Our management of the College of Members of the Court The term of office of Members of the Court lasts six years, with the possibility of renewal.
The College shall be composed of one member of each Member State.
The Court shall not take part in the appointment and appointment of members.
In 2018, the Council appointed four new members of the Court: about Eva Lindström (Sweden), Tony Murphy (Ireland) and Hannu Takkula (Finland) on 1 March 2018 and Annemie Turtelboom (Belgium) on 1 May 2018.
In addition, by 29 February 2024 the Council extended the mandates of five members of its own members: Pietro Russo (Italy), Baudilio in the São Tomé (Spain), Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) and João Figueiredo (Portugal) and Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria) until 31 December 2024.
18 meetings of the College of Members of the Court took place in 2018 (2017: 21).
