The role of the President is one of the first-rate (Primus inter Pares).
Its competences include the institution's strategy, performance planning and management, communication and the media, legal issues and internal audit.
The Court shall represent all its external relations.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected President.
Klaus-Hein Lehne, President of the Court, during the annual meeting of the College of Members of the Court and the College of Commissioners in Luxembourg in February 2018 47
President and Members 48
The audit chambers and committees shall be assigned to one of the five audit chambers of the Court.
They shall be governed by the leadership of Doyen or Doyenne chosen from among the members.
Each member shall be responsible for his or her specific tasks and shall be assisted by his or her office.
The examination work shall be carried out by professional examiners working for the management of the examination chambers.
In December 2018, five examination chambers were led by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Millionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Neven Mates and Lazaros S. Lazarou.
Danièle Lamarque presided over the Quality Control Committee and Oscar Herics presided over our ethics committee and Jereb himself our audit committee, while Rimantas Šadžius was a member of the Committee on Institutional Relations.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, the Chair of which shall be the Chair.
The European Court of Auditors consists of ten Directorates-General for all its areas of work, five of which belong to the audit chambers, one for audit quality control, one for President and three for Secretary-General.

Effects and perception of our work Our reports are effective and effective We are assessing the impact and perception of our work on the basis of the assessments carried out by the addressees. Another criterion of the evaluation is further action on the basis of our recommendations on improving the EU's financial management.
At the beginning of 2018, we started to call on stakeholders (the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, EU agencies, permanent representations of Member States, public authorities of Member States, national supervisory authorities, non-governmental organisations, science, media, etc.) to provide feedback on the adequacy and likely impact of our reports.
The feedback shall relate to selected special reports and analyses and to the Court's annual reports and shall be collected by anonymous electronic surveys from all who have previously received a copy of those reports.
This study will also allow stakeholders to provide qualitative feedback on reports and provide general proposals on the Court's work.
In total 87% of respondents confirmed the usefulness of our reports for their work and 78% confirmed their effectiveness.

Monitoring our recommendations Most of our recommendations have been implemented since 2018 instead of the European Commission's management declaration we use as the basis for this indicator of action taken by our controllers.

This analysis shows that 74% of the recommendations made by us in our 2014 Annual Report and 94% of the recommendations made in our 2014 Special Reports have been fully, largely or partially implemented.

Support for control activities Vocational training Vocational training: In this way we equip our employees and the Court for the future In line with the recommendations issued by the International Accounting Federation (IFAC), we try to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training per year.
In 2018, we again exceeded this goal, reaching 6.9 days of training for one controller.
We continued to expand the scope of the training that we offer to employees both in the area of control and beyond, and we supported controllers in obtaining different certificates.
We continued our successful series of presentations organised by internal or external experts on the development of audit or other issues related to the work of our auditors.
We continued the Performance Recognition Awards programme, which allows employees who do not hold management positions to participate in specialized external trainings.

Information, working environment and innovation Our Directorate for Information, the Labour and Innovation Environment supports our employees in the efficient and efficient use of information technologies by supporting innovation and knowledge management.
Information Management We have launched a new initiative called TECAway, which provides our employees with access to the network.
This will enable them to access the Court's digital resources and services on all devices, anywhere and at any time.
The Court has created a new harmonised document management system and has created multi-functional printing, photocopying and scanning devices.
We expect these devices to have a beneficial impact on information security and paper consumption.
In addition, we have introduced a new model for cybersecurity management and we are currently working on implementing a cybersecurity plan.
All IT projects and IT solutions have taken due account of the maintenance of the business, thus ensuring the full availability of critical systems.
Innovation We have also established ECAlab, an interdisciplinary innovation laboratory, whose main aim is to digitise the scope of control through the use of data and the use of technology.
ECAlab tests the use of technologies such as artificial intelligence, natural language processing and text mining in real test tasks.
This support has already provided a number of tasks and publications.
In addition, we have carried out a pilot project on the use of blocking technologies for the notarial certificate of verification and publication.
The ECA register was chosen by the European Blockchain Partnership (ECA register) within the European Blockchain Infrastructure (ECA register) as part of the services developed since 2019 by the EU Member States and the Commission.
Knowledge Management In July 2018, our first summer course in public financial control was held, organized jointly with the University of Pisa and the Accounting Association (ACCA) (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants) (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants).
45 people from ORB, EU institutions and universities took part in the summer course, which focused on the analysis of the data for examinations.
We also organised a conference on blockchain, during which we examined the opportunities offered by the technology and its practical applications for the control of EU spending.
This conference was addressed mainly to participants from other EU institutions.

The EuRH "K1" building and the new security control centre at Rue Alcide De Gasperi, Luxembourg The environmental management system as an institution of the European Union is our duty to respect the principle of sound environmental management in all activities.
We are therefore constantly trying to reduce the Court's environmental impact.
Currently, we successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully comply with the certification requirements set out in ISO 14001:2015.
As part of our objective of systematically reducing CO2 emissions, we regularly examine greenhouse gas emissions caused by our actions.
In 2017, total greenhouse gas emissions amounted to 10 451 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), a 3% decrease compared to 2016.
2018 was the fourth year in a row during which the Court examined its CO2 footprint.
67 The Court's liability The Court's financial information is financed by the general budget of the European Union and its budget falls within the scope of administrative expenditure.
In 2018, the Court's budget was around EUR 146 million.
This represents less than 0,1% of the total EU expenditure or around 1.5% of the total EU administrative expenditure.
The budget share for 2018 was 96%.

Internal audit and external audit Internal audit body shall advise the Court on risk management issues.
It provides independent and objective guarantees and advice to increase and improve the added value of the Court's activities.
In addition, they shall report to the Internal Audit Committee, consisting of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor the progress made in the implementation of the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the internal audit body and shall ensure its independence.
In 2018, she carried out a review of the Court's cyber security systems and the construction work related to its protection.
These services have also examined the implementation by the Court of the risk management policy and the annual declarations by the authorising officer by delegation.
The Commission has also monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations to ensure that the agreed action plans are being shaped.
In 2018, the audits carried out by the services did not reveal any shortcomings which, due to their nature or scope, could seriously undermine the overall credibility of the internal control systems which were introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations.
Every year we report to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same principles of transparency and accountability as those of the authorities it has carried out.
The auditor's report on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2017 was published on 17 May 2018 on 17 May 2018. 70

Regarding the use of resources and the Court's audit procedure: "In the framework of our actions described in this report, we have not found ourselves in a situation in which we would have to state that, in all relevant matters and in the light of the above evaluation criteria, the resources allocated to the Court have not been used for the intended purposes and that the audit procedures established do not ensure that the financial transactions have been carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations in force."
The discharge, like the other EU institutions, is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2018, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2016.
As every year, we have carefully analysed the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our responsibility for audit and management, we have taken the appropriate steps, and we have discussed in detail our follow-up to the European Parliament.
On 26 March 2019 the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge for the financial year 2017.
This means that our annual accounts were finally approved for 2017.

European Court of Auditors 5 Who we are about the European Union's external auditor; what was created in 1975 under the Treaty of Brussels; what we are about to do in October 1977; what we are about the Maastricht Treaty of 1993 is the EU institution; what we are about the EU's headquarters in Luxembourg; what is one member from each EU Member State, appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament; what is about 900 workers from all EU Member States.
Our role in ensuring that the EU ensures sound financial management, correctly applies its financial rules and achieves its objectives through its policies and programmes, and ensures that financial resources are used optimally.We warn against risks, ensure security of control, point to weaknesses and successes and give guidance to policy makers and EU legislators. to present our comments and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council, the governments and national parliaments and the general public.
2019 was the year of many changes for the Union: the elections to the European Parliament took place and the new European Commission joined it.
The strategic priorities have been re-defined and important package measures have been launched, such as the European Green Agreement and the European Digital Future (early 2020).
At the end of the year it became clear that we would now be a Union of 27 Member States.
At the same time, the EU is at an important financial crossroads.
We are in the process of negotiating the next multiannual financial framework, the results of which will be crucial for the financial capacity of the Union over the next seven years.
All EU institutions must now build on their efforts to further improve EU financial management and ensure that the EU delivers results.
As an external auditor, we offer an impartial assessment of the Union's policies and programmes and the quality of the EU's financial management within and outside the Union.
We are checking whether EU expenditure is in line with the rules whether EU policies and programmes ensure the optimal use of resources.
This activity report provides an overview of our work in 2019 in which we have published a wide range of latest special reports, analyses and opinions.
You will also find information about our employees, management and finance.
We hope that this information will be useful.
We are publishing this year's activity report at a time when public health in the EU and in the Member States is facing an unprecedented challenge due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our institution responded quickly to this situation in accordance with the Luxembourg Government's health and safety instructions.
I would like to thank all my colleagues for their good work and their willingness to adapt flexibly to the current situation.
We must now act together and make every effort to continue to act as an external EU controller in these difficult times.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President 6
7 2019 at a glance
8 Our actions Strategy To continue public financial control, we rely on multi-annual strategies to take long-term decisions on our control work and to take initiatives on organisational changes to continuously improve.
At the end of 2019 we completed the second year of the current strategy for the years 2018-2020.
During this three-year period, we have defined the following strategic objectives: increasing the added value of the Statement of Assurance; increasing the focus on the aspects of the effectiveness of EU action; providing clear information for our addressees.
To achieve our strategy, we have agreed on an action plan that includes these objectives.
Over the last two years, we have made good progress towards achieving our strategic objectives.
A number of initiatives and projects have been launched for all of the areas identified, which sometimes go even beyond the scope of the Action Plan, in particular the pilot phase of the test-based audit approach in order to produce a statement of assurance, which has led to useful results; a significant increase in the number of audits and analytical products, as well as a wider range of issues, covering both EU expenditure and regulatory action; better contacts with the European Parliament, as well as greater visibility in traditional and social media.
During the year, a group of the four highest audit bodies (Estonia, the Netherlands, Denmark and the United States) carried out a peer review of our strategy.
The report of our colleagues was published in March 2020, just in time to support our next strategy, starting in 2021.
Good progress on the implementation of the strategy 9
Monitoring the efficiency and regularity of EU operations Performance control, accounting audits and compliance audits Our performance audits take into account the efficiency, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes.
It focuses on issues relevant to the EU, such as sustainable and environmentally sustainable use of natural resources, economic growth and social inclusion, migration and global development challenges, the internal market and the banking union, and ensuring the accountability and cost-effectiveness of the European Union.
These controls aim at helping the EU achieve its policy objectives better.
Our accounting checks and compliance checks lead to the assurance of the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
In addition, we can carry out selected conformity checks to examine or assess the Union's budgetary and financial management, whether the management and control systems established for the collection and use of EU funds comply with EU and national rules in force.
Our controls are in line with international public sector controls. 10
Work Programme Strategic perspectives In 2019 we continued to integrate the strategic perspective into our audit work to better address the major future challenges for the EU through a future-oriented approach.
To this end, we have set up an advisory committee on strategies and perspectives.
One of the Committee's ongoing tasks, consisting of five members, is to monitor the development of the post-2020 strategy.
The audit priorities for EU future issues Our work programme was published in October 2019 in which we present our audit priorities for the coming years and 41 reports and analyses to be published for 2020.
Our audits planned for 2020 and beyond will continue to provide EU citizens and policy makers with independent reports on issues relevant to the future of the EU.
We draw up a work programme for our exams in an independent way, but not in complete isolation from our surroundings.
It is therefore extremely important that we cooperate with our institutional stakeholders, especially the European Parliament.
As usual, at the beginning of 2019, all parliamentary committees asked to propose possible audit topics of our work programme. 11
On-site work Most of our examination work takes place in our rooms in Luxembourg.
Our auditors also carry out numerous visits to the European Commission to our main body verified at the same time as other EU institutions and EU agencies and bodies, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, EU delegations in third countries and international organisations in receipt of EU funds.
In addition, we carry out on-the-spot checks in the EU and beyond with the beneficiaries of EU funds.
With these controls, we can understand the audit trail and obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes and in the collection or payment of EU funds and from the beneficiaries of such funds.
In line with the objective set out in the EU Financial Regulation, we are trying to complete the audits we have chosen within 13 months 12.
3 605 days of on-site verification work within and outside the EU Our examination teams usually consist of two to three examiners, and the duration of the verification visit may be several days, but may also be several weeks.
In the EU, our on-the-spot checks are generally coordinated with the highest audit authorities of the Member States concerned.
13 The frequency and intensity of our control activities in the individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of controls we have carried out.
In 2019 our auditors spent 3 605 days (2018: 3 671 days) on on-the-spot checks in the Member States and outside the EU.
In addition, our auditors spent 2504 days (2018: 2 723 days) in the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as in decentralised agencies and agencies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations, OECD and audit firms.
In order to interact with our research units, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as secure data and documents exchange. 14
Audit reports, analyses and opinions Our audit reports, analyses and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
They assist the European Parliament and the Council in monitoring and verifying the achievement of the EU's policy objectives and in clearing the bodies responsible for EU financial management in particular in the framework of the annual discharge procedure.
Special reports and analysis products In line with our strategy for 2018-2020 in recent years, we have focused more on assessing the results of EU action.
In 2019 we published 36 special reports and analyses, which address many of the challenges facing the Union in various areas of EU spending, such as food security, renewable energy, e-commerce, border controls, budgetary management and the ethical framework in selected EU institutions, in order to mention only some of them 15.
16 In the special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically and whether the EU's actions bring added value, i.e. whether more has been achieved than the actions taken at national level.
In addition, we make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, prevention of waste, or more effective achievement of the policy objectives.
Our analyses are often aimed at providing descriptions and analytical analyses from a cross-cutting perspective and on the basis of previous studies or other publicly available information.
They can also serve as a presentation of our analysis of areas or issues that have not yet been investigated or present facts on specific issues or problems.
Unlike exams, they do not deal with assessment issues, nor do they guarantee credibility.
17 Sustainable exploitation of natural resources Analysis 01/2019: EU response to the diesel scandal In 2015, differences were detected between the exhaust values of the test bench and the exhaust values of the road.
Studies have shown that so-called "cut-off devices" have been used that have resulted in lower emissions during official tests than during normal driving.
The type-approval authorities of certain Member States have responded to the exhaust scandal through the re-test of diesel engines.
These studies have shown that almost all light diesel vehicles of Euro 5 and Euro 6 have significantly exceeded the NOx limit values of road vehicles, in some cases by more than 10 times.
We have considered measures taken by both the EU and the Member States in response to the diesel scandal.
We also took into account the changes introduced after September 2015 in the exhaust emission measurement system.
We have noted that many legal changes in the EU type-approval and vehicle emission testing system have been adopted in an accelerated manner.
The Commission is currently empowered to verify the work of the national type-approval authorities and to carry out vehicle tests and to withdraw or suspend type-approval.
Interested third parties may now carry out emission tests.
The Commission has also opened infringement proceedings against certain Member States.
We have also noted that in several Member States there has been an increased readiness to reduce traffic in order to improve air quality, and in several European cities low-carbon zones have been created in which motor traffic is limited or prohibited.
We have presented the results of our work in the form of an analysis, because in the near future the legislative changes introduced will have no tangible impact.
Our analysis does not make recommendations.
18 Investment for Cohesion, Growth and Integration Special Report No 08/2019: Wind and solar energy for electricity generation: the achievement of the EU's objectives requires significant efforts in electricity generation from non-renewable energy sources such as fossil fuels, non-renewable waste and nuclear fuels in conventional reactors, or renewable energy sources such as water, wind and solar energy, biomass, etc.
Renewable energy sources also serve the production of heat and cooling and fuel production for the transport sector.
Currently, 79% of total EU greenhouse gas emissions come from the use of fossil fuels for energy production.
Increasing the share of renewable energy in electricity production will contribute to the EU's greenhouse gas reduction target.
Member States shall determine how they make best use of their energy resources and how they organise their energy supplies.
The EU can support Member States' efforts through additional funds to invest in renewable energy projects.
We have assessed the progress made by the EU and the Member States in achieving the renewable energy target in order to achieve the EU's overall target of 20% by 2020 and 32% by 2030.
In Germany, Greece, Spain and Poland, we checked whether the support for wind and photovoltaic electricity generation was effective.
We have noted that there has been significant progress since 2005 in the share of renewable energy in the energy mix, but this trend has been slowed since 2014.
The share of renewable energy in electricity production in the EU increased from around 15% in 2015 to around 31% in 2017 and doubled.
Wind and solar energy are technologies that have contributed most to this growth.
However, achieving the objectives will be a major challenge for around half of the Member States.
We recommended that the Commission encourage Member States to promote further development by organising auctions for additional renewable energy capacities, promoting greater participation by citizens, simplifying administrative procedures and removing shortcomings in the networks.
In addition, we recommended that the Commission review the legal requirements for the Member States in order to improve the timeliness of statistical data.
19 External policy, security and justice Special Report No 24/2019: Asylum, relocation and return of migrants: time to step up efforts to eliminate disparities between objectives and results In 2015, the European Union experienced an unprecedented influx of migrants, followed by an increase in the number of asylum applications.
In recent years, the number of immigrants has returned to pre-crisis levels.
We interviewed the staff of the European Commission, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (hereinafter Frontex).
Monitoring visits were carried out by national authorities, international organisations and non-governmental organisations implementing EU-funded projects, as well as 20 EU support actions in Greece and Italy.
Both Member States are particularly affected by these migration flows.
We assessed whether the objectives of EU-funded support had been achieved and the asylum and return procedures had been achieved effectively and quickly.
We also checked whether the objectives and objectives of the temporary emergency relocation system had been achieved.
We noticed that hotspots significantly improved the rates of registration and fingerprinting.
Nevertheless, many migrants continue to move to other EU Member States and apply for asylum without storing fingerprints in the Eurodac database.
In addition, asylum procedures continue to continue for a long time and a narrow throat in both Member States.
A large proportion of applicants were transferred to Italy (80% in Greece and 89% in Italy).
However, since February 2018, the Commission has not monitored the relocation process in host countries.
As in other EU countries, return rates from Greece and Italy are low.
We recommended that the next Commission take appropriate action to improve the management of emergency aid.
In addition, the Commission should take advantage of past experience in the development of future voluntary relocation mechanisms.
Finally, EASO's support for asylum procedures should be increased and Frontex's support for return operations should be adapted.
20 Market regulation and a competitive economy Special Report No 10/2019: EU-wide stress tests for banks: the need for as much information as possible on banks but greater coordination and risk concentration The aim of the EU-wide stress test for banks is to assess the possible impact that a joint shock can have on the financial situation and profitability of large European banks.
The European Banking Authority (EBA) in cooperation with the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) shall be responsible for initiating and coordinating EU-wide stress tests on banks.
Stress tests have been carried out in the EU since 2011, all of which have been carried out on the basis of a bottom-up approach, with banks reporting the results of a shock scenario based on a methodology approved by EBA.
We assessed the implementation of the EU-wide stress test in the banking sector in the framework of the mandate granted to EBA.
We found that at the beginning of the procedure EBA did not specify either the risks or the weight they considered relevant to the stress test procedure.
The ESRB, which has developed a stress scenario, has, in turn, received significant contributions from the ECB and national central banks and public authorities.
As a result, EBA had no control over the relevant stages of the procedure.
In the United States, the supervisory authorities are based on a top-down approach, which gives them much more control over the performance of the banks.
On the other hand, EBA's role in the EU is limited to the launch of stress tests, the provision of methodology and coordination of stress tests to a broad extent.
The EBA stress test assessed the vulnerability of the system and banks to the economic downturn and not to the severe financial shocks affecting the system.
Although EBA has sought wide coverage, some risk-bearing banks have been excluded from the stress test.
The bottom-up approach of EBA has led to a limited credibility and comparability of the results of the banks.
We recommended that EBA strengthen control of the stress test and develop a top-down approach to complement the current bottom-up approach.
Furthermore, in order to achieve the objective of assessing resilience to adverse market developments, future stress tests should take due account of the risks of the EU financial system, ensure a minimum level of stress and provide clear information on the resilience of banks.
Finally, the choice of banks for stress tests should be made not only by size but also by risk.
21 EU funding and management Special Report No 14/2019: "Your opinion counts!"
The public consultation carried out by the Commission includes citizens, but the lack of information activities "better lawmaking" aims at ensuring an open and transparent policy decision-making process based on the best facts available and carried out by citizens and other stakeholders, such as civil society organisations and representative organisations, which are fully involved.
The Commission shall consult citizens and representative organisations in all areas of Union action.
The Better Regulation Guidelines define consultation of stakeholders, including citizens as "interested stakeholders."

The Commission has an average of over 100 public consultations per year.
We assessed whether the public consultation carried out by the Commission effectively contributed to reaching out to citizens and stakeholders and to making use of their contributions.
We have examined the structure of the Commission's framework, how the Commission has prepared and carried out the selection of the public consultation and how it has provided information on the consultation activities and how it has benefited from the consultation.
Between 2016 and 2018, we tested the sample of 26 public consultations carried out by the Commission by the five Directorates-General and carried out a public opinion poll to determine to what extent the public consultation participants were actually satisfied.
We have noted that the Commission's public consultation framework has a high standard.
Moreover, the overall public consultation attempt with the Commission showed a positive balance sheet and its perception by the participants was generally satisfactory.
The shortcomings were detected in information activities and information activities, for example, the whole range of communication channels was not always used, there were no clear criteria to justify why the questionnaire was not available in all the official languages of the EU and some questionnaires were long and complex.
We recommended that public consultation advertising be more targeted and targeted in order to increase visibility and to allow more people to participate in the consultation.
We also encouraged the Commission to report better on the follow-up to public consultation.
Finally, there is potential for improving citizens' participation in initiating legislative proposals under the European Citizens' Initiative.
Audit forecast Audit projections provide information on current audit tasks (in terms of economic audit).
They shall be based on preparatory work carried out prior to the start of the checks and shall serve as a source of information for those who are interested in specific policy areas and/or programmes which are subject to ongoing checks.
In 2019 we published 18 exam forecasts (2018: 12).
Annual reports and special annual reports The annual reports mainly contain the results of our statement of assurance of the budget of the European Union and the European Development Fund (EDF).
The special annual reports shall include the results of the annual audit of the annual accounts of the agencies, decentralised agencies and EU Joint Undertakings and European Schools.
In addition, we publish a report on conditional obligations arising from the implementation of the Single Committee on Restructuring and Structured Restructuring and Structured Restructuring 22.
Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2018 Each year we review EU revenue and expenditure to verify that the annual accounts are reliable and that the revenue and expenditure transactions underlying them comply with the relevant EU and Member State legislation.
In addition, we present detailed evaluations on all the main areas of the EU budget, based on the (sub) headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2014-2020.
We are also looking at why and where errors have been made, we are making recommendations for improving and assessing whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been implemented.
Finally, we provide information on budgetary and financial management and information on results.
This extensive work is the basis for our statement of assurance, which we must present to the European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with our mandate set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
EU general budget: opinion on the reliability of accounts and revenue: Limited opinion on expenditure In 2018, EU expenditure amounted to EUR 156.7 billion, representing 2.2% of the EU Member State's total expenditure and 1% of the EU's gross national income.
Our auditors examined a sample of 728 payments to beneficiaries in all spending areas in the EU budget, based on a population surveyed of around EUR 120 billion.
This means that we have analysed various cases where EU funds have been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries outside the EU.
For the 2018 financial year, we have issued an unreserved opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts and revenues.
In addition, in the third year in a row, we were able to present a limited opinion on EU expenditure 23.
About half of the expenditure audited does not show a significant error rate, as in previous years, it was found that the errors in EU expenditure were not exhaustive and that the payments were legal and regular, with the exception of high risk expenditure (mainly expenditure related to reimbursement, based on complex rules).
24 Overall, the Commission and the Member States maintained the error rate of 2.6% compared to the progress of the two previous years (financial year 2017: 2,4%; financial year 2016: 3,1 %).
We find this an encouraging sign.
What does that mean?
A mistake or incorrect payment is the amount of funds that could not be paid out of the EU budget because they have not been used in accordance with EU or national rules and are therefore not in line with the objectives set by the Council and Parliament or are in conflict with specific national rules in the Member States.
We evaluate the error rate by statistical methods, based on measurable (i.e. measurable measurable) errors that we have identified by checking the sample of transactions in the entire population of expenditure.
The most erroneous issue of the MFF: Economic, social and territorial cohesion In the financial year 2018, the area of "economic, social and territorial cohesion" was the most erroneous part of the MFF, followed by "Natural Resources" and "Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs" 25.
Annual report on the European Development Fund: Opinion on the reliability of accounts and revenue: Opinion on revenue; Limited Opinion on expenditure 26 European Development Fund (EDF) are the main instruments of EU development cooperation assistance.
The EFF aims to combat poverty and promote sustainable development and the integration of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States and the overseas countries and territories into the world economy.
The EFF shall be financed by the Member States of the Union and managed by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB) outside the Union budget.
As in previous years, in respect of the financial year 2018, we issued an opinion without reservation on the reliability of EDF accounts and revenue, as well as on a limited opinion on EDF expenditure.
Special annual reports on EU agencies and joint enterprises EU agencies are separate entities with legal personality, set up to perform specific technical and scientific tasks and administrative tasks, thus contributing to the formulation and implementation of the policies of the EU institutions.
There are 43 agencies in total.
Joint enterprises are EU public-private partnerships with industry, research groups and Member States, which play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy.
The European Commission is a member of the public sector joint venture and represents the EU.
In total, there are eight joint ventures.

In October 2019 we presented our annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the EDF of the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, followed by the plenary session of the European Parliament, the Council (ECOFIN) and the national parliaments and bodies of the 21 Member States.

Opinions Opinions: a contribution to better lawmaking One way to strengthen the Commission's approach to better lawmaking is to publish an opinion on the Commission's proposals for new or revised legislation.
In the case of legislative proposals having a significant financial impact, the Court's opinions are required, in accordance with EU law.
In addition, other institutions may ask us to give an opinion on specific issues.
Our opinions will be forwarded to the European Parliament and the Council.
In 2019 we published three opinions: on the proposal for a European Union Office for Intellectual Property, the proposal for a Financial Regulation of the Single Committee for Restructuring and Structured Restructuring and Structured Resolution and the proposal for a Financial Regulation of the Community Plant Variety Office.
Our comments on the new Multiannual Financial Framework at the beginning of 2019 also published a summary of the ECA's comments on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027.
This summary focuses on the proposed procedure for setting EU spending priorities, the flexibility of the EU budget, the focus on results and the simplification of governance, as well as on accountability and audit principles.
This analysis was mainly based on several opinions on the Commission proposals that we issued in 2018, but also on our latest thematic documents and other reports on EU funding.
We have achieved a relatively balanced number of publications throughout the year, reaching a climax in October, when we published our annual reports.
31 32 Combating fraud to the detriment of the EU's financial interests The Administrative Agreement signed with OLAF The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is at the heart of the fight against fraud to the detriment of the EU's financial interests.
We have adopted detailed guidelines for the management of the risk of fraud for our auditors.
We are giving OLAF any suspicion of fraud or any other illegal activity to the detriment of the EU's financial interests which arise during our audit work or which are reported to us.
These cases are then dealt with by OLAF, which shall decide on a possible investigation and, if necessary, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2019 we also signed an administrative agreement setting out the operational rules for our cooperation with OLAF, including the coordination of training, workshops and the exchange of staff.
10 cases of alleged fraud were addressed to OLAF We are the external auditors of the EU.
Our attempts are not specifically designed to detect fraud.
However, our auditors regularly identify a number of cases where they suspect that they are engaged in fraudulent activities.
In 2019 we submitted 10 suspected cases of fraud to OLAF (2018: nine cases), including nine cases we encountered during our audits, as well as two cases that have affected third party attention.
Further information on the nature of the suspected fraud and on its recovery, as recommended by OLAF, is provided in our annual report on the EU general budget.
In 2019 we also published two special reports, which are closely related to the fight against fraud in EU expenditure: Special Report No 01/2019 on combating fraud in EU expenditure: action should be taken and Special Report No 06/2019 on combating fraud in EU expenditure: Managing authorities must step up action on detection, response and coordination.
33 Finally, we have devoted a special edition of the ECA newspaper to combat fraud and corruption and to protect the EU's financial interests.

Our governance The members of the European Court of Human Rights act as the collegial body of each Member State.
After the appointment by the relevant national government, each Member shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament.
We will not play any role in the appointment and appointment of members.
They shall take a solemn undertaking in this respect before the Court of Justice of the European Union at the time of their entry into office.

The impact and perception of our work 88% of stakeholders believe that our audit reports are useful We assess the likely impact and usefulness of our audit work on the basis of feedback from our stakeholders from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the EU agencies, the permanent representations of the Member States, the public authorities of the Member States and the European Economic and Social Committee, non-governmental organisations, science, the media and other parties.
Since 2018, we have been asking our stakeholders for an opinion on the selection of special reports and analyses and on the annual report through anonymous electronic surveys.
These studies will enable interested parties to comment on the quality of the reports and to make general proposals on the Court's work.
A total of 88% of respondents confirmed the relevance of our reports to their work in 2019 and 81% confirmed their effectiveness.
52 Monitoring our recommendations Almost all of our recommendations are implemented We determine the state of play of our recommendations on the basis of the actions taken by our controllers.
In 2019 we analysed the recommendations presented in our special reports published in 2015 and in the annual report of the same year.
This analysis shows that 96% of the recommendations made by us in our 2015 Annual Report and 94% of the recommendations in our Special Reports published in 2015 have been fully, largely or partially implemented 53.

Information technology, work environment and innovation The transition to cloud-based services The transition to cloud-based services is an important milestone that provides an easy-to-use system for various end-user applications (IT, personnel, office, security, etc.).
The new IT Security Action Plan has achieved a number of objectives, such as a more effective and regular removal of software barriers, preventing unauthorised access to cloud services, control of information security management and improvement of security oversight capabilities.
Finally, an ambitious technical programme was implemented in 2019 to provide facilities and systems to enable all workers to operate more flexibly, e.g. office, teleconferences and mobile work.

The Farm Building currently has three buildings ("K1, "K2" and "K3"), which constitute one integrated technical unit.
K1 K1 building opened in 1988 includes office rooms for up to 310 staff and conference rooms.
In the bullets there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses, library and main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical installations.
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 in order to adapt it to national health, safety and environmental requirements.
Where possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adapted to ensure compliance with the K2 and K3 buildings.
In the bullets there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses and a fitness centre.
Other missiles are used in offices for up to 241 staff, in which there are conference rooms, conference room with translation cabins, video conference room, café and simple kitchen rooms.
We are currently modernising the K2 building to optimise the organisation of its working areas and to update certain technical installations.
In 2019 a detailed study of this project was carried out and work started at the end of the year.
In accordance with the March 2014 Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Court will use the remaining budgetary resources from the construction project K3 completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation 61.
In the bullets there are parking lots, technical equipment, warehouses, warehouses, warehouses, waste storage facilities, printers, kitchens and archives.
In addition, in this building there are offices for 503 employees, conference rooms and IT room.
Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method (BREEAM) is rated as "very good" 62 on the basis of the world's leading "Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method" (BREEAM).
Further increasing our security measures In 2019 we took a number of measures to increase the security of our buildings in Luxembourg.
Among them was the establishment of a team of armed security personnel.
We have an agreement with the Luxembourg police, which allows us to use national training centres.
Furthermore, we have agreed with the European External Action Service that we will support our auditors in their visits to high-risk countries.
63 Eduardo Ruiz García, Secretary General of EuRH and Helga Schmid, Secretary General of the EEAS.
Environmental governance As an EU institution, we have an obligation to respect the principle of sound environmental management in all activities.
We continue to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions and regularly analyse greenhouse gas emissions caused by our actions.
In 2018, total greenhouse gas emissions amounted to 10 178 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), representing a 3% reduction compared to 2017.
We are proud of our EMAS certification for environmental management and audit: we successfully run an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
In the last quarter of 2019, an external EMAS audit was carried out, which led to the renewal of EMAS certification for the period 2020-2022.
New initiatives such as the "Plastic ESRB" initiative will be implemented as planned.
In 2019, in cooperation with the Luxembourg Ministry of Agriculture, we also created four hives in our gardens.
Bees are supervised by volunteers.
We assume that this will have a positive impact on the sustainability of pollinators in our surroundings 64.
The Court's liability The Court's financial information is financed by the general budget of the European Union and its budget falls under the heading of administrative expenditure.
In 2019 our budget was around 147 million euro, of which 98% was used during the year.
This represents less than 0,1% of the total EU expenditure or around 1.5% of the total EU administrative expenditure.

Internal audit and external audit Internal audit body shall advise the Court on issues relating to risk management.
It provides independent and objective guarantees and advice to increase and improve the added value of the Court's activities.
In addition, they shall report to the Internal Audit Committee, consisting of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor progress in the implementation of the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the internal audit body and shall ensure its independence.
In 2019, the Internal Audit Service carried out three selected tasks: "the risks and challenges of the Audit Quality Control Committee', "the travel costs of high-level members and officials, costs for the representation of members and the use of the Court's fleet' and "the Court's vocational training'.
In addition, our risk management strategy and three annual declarations of sub-delegated authorising officers have been examined.
In addition, the Internal Audit Department monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations, ensuring that the agreed action plans were implemented, and advised on issues related to the Court's new internal control framework.
Our internal auditor has not demonstrated any shortcomings which, due to their nature or scope, could seriously undermine the overall credibility of internal control systems; the control systems were introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations in 2019.
External audit Our financial statements are audited by an independent external auditor.
This study is very important because it shows that we apply the same principles of transparency and accountability to ourselves as to the bodies we study.
The auditor's report on the Court's accounts for the financial year 2018 was published on 4 April 2019. 67

DE EUROPEAN COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF COURT OF AUDITORS 2013 Brief information on the EU review Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2014 ISBN 978-92-872-0998-6 doi:10.2865/23970 © European Union, 2014 Reproduction is authorised provided the source is acknowledged.
PL 2013 Brief information on the EU review Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Preface by the President 02 Each year in November, the European Court of Auditors shall present the results of its annual audits of the EU financial management in the previous financial year.
On the basis of the audit evidence obtained, the Court guarantees the reliability of the use of EU funds and stresses the extent to which the risk that EU funds have not been fully used has been the greatest.
The reports also contain recommendations on possible improvements in EU financial management.
In this way, the Court supports the European Parliament and the Council in the review of EU expenditure and contributes to the effective performance of the calculation duties towards EU citizens.
This Shorter Shorter Shorter Shorter Shorter Shorter Shorter EU Verification presented and explained the most important findings in our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget in 2013 or through the European Development Fund.
As in previous years, reports show to what extent the bodies responsible for the financial management of the EU and at national level have fully demonstrated the management of the financial resources, ensured the application of EU financial rules and complied with the basic principles of savings, efficiency and efficiency.
2013 was the last year of the seven-year programming period and we publish our progress reports for this financial year during a transitional period of major importance for the EU and its finances.
As our reports show, the new European Parliament and the new Commission have faced the long-standing and new challenges of financial management and accountability in the current 2014-2020 programming period.
Continued emphasis on EU and national finances requires careful management and control of EU funds and better forecasting of long-term financing needs.
In particular, we stress in our reports that the Commission and the authorities of the Member States in their EU budget should make greater efforts to ensure that EU funds are used to achieve results that could otherwise not be achieved in an equally effective or effective way.
At the same time, the Court's audit results show that further action can and should be taken to ensure that EU action is in line with the rules.
The Court will be pleased to take the opportunity to help the new European Parliament and the Commission to address these and other problems related to financial management and calculation obligations at EU level.
To this end, on the basis of our experience with control, we have also prepared two land control analyses, which have identified the main challenges facing the EU in terms of computing, auditing and financial management.
Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva CALDEIRA President of the European Court of Auditors

Overall results 04 Main conclusions Summary of the 2013 Statement of Assurance The European Court of Auditors (ECA, Court) gives an opinion on the reliability of the European Union accounts for 2013.
General revenue for 2013 is legal and regular.
The 2013 budget commitments are generally legal and regular.
Payments for 2013 are largely affected by errors.
The Court therefore gives its opinion on the lack of legality and regularity.
The text of the Statement of Assurance is set out in Chapter 1 of the Annual Report for the financial year 2013. The Court estimates the error rate of 4.7 % in 2013 compared to the error rate for 2012 (4.8 %) and at a constant level above the materiality threshold at a level of 2 %. ο Overall, the audited supervisory and control systems in 2013 ensured that the level of regularity of payments compared to the error rates in 2012 (4,8%) and that the error rate in the two areas of regional policy, transport and energy at a level of 6,9% and in rural development, the environment, fisheries and health at a level of 6,7%.
The total error rate in shared management, including in agriculture: market support, direct payments and employment and social affairs, was estimated at 5.2%. ο The remedial actions and recovery by the authorities in the Member States and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
General results 05 Appropriate use of EU funds EU funds for 2013. Each year the Court reviews EU revenue and expenditure and participates in the assessment of the reliability of the annual accounts and in the assessment of expenditure and revenue in accordance with rules and rules.
In 2013, spending from the EU budget amounted to EUR 148.5 billion or around EUR 290 per citizen.
These expenditures account for around 1% of the EU's gross national income and account for around 2% of the total public expenditure of the EU Member States.
The EU budget is adopted annually by the European Parliament and the Council on the basis of the seven-year financial framework.
It is first of all the Commission's responsibility to ensure that the budget is spent properly.
In the case of around 80% of expenditure, in particular in the field of agriculture and cohesion, the Commission shares this with the EU Member States.
Where's the money coming from?
The EU budget is financed from different sources.
The largest share is payments made by Member States on the basis of their gross national income (EUR 110,0 billion).
Other sources include payments made by Member States on the basis of VAT (EUR 14.5 billion) and agricultural duties and duties (EUR 15.4 billion).
The annual EU budget is spent in a number of policy areas (see Figure 1).
Payments are intended to support different activities, such as research projects, unemployment training or agricultural production.

Overall results 09 Errors, waste and abuse The Court's assessment of the error rate is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency or waste.
This is a harmful part of the funds that could not be paid because they were not used in accordance with the rules in force.
Typical errors include payments for ineligible expenditure or purchases for which procurement rules have not been correctly applied.
Fraud is a deliberate fraud aimed at obtaining benefits.
The Court shall refer the cases under review and suspected fraud to OLAF (the Anti-Fraud Office of the European Union), which shall be responsible for carrying out any further investigations in cooperation with the authorities in the Member States.
A comparison of the error rates estimated for the different expenditure areas is shown in Figure 5.
Greater amounts in the field of research and other internal policies and in the field of administrative and related expenditure have been compensated by lower amounts in the field of rural development, the environment, fisheries and health and external relations, external assistance and enlargement.
As in 2012, two areas of expenditure in the area of regional policy, transport and energy, as well as rural development, the environment, fisheries and health were the most defective.
These two areas, together with the other two areas of shared management (agricultural: market support and direct payments and employment and social affairs), show an estimated 5,2 % error rate.
For all other operational expenditure (mainly managed directly by the Commission), the estimated error rate was 3.7 %.
Moreover, the Court noted an estimated error rate of 1,0% in administrative expenditure.

Overall results 12 The Court analyses the contribution of the different types of errors and the different expenditure areas to the estimated overall error rate (see Figure 6).
Expenditure which did not meet the necessary conditions for the implementation of projects financed by the EU accounted for the largest part of the estimated total error rate (including ineligible costs in the cost statement: 39% or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
Secondly, projects for which either the financed action or the beneficiary should not have received support in accordance with the applicable rules (non-qualifying projects/actions or beneficiaries: 22% or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
As the largest expenditure area, which is still the largest estimated error rate, the area of regional policy, transport and energy is by far the largest source of the estimated overall error rate (44% or 2.1 pro-points of the estimated overall error rate).
Agriculture: Market support and direct payments, where the level of expenditure was almost the same, contribute approximately half as much to the estimated overall error rate.
Recovery measures have a positive impact on the level of error in the Member States and the Commission by applying corrective measures to protect the EU budget in the case of ineffective control systems or irregular expenditure.
If such corrective action had not been taken with regard to payments in 2013, which the Court had audited, the estimated total error rate in 2013 would have been 6,3% instead of 4,7%.
However, the estimated error rate could be further reduced by better application of existing control systems and corrective actions.
The Court found that, in the case of a significant proportion of the errors in shared management, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct errors before applying for a refund to the Commission.
For example, this would reduce the estimated level of error in regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9% to 3.9%, in rural development, the environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0%, and in employment and social affairs from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges related to the provision of reliable financial information There is no clear distinction between the main types of correction and the information provided to a large extent outside the accounting system in the reports of the above corrective corrections.
This hinders a more in-depth analysis and reduces the accuracy of the accounting data and the related financial statements.
Further changes are the increasing use of financial instruments supporting investment in potentially viable projects in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms.
Due to the complexity of financial instruments, the assessment and recording of financial instruments require particular care in accordance with the international public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in amounts to be financed from future budgets The main features of EU budgetary and financial management in 2013 include: ο a significant increase in the amount of payments that the Commission could make in the amending budgets: 9.6% of the original budget; ο a steady increase in the commitments that in the future will amount to payments (by 2.6%) despite the large amount of payments; ο a long period (on average over two years) between the date of the initial budgetary commitment and the date of acceptance of the statement of expenditure by the Commission; ο only 37% of the appropriations for the financial instruments were paid to the final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; ο refunds, interest and dividends of EUR 259 million that were collected since 2008 - were not included as revenue.
What are commitments and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements: commitments (amounts to be paid in the current year or in the coming years) and payments (amounts to be paid in the current year).
Payments may only be made in respect of important budgetary commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitment and payment appropriations shall be set out in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and Parliament.
The nature of EU spending programmes, in particular the long period between commitment and payment, creates increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This is due to the much higher payment budget in 2013 and this trend will continue in the same way in future budgets.
General results 14 How does the Court consider that budgetary and financial management can increase the accuracy of data by collecting information under traditional accounting systems; ο shall record and evaluate all financial instruments and financial instruments in accordance with internationally recognised accounting rules in the public sector, in particular through reliable procedures for the determination and recording of impairments; ο shall provide information on the cash that is maintained until the final beneficiaries are paid; ο shall draw up and publish forecasts of the long-term cash flows that are updated annually, which would make it easier for stakeholders to identify future payment needs and to identify budgetary priorities. ο For more information on this subject?
Full information on the main findings of the audit can be found in Chapter 1 of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
The overall results of EU 15 funds and their results should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (savings, efficiency and efficiency).
In this context, input data (financial, personal, material, organisational or regulatory), results (to be achieved under the programme), results (to be achieved by the programme, initial changes to the programme among direct or direct beneficiaries) and impacts (long-term social changes, at least partly linked to EU action) are needed to achieve good results.
The Court assesses these aspects in its economic audits.
The effectiveness of the use of EU funds in the 2007-2013 programming period, which focuses on absorption (use it or fate it in the event of non-use) and on compliance and not on good results, is not given sufficient attention.
For example, when selecting projects for EU funding, there was a need to use the EU funds available; there was a need to comply with the rules, but only in the third place, but only to a certain extent to achieve results and results.
This focus on results is crucial in the way a large part of the EU budget is built.
According to the Commission, the focus for the 2014-2020 programming period is more on mitigation, with the performance reserve being the main stimulus.
With these reserves, the Commission will retain 6 percent of the resources allocated to individual Member States until they are considered satisfactory.
However, in practice, the input and output indicators will remain broadly in line with the release of measures.
The performance indicators will only be applied by the Commission in certain areas.
The more efficient functioning of performance-related reserves will depend on how effectively the Commission will negotiate the relevant intermediate objectives and objectives at the beginning of the programming period and on whether the Member States will obtain accurate, reliable and up-to-date data to determine whether these objectives have been achieved.
The reporting framework is not appropriate for the desired culture of results The implementation reports are divided into several general reports at the level of the general budget.
These reports do not provide information on progress towards the Europe 2020 objectives and do not provide a complete picture of the results of the EU added value.
However, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction, as it seeks to combine the main financial programmes with the available information on the results that are relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of each Directorate-General of the Commission, the performance targets in policy areas of their competence shall be set out in the management plans and then presented in the annual activity reports.
The Court's analysis of the management plans and the annual reports on the activities of the Commission's DG has shown that the assurance of reliability is limited to the aspects of the regularity and internal control and that it does not take account of the performance aspects.
Moreover, the objectives are too general to be used for management purposes, and the selected indicators are not always suitable for the purposes of measuring the results.
Overall results 16 The added value of EU spending is not always demonstrated In 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013, in the framework of performance control, a wide range of issues were discussed and the EU intervention was assessed in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (savings, efficiency and efficiency).
The Court examined the conclusions of its special reports adopted in 2013 in order to prepare new programmes and projects for the 2014-2020 programming period and concluded that the EU added value could not always be guaranteed. ο In many cases, i.e. the beneficiaries carried out activities without EU support.
Example: The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides compensation to workers affected by collective redundancies.
The Court found that a third of the support would be used for actions that would still be paid by the Member States (Special Report No 7/2013 on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which, in the context of the reintegration of redundant workers, would bring EU added value? on the reintegration of redundant workers).
For example, the Commission's risk-sharing funding mechanism has not shown enough that EU funding under the risk-sharing financing instrument (the financing instrument aimed at facilitating access to debt financing in the field of research) leads to more investment than in the event that the beneficiaries would not invest public funds in it (Special Report No 2/2013 did not ensure the Commission's effective implementation of the Seventh Framework Programme for Research? not enough).
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented Follow-up of the Court's recommendations as a result of the audit of budgetary implementation are a key element of the cycle of responsibility and can contribute to the effective implementation by the Commission of the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court examined how the Commission's recommendations in the eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010 were fully or largely implemented by the Commission and concluded that 79% of the recommendations were adopted by the Commission.
The Court recommends the Commission: ο Commission should improve the reporting framework for the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ο Commission should ensure that the evaluation report contains a summary report that gathers all available information on the progress made towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. ο Commission should continue to develop its performance and reporting management system so that it can assume responsibility for sound financial management and the contribution of the EU budget to achieving the policy objectives.
Full information on the Court's evaluation of the results can be found in Chapter 10 of the EU budget and Chapter 10 of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/en/Pages/AuditReports Opinions.aspx.

Import duties and the sugar production levy collected by the Member States' authorities on behalf of the EU accounted for 10% of EU revenue and the remaining 6% of other revenue.

General information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is an independent audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It covers about 900 employees of all EU countries, which consist of auditors and employees working in the horizontal service.
Since its creation in 1977, it has increased its awareness of and contributes to the EU's financial management.
The Court's audit reports and opinions are an important part of the EU's liability chain.
Our results will be used to hold the bodies responsible for EU financial management responsible, especially under the discharge procedure, under the responsibility of the bodies responsible for the financial management of the EU.
This is mainly about the Commission, but it also applies to other EU institutions, bodies and agencies.
In the case of shared management, Member States also play an important role.
Our main task is to: ο audits of accounting and compliance checks, mainly with regard to the statement of assurance; ο audits of efficiency in matters that are chosen in such a way that our work is most effective; ο opinions on legislation on financial management and other important issues.
We are trying to use our resources to strike a balance between the different fields of activity to achieve sound results and a suitable range of different areas of the EU budget.
General information 38 Our results We present the following results: annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund; annual reports mainly cover audit opinions within the framework of the Statement of Assurance and Results; annual reports containing audit opinions on agencies and other EU bodies; annual reports containing 53 reports in 2014; specific reports on selected audit topics published in the course of the year; mainly reports on results; in 2014 around 25 reports will be published; EU opinions used by the European Parliament and the Council in the adoption of EU legislation having a significant impact on financial management; in 2014 six opinions will be published; EU analyses on selected EU policy areas where greater challenges and long-term trends are analysed; EU opinions in 2014; EU annual activity report containing information and clarifications on our activities.
Our work contributes to raising awareness of and transparency in EU financial management, ensuring the reliability of financial management and recommending further improvements.
This is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union.
For information on the Court's audits of the agencies and other decentralised agencies of the European Union, see the corresponding annual reports for the financial year 2013, available on the Court's website.
The European Court of Auditors is an independent external audit body of the EU - guardian of EU funds In its annual reports on the EU budget and the European Development Fund, the Court is issuing an audit opinion (confidence certificate) on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This summary summary summarises the main findings and conclusions.

INTRODUCTION 1. The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) established in Ljubljana was established by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council1.
The Agency's main task is to assist national regulatory authorities in the performance of regulatory tasks in the Member States at Union level and, where appropriate, in the coordination of the activities of those authorities.
In the framework of the Regulation on the integrity and transparency of the wholesale energy market (REMIT Regulation) 2, the Agency, together with the national regulatory authorities, receives additional tasks to monitor the European wholesale energy market3.

The Agency's objective is to assist national regulatory authorities in the performance of regulatory tasks in the Member States at Union level and to the extent necessary to coordinate their activities.
Tasks - complementing and coordinating the work of the national regulatory authorities, - contributing to the development of the rules on European networks, - under certain conditions - taking binding individual decisions on the conditions of access and operational security of cross-border infrastructure, - advising the European institutions on energy issues, - monitoring the development of energy markets and reporting, - preparing a proposal addressed to the European Commission on the annual amount of cross-border infrastructure compensation under the ITC mechanism, - cooperating with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities to monitor energy markets in wholesale trade, - assessing the functioning and transparency of the various categories of markets and trades, - making recommendations to the Commission on market rules, trade registers, trade orders, standards and procedures that could improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.
Composition of the Management Board: The Management Board shall consist of two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Each member has an alternate.
Tasks: The Management Board shall adopt the Agency's annual work programme, adopt its budget and monitor its implementation.
The Executive Director will be appointed Director on the basis of a positive opinion of the Board of Regulators on the basis of ADB001375DE04-12PP-CH058-12APCFIN-RAS-2011_ACER-TR.DOC 19.9.2012
Composition of the Board of Regulators: The Board of Regulators shall consist of high-level representatives of the regulatory authorities of each Member State and a representative of the Commission without voting rights.
Each member shall have an alternate appointed by the relevant national regulatory authority of each Member State.
Tasks: - The Board of Regulators shall present opinions to the Director on the opinions, recommendations and decisions to be adopted. - The Board of Regulators shall present the Director in the course of the performance of its duties. - The Board of Regulators shall present an opinion to the Administrative Board on the candidate to be appointed Director. - shall approve the Agency's work programme.

In the first year of ACER's activity, ACER had to employ a large part of its employees, which involved problems and caused the job vacancies to be filled with delay, which was clearly reflected in the utilisation rates of the Agency's budget.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 evaluation report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the urgent need to clarify the roles and responsibilities and to analyse the workload of the contracting entity in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures.
The IAS also concluded that the planning and monitoring of public procurement should be significantly improved.
The Agency and IAS have agreed on a corrective action plan.
The Agency has allocated EUR 4.9 million and 86% of the appropriations entered in Title III (operational expenditure) for the following financial year (EUR 1.4 million and EUR 59% respectively in 2015).

In Title II (Administration expenditure) in Title II (Administration) respectively, the Agency transferred EUR 1 million and 38% of the appropriations (EUR 0,8 million and 35% respectively) to the following financial year.
