COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.33.8.
In 2017, procurement and grant procedures were not adequately documented.
In the case of service contracts in the form of low and medium value contracts in published procurement documents, in the absence of documentation to calculate the initial selection of candidates in the case of low value contracts, the Authority has not drawn up assessment reports in respect of low value procurement procedures and has not drawn up assessment reports in respect of the procedures for the award of fixed-term service contracts.
Furthermore, the award criteria have not been clearly defined.
As regards the award of grants, risk assessments were inappropriate and the expert reports were not signed.

The prices applied on a case-by-case basis for services shall be based on unit prices (price/personal day, etc.) established in framework agreements and on the number of units for which the service may be recognised.

3.34.10.
However, for the framework agreement procedure of EUR 80 million for general advisory, advisory and project management services, as well as for research, the list of services to be provided under the framework agreement has not been drawn up.
As regards the evaluation of tenders, the tender descriptions contained two business scenarios for project management and a programme covering several projects.
The Framework Agreement is a multi-faceted framework agreement, which partly covers the cascade procedure (general advisory services and project management services) and partly the call for competition (practic and research).
The Authority has previously identified the entities and the tenderers have been asked to determine the breakdown between the various profiles.
Therefore, the framework agreement and some of the individual related agreements were announced on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not on the basis of the expected number of units they benefit from, which is another important element in the calculation of the fixed price agreement.

The Authority takes note of the Court's observations.
It should first be noted that the scenarios described in the public procurement documents for future uses of the contract were intended to achieve the objective of clarity and reliance and not to expect that they would be specifically linked to each specific contract.
As regards the adequacy of the new competitiveness mechanisms and in line with the Authority's response to the 2016 audit, this concept has already been included in the Narrow Framework Agreement on Audits and Research.
The Authority compared the added value of the mechanism with the administrative costs incurred and, in view of the Authority's intensive use of advisory and project management services, concluded that this is not the most efficient way of managing the latter services.
Note that the current Framework Agreement for 2020 has the power to extend this mechanism to consultancy services and project management services would require a new call for proposals at this stage, which the Authority considers inappropriate.
In the existing cascade system, the Authority shall once again respond to the 2016 audit for the purposes of the application of fixed pricing procedures.
The main reason for this option is that proceedings against the Office before the Spanish labour courts for the transfer of workers that are not justified is, inter alia, related to the use of the ăTime and Means system.
In the case of a fixed price procedure (under the cascade system), the Authority shall have experience in the evaluation of tenders.
EUIPO has established a dedicated team which, on the basis of previous practice and expertise, is able to determine what resources are needed to carry out the tasks which are necessary to carry out tasks which are outside fixed price services.
However, we believe that the Court's doubts can be resolved by other contractual methods than the fixed price, e.g. by the procedure ăquoted Time and Means... which can in the future be dealt with by the Office in individual cases.
The Authority undertakes to provide further information and to document its own resources necessary for the performance of fixed price service tasks prior to the submission of a request for a tender in order to provide evidence of the above mentioned experience of the Authority prior to the submission of a request for a tender.

The contributions collected in advance in favour of the Fund shall be calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee of credit institutions and to certain investment firms.
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework to ensure the compatibility of this information, the SRF devotes all possible attention to this aspect.
The data shall be reported on the basis of the data provided by the institutions in the previous year and the data contained in the ECB's database.
The differences are displayed to the national resolution authorities which are asked to clarify the facts, which allowed the SRF to improve the quality of the data in previous cycles.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot disclose the details of the previously collected contributions to the institution, calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, since the calculations are limited and thus disclose confidential information on other institutions.
However, the SRF revealed the method of calculation and detailed calibrations to ensure transparency and cooperation.
3.35.12.
In 2017, the financial team was unable to find experienced employees, thanks to the combination of unexpectedly high workload, unfortunate fluctuations of employees in the financial team and general difficulties in finding experienced employees.
Since the 4th quarter of 2017, the team has been reconstructed and measures have been taken to ensure timely processing of invoices.
So far, almost 98% of invoices have been paid in 2018.
Any delay in payments is currently being examined in detail in order to further improve in this area.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/219 PL ANNEX Follow-up of the Court's observations in previous years The reports on tenders and evaluations drawn up by the Procurement Committee and the Agency's Employment Committee do not provide a complete and practical picture of the procedures used.

DE C 434/220 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 of the AGENCY's replies 3.39.8. Currently, electronic submission of tenders is limited to open procedures (the thresholds are set out in Directive 2014/25/EU on public procurement and amounted to EUR 135 000 in 2017).

For the Commission, the Agency's results have been assessed externally in 2012-2015, which was presented in the final report in May 2016.
The evaluation concluded that the Agency carried out its tasks in an efficient, efficient and costly manner during the period in question, and that its tasks and the Commission's recommendations are still relevant in the most efficient, efficient and costly manner and that the Commission's operational tasks for the Agency have been successful.
However, the evaluators have also contributed to an even more effective and efficient skills development. The Agency and the Commission have been asked to improve internal dialogue and cooperation, communication and certain aspects of IT and human resources management.
The Agency and the Commission have agreed on a corrective action plan.

In 2017, REA carried out only one low-value award procedure.
The current tools for the electronic invitation to tender and the electronic submission of tenders are only applicable for public contracts above the threshold of EUR 144 000. Since the REA has not yet launched a procurement procedure above this threshold, it has not been able to use the tools for the electronic invitation to tender and the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.

The Executive Agency for Consumers, Health, Agriculture and Food (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established on 1 January 2005 (2005-2008: the Executive Agency for Health and Consumers (PHEA), 2008-2013: the Executive Agency for Health and Consumers (EAHC), from 1 January 2014: the Executive Agency for Consumers, Health, Agriculture and Food (307).

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors shall be the institution responsible for the financial control of the European Union (EU) in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external EU auditor, we contribute to improving the financial management of the EU, while at the same time acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
For more detailed information on our work, see the Annual Activity Report, www.eca.europa.eu, and the Special Reports on EU spending and revenue programmes, as well as the opinions on new or revised legislation.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, which concerns the financial year 2014.
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately.
0.3.
The EU's general budget shall be adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report together with the special reports is the basis for the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, on the basis of a recommendation from the Council, decides whether the Commission has carried out its tasks with regard to the implementation of the budget to the satisfaction of the Commission.
At the same time, we are forwarding our annual report to the national Parliaments, together with the transmission to the European Parliament and the Council.
0.4.
The main element of our annual report is the statement of the reliability of the consolidated financial statements of the European Union and of the legality and regularity of transactions (hereinafter referred to as "the regularity of transactions") and (hereinafter referred to as "the regularity").
We complete this statement of assurance through detailed assessments of all the main areas of EU activity.
0.5.
The structure of the chapters now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), and therefore our report is even more important.
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 in order to determine the volume and distribution of EU expenditure in the period up to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to establish the relationship between the findings in our report and the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate financial statements for each MFF action and therefore the proposals presented in each evaluation do not constitute an audit opinion.
0.7.
In Chapter 2 we present our findings on budgetary and financial management. In Chapter 3 we present our strategic objectives for improving EU public responsibility. In Chapter 5-9 (MFF 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5 tubes) (MFF 1a, 1b, 4 and 5 tubes) (MFF 1a, 1b, 4 and 5 tubes) (MFF 1a, 1b, 4 and 5 tubes) (Rums) (Rums on the regularity of transactions and on the control of selected systems and annual activity reports).
0.8.
The Commission's (or, where appropriate, other EU institutions and bodies' replies) replies to our comments are contained in the report and our findings and conclusions are in line with the replies of the audited entity.
However, as an external auditor, our task is merely to present our findings from the audit, to learn from these findings, and thus to carry out an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions.
(1) How are no detailed assessments of expenditure on actions of the MFF 3 (Security and citizenship) and 6 (non-counting figures?) are presented?

DE C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 to the European Parliament and to the Council Statement of Assurance to the Court of Justice I. For the financial year ending 31 December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015, we conducted a study: (a) the consolidated accounts of the European Union in the form of a consolidated financial report and a consolidated report on the implementation of the budget [2], and (b) the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying that financial report in accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
Responsibility for the management of II. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for drawing up and submitting the consolidated accounts of the European Union correctly on the basis of recognised international public sector accounting principles and for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This liability shall include the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements which are free from material or unintentional misconceptions or.
The Commission is ultimately responsible for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
It is our task to present to the European Parliament and the Council, on the basis of our control, the statement of assurance of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We have conducted our research in accordance with international auditing standards, as well as with IFAC's professional behaviour requirements and international standards for INTOSAI's highest control bodies.
In accordance with these standards, we must respect the requirements of professional behaviour and plan and conduct studies in such a way as to ensure that the consolidated financial statements of the European Union are free from significant bad presentations and that the underlying transactions are legal and regular.
IV. The audit shall include the carrying out of audit activities to obtain evidence of the audit of the value and other information contained in the consolidated accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The choice of audit activities shall be the responsibility of the auditor, including the assessment of the risks associated with the material or unintended misrepresentations in the consolidated accounts and in the material or unintended infringements of European Union law in respect of the underlying transactions.
When assessing those risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant to the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions to plan the controls relevant to the circumstances, but not to give an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
The audit shall also include an assessment of the adequacy of the accounting rules applied, the reasonableness of the estimated accounting values, as well as of the total consolidated financial statements.
V. In the area of revenue, as a starting point for our analysis of VAT-based and gross national income-based own resources, we use macroeconomic aggregates that are relevant for their calculation, and we evaluate the data processing systems by the Commission until the Member States receive their contributions and until they are received in the consolidated financial statements.
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine the customs accounts and analyse the flows of customs duties until they are received by the Commission and until the amounts are entered in the accounts.
1. Consolidated financial statements shall include the balance sheet, profit and loss account, cash flow account, changes in the net asset value and summary of the relevant accounting rules and other explanations (including segmented reporting).
In the area of expenditure, we check the payment transactions after the expenditure has been made, covered and accepted, we check all types of payments, with the exception of advances and advances, after the expenditure has been made, with the exception of payments for the acquisition of assets.
Advances shall be examined if the beneficiary has to provide or provide evidence that they are properly used and the advance is settled or may be recovered.
VII. We believe that the evidence obtained is sufficient and adequate to serve as the basis for our opinions.
Reliability of the accounts The audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts VIII. According to our assessment, the consolidated accounts of the European Union for the year ending 31 December 2014 presents, in all material respects, the financial situation of the Union, the results of its operations and the cash flows, as well as the changes in the net assets for the financial year ending that day, in accordance with the Financial Regulation and the accounting principles based on the international accounting principles of the public sector. Legality and regularity of the underlying transactions Payment Audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the underlying revenue IX. According to our assessment, the revenue underlying the accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 is in all material respects legal and regular.
Expenditure incurred in 2014 under the operational budget under headings 1 to 4 of the multiannual financial framework (3) is to a large extent affected by errors.
Our estimated error rate in the payments underlying the accounts is 4.4%.
Our proposal is confirmed by the analysis of the risk levels presented by the Commission in the summary report.
It follows from our assessment that the payments underlying the financial statements for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 are to a large extent to blame for the error in the assessment of the reliability and regularity of the payments underlying the financial statements for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 as regards the reliability and regularity of the payments referred to in paragraph as regards the lack of assessment of the reliability and regularity of the payments underlying the financial statements.
3. These headings will be discussed in Chapters 5 to 8 of this annual report.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT PRELIMINARY EU expenditure is an important tool for achieving the policy objectives 1.1.
EU spending is an important tool for achieving policy objectives.
Other important instruments are legislation, the free movement of goods, services and capital and the free movement of persons throughout the Union.
EU spending averages 1.9% of total EU spending (see Figure 1.1).
In line with the Treaty, it is our task, inter alia, to assess whether the use of EU budget resources is in line with applicable legislation and other legislation; to assess EU financial statements; to report on savings, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU expenditure; to present an opinion on legislative proposals with financial implications.
Our research in support of the Statement of Assurance meets the first and the second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that have a negative impact on economy, cost-effectiveness and efficiency.
It also makes an important contribution to the drafting of an opinion on the proposed financial rules.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.11.
Overall, in the last three years the results have remained relatively unchanged, at a level much higher than our indicative materiality level (see Figure 1.2).
REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.11.
The Commission notes that the error rate notified by the Court constitutes an annual estimate taking into account the accounting corrections of project expenditure that were made before the Court's audit was announced.
The Commission recalls that it is bound by a Financial Regulation in which Article 32 (2) (e) provides that its internal control system should, inter alia, ensure adequate management of the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multiannual nature of the programmes and the nature of the payments concerned.
In its 2014 summary report (COM (2015) 279 final), the Commission assessed the future impact of the correction mechanisms on EUR 2.7 billion, representing 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
The Commission will continue to exercise its supervisory role by making financial corrections and recovery at the level corresponding to the level of irregularities and irregularities found throughout the period and at the end of the programmes.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.12.
EU expenditure consists mainly of two types of expenditure programmes which have different types of risk (12): programmes based on payment entitlements which depend on the fulfilment of certain conditions; these programmes include scholarships for students and research scholarships (Chapter 5), direct payments for farmers (Chapter 7), direct budget support (Chapter 8) and remuneration and pensions (Chapter 9); programmes for the reimbursement of eligible costs by the EU which include research projects (Chapter 5), investment programmes for regional development and rural areas (Chapter 6 and 7), training programmes (Chapter 6) and development projects (Chapter 8).
(12) Points 1.20 to 1.22 describe in detail these different risks.
(13) Budgetary support payments contribute to the general budget of the State or to the budget allocated by the State for specific policies or objectives (see also paragraphs 8.7 and 8.8).
DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT New approach to scrutiny...
In 2014, we reworded our approach to quantifying serious infringements of public procurement rules.
This approach explains how we assess the effects of these infringements.
In particular, we have introduced a proportionate approach to the calculation of the errors associated with the change of contracts.
1.14.
To ensure comparability of the results presented in this report, we adjusted the figures for 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and in figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6, in line with this new approach.
Annex 1.4 presents unchanged historical data on the estimated error rate calculated for the period 2009-2013.
As a result of this adjustment, the estimated total error rate in 2013 was reduced by 0,2% and by 0,3% in 2012.
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions we have reached for these years, and this is still a significant level of error.
1.15.
In 2015, we will adapt our approach to cross compliance to the revised legal framework of the common agricultural policy.
We will continue to report on the information provided by the Commission on cross compliance, but this element will no longer be the subject of our controls.
This year we have discovered many errors in cross-compliance in respect of every fourth of the farms covered by the visit.
The share of these errors in the estimated total error rate shall be 0,2 percentage points (2013: 0,2) ((14))) and 0,6 percentage points (2013: 0,5) in the error rate in the chapter on natural resources in this chapter.
The Commission welcomes the revision of the Court's approach since 2015.
As regards 2014, the Commission confirms that the breach of cross-compliance does not affect the eligibility conditions for payments (see the Commission's reply to paragraph 7.7).

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.18.
Errors in eligibility in reimbursement schemes have a major contribution to the errors detected in 2014 (see also paragraphs 1.20 to 1.22, graph 1.5 and graph 1.6). (a) For reimbursements, the estimated error rate is 5.5 % (2013): 5.6 %).
Typical errors in this area include: inclusion of ineligible costs in the cost statement, including ineligible projects, actions or beneficiaries, including serious breaches of procurement rules in the course of the award of contracts, including serious breaches of procurement rules in the course of the performance of the contract (i.e. changes in contracts and additional contracts).

Our examination of errors and corrections of the ed is aimed at examining complex mechanisms for the implementation and recording of corrective actions and explaining the various ways in which these mechanisms can affect our examination work.

Corrective measures 1.31.
We are trying to take account of the corrective actions taken by the Member States and the Commission prior to the payment or our investigation.
We also note the corrections that occur after our audit announcement, but we cannot reduce the estimated error rate each time the control itself triggers the corrective action (24).
We verify the application of these corrections (including the recovery of funds from beneficiaries and corrections at project level) and, where appropriate, adjust the calculation of the error rate.
However, the effects of corrective actions vary considerably depending on the area of expenditure and corrective actions.
1.32.
The Commission and the authorities of the Member States have taken corrective measures in respect of 24 sampled transactions in 2014, which had a direct impact on the operation in question and were relevant for our calculations.
These corrective actions have led to a reduction of our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (in 2013 1.6 percentage points), corresponding to around EUR 1.6 billion.
Changes in the number of transactions and the impact on the estimated error rate do not indicate that the corrective actions are more or less effective: in view of the relatively small part of our sample, it can be expected that they will change from year to year.
1.30.
The Commission considers that the annual representative error rate of the Court should be considered in relation to the Commission's ability to correct the various annual activity reports and in the summary report.
The Financial Regulation requires appropriate consideration of the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the control systems and the nature of the payments.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.35.
The corrective actions discussed in this Section of the annual report shall include the work of the Member States' authorities as well as the recovery operations carried out by the national authorities and the Commission.
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT The consequences of the corrective action are largely evident when the Commission accepts the expenditure 1.36.
All relevant sectoral regulations on shared management contain provisions on pre-control or reduction of amounts declared by final beneficiaries prior to the declaration of expenditure by national authorities.
In some cases, national authorities also agree to reduce or remove some of the costs that, due to errors of long-term impact, appear in the declarations (such as continuous payments under the contract, where there is an error in the rules for the award of public contracts).
Such adjustments may have a measurable impact on the level of refunds on individual projects or on the level of aid paid to individual farmers and the correction contributes to the reduction of our estimated error rate.
1.37.
For direct and indirect management, the amounts which are recorded by the Commission shall include, inter alia, the deduction of amounts which are not eligible for payment applications prior to the approval of payments.
Eligibility of amounts shall be determined on the basis of the examination of the documentation available or on the basis of the results of the checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7).
This also allows us to lower our estimated error rate.
Conformity decisions (on financial corrections in the agricultural sector) are often taken in a flat-rate manner.
In general, they refer to system flaws rather than to errors at the level of the final beneficiaries.
In rare cases, they entail recovery of quotas from the farmers concerned.
Such corrective measures encourage Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of transactions at the level of the final beneficiaries if they lead to permanent improvements in the accounts of expenditure accepted by the paying agencies (see Boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
In addition, the Commission services shall recover funds from the Fund on the basis of the deduction of ineligible expenditure (as defined in previous or current accounts of expenditure) from payments made.
1.38.
Financial corrections by the Commission in respect of agricultural expenditure are intended to protect the EU budget and require Member States to apply them.
They do not directly lead to recovery of payments from farmers, as the Commission does not pay directly to the final beneficiaries, but returns payments made by Member States to farmers.
However, if payments are not identifiable as a result of the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect Member States to continue to verify them by means of recovery actions against beneficiaries.
See response to Box 1.3.
The paying agencies shall implement conformity decisions by reducing future requests by the Commission for reimbursement of payment costs to farmers.
The Commission shall record the full amount paid to farmers as expenditure, which means that the adjustment does not entail a reduction in the amount of payments covered by the payments.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and refunds to paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26).
Over two thirds of financial corrections in 2014 in the area of cohesion in...
1.40.
In the area of consistency, financial corrections for more than two thirds of the total amount included in the report shall be those where the public authorities in the Member States withdraw the expenditure concerned and replace it with new expenditure.
For some cases of withdrawal, no specific projects can be considered to be withdrawn.
Instead, Member States report additional projects and therefore receive de facto lower co-financing rates.
1.40. The Commission considers that any financial corrections, including corrections, for which Member States have the right to submit new projects and new expenditure to re-use the corrected amounts, protect the EU budget against illegal expenditure and encourage Member States to recover amounts from beneficiaries (and thus contribute to improving management and control systems).
However, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, where Member States are unable to re-use the corrected and recovered amounts and are therefore losing resources, is certainly higher.
(26) For example, if the paying agency in the agricultural sector, which makes a financial correction of 5%, makes a payment to farmers of EUR 100 million, the Commission will reimburse the payment of EUR 95 million, while the Commission will pay EUR 100 million, which will be covered on the basis of assigned revenue of EUR 5 million.

"" "" "" "" """ "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" """""""""" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" "" """""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""
The Commission expects net corrections to be applied to a wider extent in the future as a result of changes in legislation. 1.41.
For example, in the agricultural field, the legislator decided to apply a similar net financial correction mechanism to cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period.
This provides an additional incentive for Member States to prevent or detect serious irregularities in their management and control systems and to remove them before their financial statements are transmitted to the Commission.
Otherwise, and if the Commission or the Court continue to detect serious deficiencies after the submission of the accounts, the Commission must make a net financial correction under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, which means that the Member State concerned has lost its financial resources.
The Commission also considers that, under shared management, any financial corrections and recovery have a negative impact on national budgets, regardless of how they are implemented.
In order to avoid the loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace expenditure not eligible for additional operations eligible for aid.
This means that a Member State and its national budget bear the financial consequences of the loss of EU co-financing, which is considered ineligible, provided that the Member State does not recover the amounts from the individual beneficiaries.

Box 1.2.2 For more information on the improvement of management and control systems in Greece: Improving the land identification system The Commission has taken action to improve the identification system for agricultural parcels (LPIS), which serves as the basis for payments to agricultural holdings, for example under the single payment scheme (the largest EU spending system).
This process took place at various stages and led to a reduction of permanent grassland from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014, included in the GreekLPIS.

Action plans shall be implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission shall carefully monitor their implementation and report on the corrective actions taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
The land identification system prevents beneficiaries from seeking claims in respect of land which does not exist or which does not fulfil eligibility conditions or in respect of land in respect of which another beneficiary has already made claims.
With proper implementation, this is a very effective tool to reduce error rates.
It covers 75% of CAP expenditure.
According to the Annual Activity Report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development for 2014, the error rate for area payments is lower than for other measures.

In previous annual reports, we stressed that this approach does not encourage beneficiaries to correct errors (32).
The main reasons for the correction were the weaknesses in the LRIS/GIS system (EUR 695 million) and the ceiling for payment entitlements, which led to an excessive payment for farmers (EUR 41 million).
Another reason, although to a lesser extent, was the breach of the cross-compliance obligation with regard to the timely notification of movements of animals (EUR 123 million).
All these reasons relate to payments made between 2009 and 2013.
No adjustment was made in 2014 and the non-compliance with the ceiling for payment entitlements and non-qualifying land covered by the PDO in France contributed to an increase in our estimated error rate for natural resources of 0,3 percentage points this year.

A financial correction of EUR 1.1 billion will be reimbursed to the EU budget in three annual instalments (2015-2017 and 2017).
The Commission notes that, given the nature of the ex post conformity clearance procedure, which applies very rarely, after the clearance of the accounts procedure in the year and after the end of the adversarial period, in which the Member State concerned may present its own arguments and calculations, the Commission shall decide on the financial correction in the following year of expenditure.
The ongoing conformity clearance procedure will ensure that the EU budget is protected for 2014.

In 2013, we managed to reduce the estimated error rate for a number of Romanian projects of the European Social Fund (ESF) because the national authorities identified the impact of the corrections at the project level.
This was also the case in 2014.
Some of the projects we have examined are still flawed due to problems that are not covered by the corrections.
In its 2014 Annual Activity Report, Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Integration (DG EMPL) indicated that it continued to monitor the implementation of the agreed action plan.
Revised financial corrections do not necessarily mean that Romania will receive less EU funds because Member States can benefit from the possibility of recovering more expenditure (33).

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/37 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT In its report on corrective actions, the Commission does not always quantify their different effects,...
1.43.
Explanation 6 on annual accounts is largely voluntary disclosure which is not required in accordance with accounting principles.
A significant part of this information does not come from accounting systems.
The explanation describes the different impacts of the different adjustments to the EU budget, but not always in quantitative form... and further improvements would allow for a better analysis of 1.44.
The Commission's ability to improve the quality of expenditure is linked not only to the amounts concerned but also to their impact.
A rigorous assessment of the impact of corrective actions requires better identification of the type of corrected error and the way in which corrections are made (34).
Where the relevant Commission Directorates-General assess the impact of their corrective actions, they shall make the necessary adjustments to the figures set out in note 6 (see point 1.55).
The Commission's summary report confirms significant errors in transactions 1.45.
Each Directorate-General of the Commission shall draw up an annual activity report.
This report shall report on the implementation of the main policy objectives (as approved in Chapter 3), the management report prepared by the Director-General for the College of Commissioners and the statement in which the Director-General (Directives) accepts the assurance that the financial information contained in the report is adequately presented and that the transactions that fall under its responsibility are legal and regular.
1.43.
The legislator has provided the Commission with the financial correction instrument to ensure that the expenditure effected unlawfully is not financed by the EU budget.
Financial corrections mainly relate to system flaws that lead to a risk of error.
The task of the Member States, not the Commission, is to establish irregular amounts and recover them from the beneficiaries.
If this is not the case, EU funds will be replaced by national funds, as national budgets have to bear the cost of financial corrections.
1.44.
Several services have adjusted their figures in their explanations 6 in relation to the protection of the EU budget in order to allow for the estimation of future corrections in relation to their specific circumstances.
(34) See paragraphs 1.13 to 1.15 of the annual report for the financial year 2013.

This section of the chapter contains the results of our analysis of the annual reports on the activities of the Directorates-General and the Commission summary report[35].
It focuses on the coherence and adequacy of the Commission's estimates of the error rate at the time of reimbursement or reimbursement by the Commission of its own expenditure (the Commission refers to the amount of risk to the greater extent that the errors will be corrected by subsequent corrections (the Commission refers to its ability to correct or to estimated future corrections at most (36)).
The Directors-General shall report annually on the regularity of 1.48.
If the Directors-General are unable to guarantee credibility in respect of a significant part of the expenditure, they raise reservations (see Box 1.5).
Directors-general should do so when, having a serious impact on the reputation of the Commission, or, still have a significant impact on the impact of the estimated error rates reduced by the financial corrections already made and the recovery of funds.

DE COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.50.
In line with the proposal of the discharge authority in 2014, the Commission developed internal guidelines (45) for the submission of information in the annual activity reports.
Directors-general are now to present the average error rate detected (46).
The application of this error rate to the total payments for a given year leads to the calculation of the risk amount of that year[47].
The summary report sets out this amount together with estimates of the future ex post audit capacity carried out by the Commission. The Commission acknowledges that expenditure is heavily affected by errors.
1.51.
In its 2014 summary report, the Commission identified a risk amount of between EUR 3.7 and EUR 5 billion.
This corresponds to between 2,6% and 3.5% of the payments included in the 2014 summary report[48].
These figures show that total expenditure is largely affected by errors... but indicate the estimated impact of future corrections of 1.52.
The 2014 Summary Report provides for the total estimated value of future corrections (correction potential).
On the basis of the corrections registered over the last six years[49], the Commission estimates that in the coming years it will be able to detect and correct errors in the total amount of around EUR 2700 million over the next six years.
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC (2014) 553).
(46) This is the level of error detected or estimated at the time of payment (not the residual error rate), i.e. without the correction resulting from errors corrected in advance.
